HEADLINE: High Prices In London For Picasso And Monet 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL

DATELINE: LONDON, June 30 

 BODY:
The world was a rosier place this time last year, when no one could have ever imagined the events of Sept. 11 or the scandals at WorldCom, ImClone Systems, Tyco International and Xerox. Yet despite last week's stock market jitters and a general nervousness about the economy, the important annual auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art here proved that the rich feel more confident putting their money in Picassos, Monets or Legers than they do in financial markets. 
 "There are a lot of people who have made money and simply want to enjoy themselves," said Melanie Clore, deputy chairman of Sotheby's in Europe and co-chairwoman of its Impressionist and modern art department. "Everyone these days wants an escape." 
 That is not to say that bidding was fast and furious all week. Collectors showed restraint, knowing exactly what they wanted and what they were prepared to pay. The big spenders, however, were mostly Europeans, something that has been true now for the last year. 
"The economic perspective from Europe is more confident than that of the United States," said Robin Woodhead, Sotheby's chief executive for Europe and Asia. That, coupled with a reluctance to fly since Sept. 11, may have accounted for the noticeable absence of American collectors in the salesrooms.
But who actually bought the top two paintings of the week -- a 1932 Picasso portrait that sold for $23.9 million and the dreamy Monet "Waterlilies" that went for $20.1 million -- is part of the mystery that is the allure of auctions. While the person raising the paddle may be a well-known dealer, art adviser or auction house expert taking a telephone bid on behalf of a client, the font of gossip and speculation as to who writes the checks and whose living room the works will magically appear in is as addictive as collecting itself. Even the auction houses do not always know who the real buyers are. But when they do, their lips are sealed. 
Still, patterns emerge each season. "It's a masterpiece market at the moment," said Tobias Meyer, director of Sotheby's contemporary art department worldwide. Paintings that scream the signature of a big-name artist are more in demand now than the more intellectual works, which often remained unsold or went for bargain prices. And just as they had at the May auctions in New York, top examples by personalities like Gerhard Richter and Giacometti, whose recent retrospectives at the Museum of Modern Art in New York got rave reviews, were hotly sought after. 
Sotheby's and Christie's each had a star work in Impressionist and modern art. At Christie's it was Picasso's "Nude With Necklace," a 1932 portrait of the artist's mistress Marie-Therese Walter. Four bidders were willing to spend more than $10 million on the painting, which ended up selling to Libby Howie, a London art dealer, for $23.9 million, way above its $13.4 million high estimate. It became the highest priced work of the week. Ms. Howie is said to buy art for an Arab collector. At Christie's in New York in 1997 she bought one of Picasso's series "Women of Algiers" from the collection of Victor and Sally Ganz for $31.9 million. 
Sotheby's most important work of the week -- Monet's 1906 "Waterlilies," which brought $20.1 million, just under its $22.5 million high estimate -- was bought through David Norman, Sotheby's director of Impressionist and modern art in New York. Experts trying to predict the buyer think it may have been one of two Americans, Stephen Cohen, a Manhattan hedge fund manager, or Henry Kravis, the financier. 
The painting had been hidden away in an unidentified private collection in France for more than 60 years and was considered by art historians to be one of the best of the Monet series. Some experts thought the painting could well have fetched an even higher price and were surprised when the Picasso surpassed it by $3.8 million. The reason, experts rationalized, was that three such "Waterlilies" were up at auction recently, and one is back on the market in New York. But Jussi Pylkkanen, head of Christie's department of Impressionist and modern art in London, said he believed that "collectors are moving their tastes forward." "As Impressionist paintings are becoming rarer, tastes are becoming more avant-garde," he added. 
Some experts noted that the price for the Picasso had more to do with supply and demand. Bidders applying the acumen of a Wall Street analyst who perceives that a 1932 Picasso is rarer than a Monet "Waterlilies" because fewer have been up for sale recently made the price rise to nearly twice its high estimate. It also seemed cheap compared to other Marie-Therese portraits that Picasso painted the same year; they have brought more than $40 million at auction. 
When a top Impressionist work was up for grabs, however, bidding was competitive. At Christie's, "Vetheuil," a sun-dappled Monet landscape of the town 40 miles from Paris where the artist lived for three years from 1878, brought $7.5 million, well above its $5.2 million estimate. The buyer was Gilly Kinloch, a British art adviser. Ms. Kinloch made another big purchase last week, too, a Degas pastel "Dancers" (1880-85), which was on the cover of Sotheby's Impressionist and modern catalog. She paid $3.3 million, just shy of its $3.5 million high estimate. While nobody knew or would say who she was bidding for, Ms. Kinloch is known to be the art adviser for Lord Harris, a carpet manufacturer from London. 
Continuing a trend that has been evident for the last few years, top German Expressionist paintings were hotly pursued. At Sotheby's, "Nudes in the Sun, Moritzburg," a 1910 landscape by Kirchner, incited a bidding war among three determined parties. The painting, which depicts six bathers in a lush green landscape, sold for $5.2 million, a record price for the artist and above its $4.5 million high estimate. The buyer was an unidentified telephone bidder.
(Final prices include the auction house commission. At Sotheby's and Christie's it is 19.5 percent of the first $100,000 and 10 percent of the rest. At de Pury & Luxembourg it is 15 percent for the first $50,000 and 10 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.) 
Determined to be a player that rivals Sotheby's and Christie's, Phillips de Pury & Luxembourg (for legal reasons, however, the Phillips name cannot be used in Britain for several years) held its first sale in London. It took place last Monday afternoon in the ballroom of Claridge's, where Champagne was freely flowing for the collectors and dealers as they entered the makeshift salesroom. The auction had less fizz than estimated, with most works selling at or below their estimates. 
About one-third of the sale was bought by the Nahmad family, Lebanese dealers with galleries in New York and London, who have been among the biggest buyers at auction for years now. The Nahmads were big buyers at Christie's, too, fueling speculation that both auction houses may have given them special terms of payment. But no one was willing to comment, least of all the Nahmads. 
"These were our style of paintings," said David Nahmad, one of the principals who is based in New York, after he had bought millions of dollars worth of Picassos, Vlamincks, Matisses and Pissarros. "We sustained the art market through the 1960's, 70's and 80's. I used to buy a lot more." 
During the contemporary art auctions the majority of buyers were collectors, not dealers, and they bought selectively. While mediocre Warhols and lesser examples of the so-called Young British Artists failed to sell, both Sotheby's and Christie's managed to get some high prices for a few works. 
At Christie's five bidders tried to bring home a 1962 untitled Basquiat that sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $2.1 million, above its $1.8 million high estimate. Later that evening 19 telephone bidders went for "Composition," a 1951 abstract drip painting by Jean-Paul Riopelle. 
"It's considered his best work," said Brett Gorvy, who is co-head of Christie's contemporary and postwar art department in New York, when the painting brought $965,683, more than four times its high, $225,000 estimate. The total for its sale was $13.3 million, just above its low $12.9 million low estimate. 
Sotheby's sale of contemporary art was far stronger, bringing in $21.5 million, topping its $19.6 million high estimate, making it the highest total for a London contemporary art auction in 12 years. It's success was due in part to the high prices paid for artists like Mr. Richter, Francis Bacon and Lucio Fontana.
"There was fearless buying for great quality," said Mr. Meyer, the evening's auctioneer. "The desire to buy was so strong I could literally feel the energy of the bidders."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 2, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Arts yesterday about art auctions in London last week misstated the date of an untitled work by Jean-Michel Basquiat that sold for $2.1 million. It was 1982, not 1962.

HEADLINE: DoubleClick Sells Its Media Sales Businessto L90 

BYLINE:  By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
DoubleClick, the Internet advertising company, has sold its North American media sales business to L90, a former competitor in that business, for $9.4 million in cash and stock and possibly another $6 million if performance thresholds are met, the companies said on Sunday. In addition, L90 will change its name to MaxWorldwide when the deal closes, which the companies expect to happen early this month.
 The deal solidifies an emerging strategy for both DoubleClick and L90, analysts said, in that it moves DoubleClick further away from advertising sales and allows it to concentrate on its advertising technology and data analysis tools. L90, meanwhile, has been focusing more on ad sales, and less on advertising technology. 
 L90 had for years operated in a manner similar to DoubleClick, in that it sold online ad-delivery and tracking technology to advertisers, while also selling advertising inventory on behalf of a network of hundreds of Internet publishers. Last year, L90 sold its ad-delivery and tracking technology, adMonitor, to DoubleClick.
Including the 850 sites that DoubleClick used to sell online ads on behalf of -- among others Edgar Online and Dilbert.com -- L90 now represents a network of more than 1,000 sites, the company said.
Analysts said the move was good for both companies. "The network ad model has not been terribly profitable for anyone, much less someone with DoubleClick's scale," said Rudy Grahn, an analyst with the online consulting company Jupiter Research. "And since this is such a bad ad market, and DoubleClick is focusing on profitability, it's right for them to jettison this business."
For L90, Mr. Grahn said, this deal represented a chance "to buy in at a much better price than they would have been able to pay once the market rebounds."
L90 will have a new stock symbol, MAXW, and is moving its headquarters from Los Angeles to New York. It said in a news release that with DoubleClick's North America sites now included in its network, its advertisers can reach about the same number of Internet surfers as they would on AOL, MSN and Yahoo.
But Jim Nail, advertising analyst with Forrester Research, a technology consulting firm, said that it would be a mistake for advertisers to consider L90 the peer of the big portals. "What advertisers want is to reach a particular kind of target audience," he said. "In an ad network with several hundred sites, even if you group them into auto, or women's sites, the range of content means there's no consistent audience."
On AOL, by contrast, the content breakdown is meant to draw certain types of consumers, like car buyers, for instance, who better suit advertisers' needs, Mr. Nail said. Still, L90 "can probably make a nice little business" from selling ads on its network after the DoubleClick deal.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
With the Lifestyle Comes the Access to Information
From Greenwich to East Hampton, on helicopters ferrying investment bankers into town and in the steam room of Park Avenue's Racquet Club, the cognoscenti can recognize a familiar facet of the tale of Martha Stewart and her friend, Samuel D. Waksal of ImClone. They were entwined in a Manhattan grapevine where the exchange of corporate information is a social custom.
 Where power, access and social advantage intersect, information that many would consider privileged is passed as casually as canapes. Section A. 

Offering Is This Week for CIT Group
The offering of the CIT Group, which is expected to raise about $5 billion for Tyco, will give the conglomerate much-needed cash and give CIT access to the short-term commercial paper market. Market Place. C2.

Ashamed to Be an Executive
The stream of corporate scandals -- WorldCom, Global Crossing, Enron -- has appalled some longtime technology leaders. "I've been in business for 40 years," said Andrew S. Grove, left, the chairman of Intel, but lately, "I find myself feeling embarrassed and ashamed" to be a businessman. New Economy. C3.

DoubleClick in Deal With Rival
DoubleClick, the Internet advertising company, has sold its North American media sales business to L90, a former rival. C8.

A Dispute Over Wireless Networks
Time Warner Cable has warned some cable-modem subscribers that operating wireless networks and inviting others to freely share them violates their subscription agreements. The action highlights a potential conflict between advocates of free, wireless networking and the broadband providers. C4.

Amazon Expected to Sell Apparel
Amazon is expected to open an online apparel store, helping to fill a hole in its product mix. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C6.

Group Returns to Wartime Mission
The Ad Council, which was established in 1942 to rally support for the war effort, is returning to its original mission. Advertising. C8.

In the latest example of how TV programming and advertising are becoming indistinguishable, Levi Strauss has paid for an actor featured in a commercial for its Dockers pants to appear on a show on Fox Sports Net. C7.

Random House Executive Is Moving
The publisher Phyllis Grann, left, is leaving Random House after six months, complaining of boredom with her job, people close to Ms. Grann said. Her departure follows her resignation last fall as chief executive of Penguin Putnam and extends a story that has captivated the publishing industry. C7.

A Patent to Deal With Angry Callers
Two inventors have patented a voice-prompt system that detects outrage or anger in a caller's voice, and directs the caller to customer-service operators trained to handle customers who are spoiling for a fight. Patents. C2.

Battle for Control of Czech Station
In the Czech Republic, a fight is brewing for a control of Eastern Europe's most popular television station, a battle that threatens the future of the channel and of its director. C2.

PERSON: Clifford Possum 

HEADLINE: Clifford Possum, a Painter Of Aboriginal Masterworks 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SHAW 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, June 29 

 BODY:
Clifford Possum, who painted some of the masterpieces of Australian aboriginal art, died on June 21 in Alice Springs in the Australian desert, an ancient landscape he depicted in the mythical terms central to his heritage. He was about 70, art historians said.
 In accordance with tribal tradition, details of his death, the long illness that preceded it and his exact age were not disclosed by his family. 
 Mr. Possum, known among the Ammatyerre people as Kumuntjayi Tjapaltjarri, was the first Australian aboriginal artist to gain international recognition. He cleared the paths to artistic and economic success that many indigenous painters have followed since the 1970's by invoking sources and spiritual beliefs thought to be many thousands of years old.
Since 1974 Mr. Possum's paintings, mixing symbolism and abstraction, have been shown in solo and group exhibitions and sold to major galleries and collections in Australia, the United States, Europe and Asia.
His work had its first public exhibition in the United States in 1980, in Los Angeles. His first major New York exhibition was in a group show at the Asia Society in 1988.
In the United States his work is in the collections of the Kelton Foundation in Santa Monica, Calif., the Lowe Art Museum at the University of Miami and the Pacific Asia Museum in Los Angeles.
On June 24 five of his works were sold in Melbourne at Sotheby's Australia for more than $20,000 each; one, "Love-Sun Dreaming," was bought for $60,000.
The record auction price for a Possum painting is $68,000, paid by an Australian public gallery last year for one of his earliest works, a 1972 landscape. At the time he painted it, some of his depictions of what is known as the Dreaming, a legendary time akin to creation or Genesis in other cultures, were selling for less than $50.
Mr. Possum, who adopted that name for nontribal use after a stay in the 1940's at a Christian mission where he was nursed for malnutrition, began painting after 15 years of work on a cattle ranch. 
At Papunya, a remote government settlement for the desert people, a teacher, Geoffrey Bordon, encouraged aborigines to counter feelings of alienation by recording traditional images and themes in modern media, like acrylic paint on hardboard and later on canvas. This was the cradle of the Desert Painters movement in aboriginal art. 
Dr. Vivien Johnson, a historian of indigenous art at Macquarie University in Sydney, wrote that Mr. Possum quickly showed himself to be "an accomplished and inventive artist, an exponent of striking multilayered visual effects, meticulously rendered."
Tim Klingender, director of the indigenous art department of Sotheby's Australia, said that many collectors and galleries rated Mr. Possum "high in the pantheon of aboriginal painters" for his "innovative visual language and complex narratives of myths."
In June the Australian government awarded Mr. Possum the Order of Australia medal for his service to the art movement and to the indigenous people.
Critics and collectors rate his numerous works since the 1980's below his achievements in the 1970's, and his scarcer earlier canvases draw higher prices.
Mr. Klingender estimated that several such works in private American collections would bring about $500,000 each if sold at auction now.
Mr. Possum's survivors include two daughters, Gabriella and Michelle; a son, Lionel; and 11 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Democracy in Africa 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Africa's New Realism," by Thabo Mbeki (Op-Ed, June 24): 
 Many African leaders have high hopes for the New Partnership for Africa's Development, an African-conceived program through which African countries demonstrate a commitment to advancing democracy, human rights and the rule of law in exchange for additional resources from the industrialized world. 
As Mr. Mbeki says, an "independent mechanism for peer review" is central to the partnership. 
 But the response to the Zimbabwean crisis is undermining the program. Zimbabwe is on the precipice of a devastating famine of Robert Mugabe's making, the latest of the illegitimately re-elected president's ploys to maintain power. African leaders, with a few exceptions, have been silent. Until they show a commitment to the program's goals, Zimbabweans and other Africans will pay the price.

(Rep.) EDWARD R. ROYCE
Chairman
Subcommittee on Africa
Washington, June 25, 2002

HEADLINE: Irking Democrats Is Part of Job for a House Leader 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30 

 BODY:
Maybe all the complaints about the confrontational, partisan style of Representative Bill Thomas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, come with the territory. That, at least, is what he suggests.
 "If they spend a lot of time complaining about me, maybe that means I'm doing my job," Representative Thomas said last week, between a fight with Democrats over trade and a fight with them over prescription drugs. After all, Mr. Thomas's defenders say, the chairman of Ways and Means, who has vast responsibility for tax, economic, welfare and health policy, is rarely beloved by the minority party -- or rarely even "a really nice guy," as one Republican put it. 
 Even so, the animosity between the Democrats and Mr. Thomas is striking these days -- emblematic, in its way, of a mean political season as the midterm election approaches. It was apparent this week, as Mr. Thomas, 60, a Californian in his 24th year in the House, muscled through a bill adding prescription drug benefits to the Medicare program, a bill that Democrats -- and even some Republicans, privately -- say is headed toward oblivion in the Democratic-controlled Senate.
Democrats denounced Mr. Thomas's legislation as a "fraud," a "sham" and a "placebo made in the dark." It is, one said, a bill "written by the drug companies." It was pushed through the House under procedures typical of "Soviet-style democracy," another said.
Mr. Thomas says the Democrats simply cannot handle the idea that Republicans, not Democrats, are moving to deliver a sweeping new entitlement to the nation's elderly or the idea that the Democrats are no longer running the show as the majority.
"Their biggest problem," he said in an interview, "is not that the majority is fair -- and fairer than they were -- when we work our will. It is that we are the majority and they are not. And for members who were around for a long time, who came in when the Democrats were the majority, who grew up in the committee system as the majority and who expected to finish their careers as chairmen of the committees, it is a very, very frustrating time because Republicans came in and took away their birthright."
Mr. Thomas's relationships with the Democrats, notably with Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, who would be the Ways and Means chairman if the Democrats controlled the House, have been fraying for a long time. But even some Republicans complain at times about Mr. Thomas's edge. Some textile-state Republicans sharply criticized him last week, saying he had blindsided them with changes in a trade bill.
His allies acknowledge the problem. "He doesn't suffer fools well, and that's not to say anyone's a fool," said Representative Jim McCrery, Republican of Louisiana. "But I know that he knows that that's a fault of his, and that for the last couple of years he's been working on it, trying to become more tolerant in more situations."
Mr. Thomas's temper was an issue when he sought the chairmanship in 2000, but his policy expertise and legislative skill clearly outweighed it. With the backing of J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House, he won the post over a more senior Republican on the committee.
While acknowledging that he has shortcomings, Mr. Thomas suggests that his personality is ideally suited for the job of pushing through his party's economic agenda with one of the smallest majorities in history, a five-vote Republican edge.
"Why did Eisenhower give Patton the job of moving across Germany at lightning speed?" he says. "Because he knew Patton would do it. Sometimes hills just need to be captured."
Democrats have taken to goading Mr. Thomas. Committee hearings presided over by Mr. Thomas and Mr. Rangel can be almost painful, like dining with a couple on the brink of divorce, who know each other's vulnerabilities far too well.
Mr. Rangel began an interview about Mr. Thomas by saying, "I don't have any training in psychiatric evaluation; I'm a mere lawyer."
Mr. Rangel added, "He sets the tone, and the tone is one of exclusion -- under the excuse that that's how he feels he was treated in the minority."
Mr. Thomas said that he would like to work with Democrats but that Democratic leaders discouraged it. He said that he had reached out to Mr. Rangel but that Mr. Rangel appeared more comfortable in the role of an aggrieved outsider.
All this means that Mr. Thomas, and the other Republican leaders, often must pass major legislation with almost nothing but Republican votes. This can be very hard when the legislation is complicated, like the prescription drug bill, which some Republicans considered too big an entitlement, others too little.
Mr. Thomas, a former political science professor and state legislator, has steeped himself in health policy over the years, particularly the Medicare program. Many say that his is the most influential vision on health care in the Republican Party and that this makes him a lightning rod for liberals. They argue that his desire to see more competition and more private health plans involved in Medicare is a step toward privatizing the program.
His prescription drug bill, in fact, would deliver benefits to the elderly by giving subsidies to private health plans that offered coverage. Mr. Thomas dismisses the talk of "privatization" as a political scare tactic.
Charles N. Kahn III, president of the Federation of American Hospitals and once on Mr. Thomas's staff, said of Mr. Thomas: "He's a wonk. He firmly believes in private sector and market approaches to the extent possible. And he feels very strongly about the pull of policy as well as politics."
Mr. Thomas refuses to accept the idea that the bill just passed in the House is essentially a political document with little chance of final passage. "I'm not in this for charades," he said. "I don't start things for them not to become law."
The son of a plumber, Mr. Thomas said his hobbies involve working with his hands: carpentry and rebuilding old cars. They require the same kind of puzzle-solving that draws him to legislation, he said, choking up when he talked about suddenly seeing solutions and being able to make a difference. "I'm not easy to get to know," he acknowledged.
Mr. Thomas said he loved his job. "I didn't like it for the first 16 years very much because I thought my talents were not being used," he said, speaking of his time in the minority. "Sixteen long years is the way you say it."
The Democrats would understand.

HEADLINE: California Officials Wrangle Over Plans for Great Park 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif., June 28 

 BODY:
It had always seemed a given that once the residents of the vast suburban stretches of Orange County decided what the shuttered El Toro Marine Corps Air Station here should become, a decade of epic battling would end and the workaday task of drawing up plans and calling in the earthmovers would begin. 
 That decision came in March, when voters soundly rejected plans for a big new airport in favor of what has long been called the Great Park. Though there is still some legal skirmishing, the park the voters selected would fill a great part of the 4,700-acre site, a billiard-table-flat collection of deserted runways smack in the center of the county. Many here say it would become America's greatest urban park. 
 But now, as planners try to figure out how to build and pay for the park, and lawmakers wrangle over the details, it is starting to look as if the political battle was the easy part.
"I would say one book is written now in this story, but it's going to be more than one book," said Todd Spitzer, a county supervisor who fought against the airport for years. "Another book is going to be written about what happens with that 4,700 acres. We just haven't had time to focus on that part yet."
Many expected the Navy to give the land to the county at no charge, as the military has sometimes done in other base closings. But the Navy decided to sell it in pieces to the highest bidders, collaborating closely with local governments. 
The sales could net more than $1 billion and have a profound impact on Orange County, which has nearly three million people and is often described as a collection of suburbs in search of a downtown. 
Given the new economics of the site, local planners are preparing to allow developers to build on perhaps two-thirds of the old base, with projects including a university campus, an industrial park and golf courses surrounded by homes.
What will be left for the promised park? Perhaps 350 prime acres where abandoned runways now sit.
"What we all campaigned for was to have a Great Park," Mr. Spitzer said. "But it's not going to be a great big park. The economic developments are going to drive how much open space there will be. The land use will be driven by the economics."
Larry Agran, mayor of the City of Irvine, which is next to El Toro and is expected to annex the land, said, "Well, it's a development plan with the idea of a Great Park." 
There is another complication. Residents of the poorer, more densely populated northern half of the county are demanding that some of the revenues generated by private development be used to build smaller parks in their area. 
"I think if it's done right the entire county would benefit and tourism would benefit," said John Palacio, president of the school board in Santa Ana, an overwhelmingly Latino working-class city just to the north. "Some of that money must be used to build parks in our area, too." 
Cynthia P. Coad, another county supervisor, has threatened to stop Irvine's annexation of the base and construction of the park unless the planners promise that $800,000 a year will be dedicated to creating parks in the north. "I'm not interested in megaparks," Ms. Coad said. "I want neighborhood parks in the heavily built up areas of the north county." 
Irvine's city manager, Allison Hart, has been working closely with the Navy to draw up a sales plan that will include a master plan for how the properties can be developed once they are sold to private companies. 
Irvine's plan looks far different from what residents voted on in March, when 3 percent of the base site would have been turned over to private developers, leaving 97 percent for various public purposes.
The new plan involves giving developers 18 percent of the land and leaving 82 percent for public park space, which would include convention centers, educational campuses and the like. Private money would finance all the development.
As conceived now, there would be a 1,000-acre natural habitat on the northern end of the land, close to 300 acres of agriculture, some of which would be a prison farm, a 75-acre cemetery (the first in Irvine), 45 holes of golf, more than 400 acres of housing (25 percent of which would have to be for low-income residents) and several hundred acres of industrial and commercial development.
The 350 acres of park would lie in the middle, divided by some creeks.
Daniel Jung, Irvine's director of strategic programs, said the site might include some housing planned in the almost-freakish expectation, for California, that people would be close enough to public transportation and shopping that they would not use their cars every day.
"It's a development you haven't really seen in Orange County," Mr. Jung said. 
Some officials have insisted that the park would vault Orange County into the nation's first ranks. But while people here often cite other major urban parks in the region as models, it is clear that the comparisons come up short.
For instance, Balboa Park in San Diego, the park most often cited, is just 1,200 acres, but it is in the middle of a dense urban setting. It is home to 15 museums, the San Diego Zoo and a theater.
North of Orange County is Griffith Park, near the heart of Los Angeles. It consists of 4,107 acres of mountainous wilderness and only a modest amount of development. There is the Los Angeles Zoo, the Autry Museum of Western Heritage, a theater, an observatory and lots of sports fields, but mostly heavily wooded hillsides and canyons. 
The El Toro site is flat, a big chunk of it covered with asphalt from the old runways. It is surrounded by suburban development and a clean-looking, high-tech industrial park. 
"It's hard to know what the draw would be," said Con Howe, the planning director for Los Angeles. "It's not surrounded by dense urban development. It's suburban. It's not an immediate area that is open-space-starved. And it does seem like from the get-go they have no natural character there to work with." 
Ms. Hart, the Irvine city manager, suggested that those opinions miss the point. 
"This is a total free-market experiment," Ms. Hart said. "We want to take a little more time to package this and then it's rock 'n' roll."

HEADLINE: Some Conservatives Question the Value of Reorganizing Domestic Security 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30 

 BODY:
He has no realistic hope of stopping the proposed Department of Homeland Security -- a reorganization of federal agencies that official Washington suddenly considers vital to the prevention of terrorism -- but John J. Duncan Jr. says he is seriously considering voting against it.
 Representative Duncan, a Republican from Tennessee with a record of trying to knock down government projects, says the department will become another overgrown garden. He has no illusions, though, about why his colleagues will probably pass it overwhelmingly. 
 "Almost everyone in Congress wants to be seen as doing something big and lavish for homeland security, so they'll vote to create this new department," he said. "But I'm not sure it's going to make the dramatic difference that some people are hoping for." 
Mr. Duncan is the sole member of Congress who openly speaks of opposing the department. But several other conservatives on and off Capitol Hill are asking whether rearranging agencies will truly improve the nation's defense against terrorism.
Ivan Eland of the Cato Institute, a libertarian research group in Washington, wrote that the department was "designed to pretend that the administration is doing something," rather than to improve the nation's efficiency at gathering intelligence or plugging holes of vulnerability.
"Even before the September attacks, the U.S. government had sufficient bureaucratic machinery to deal with terrorist attacks on the homeland without adding a new department," wrote Mr. Eland, the group's director of defense policy studies, in a paper this month. "But in Washington, the typical response to any crisis is to rearrange organizational charts and add bureaucracies. The real problem revealed by the terrorist attacks is too much bureaucracy -- causing too many communication and coordination problems -- not too little."
In an interview, Mr. Eland criticized the administration for failing to reduce duplication and waste before announcing the plan. He said 11 government agencies -- including the departments of Commerce and State -- have intelligence departments. But rather than combining those, he said, the White House proposed a department that would demand more money and employees.
Despite such criticism, the momentum for the new department appears unstoppable. Democrats were the first to propose it, and most Republicans trudged along after the administration made the idea its own. Even conservative editorial pages like those of The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Times grudgingly set aside their opposition to bigger government and agreed.
The administration insists that creating the department will not in itself cost taxpayer money. In testimony before Congress this month, Tom Ridge, the White House director of domestic security, said the department "would not grow government," and he predicted that the expenses of creating any new functions would be offset by the savings derived from eliminating duplicated services. 
But many conservatives said they heard such promises when the departments of Education, Energy and Transportation were established.
Stephen Moore, the president of the Club for Growth, an antitax political action committee, said any new cabinet department creates a demand for money. He cited the same postwar reorganization President Bush brought up this month.
"Homeland security should have been a function of the Department of Defense, and that's what they originally had in mind when they created it back in the 1940's," Mr. Moore said. "That department was originally supposed to keep us safe from foreign invaders, but our foreign policy has become so adventurous in the following years that now they say we need a new department to handle the job."
Mr. Duncan said his staff had found that the growth of each modern cabinet department had outpaced the inflation rate.
"We've got to start asking these questions now, before it becomes just another department that greatly increases our expenditures," he said. 
Although they have stopped short of expressing outright opposition, several other members of Congress have voiced doubts about whether the proposed agency would make domestic protection more efficient. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, wrote to Mr. Ridge this month urging him to ensure that the new department reduces government security costs.
"I am going to watch that agencies losing staff or funds do not try to replicate what they give to homeland security just to keep their turf," he wrote.
Some liberals have also raised warnings. Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat who is the ranking member of the House Appropriations Committee, has railed about what he calls haphazard planning. Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, the ranking member of the House Judiciary Committee, said the department was intended to deflect attention from the intelligence failures of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency. He also said that moving agencies from one department to another had rarely solved problems.
Congressional conservatives who normally oppose large government initiatives said this plan was different because of the national sense of emergency and the perception that the security structure had failed.
"I always have a concern about more bureaucracy," said Representative Bob Barr, Republican of Georgia, an outspoken conservative. "But in this case there's not much doubt that things weren't working the way they should work."
Mr. Moore said conservatives should seek something in return for a new department. "We ought to have a position of no growth in cabinet departments," he said. "In exchange, couldn't they at least get rid of the Commerce Department?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative John J. Duncan Jr. says a new security department will be another overgrown garden. (Carol T. Powers for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Waiting for Ground Zero Proposals 

 BODY:
Those who care passionately about the rebuilding of downtown Manhattan now find themselves in an anxious limbo. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has promised that by mid-July, the public will see a half-dozen options for reclaiming ground zero. The waiting would be easier if we were totally confident that everyone else is waiting, too. The corporation chairman, John Whitehead, and Gov. George Pataki need to assure the public repeatedly that no developer, no advocate group, no politician is slipping through the back doors to wield insider clout while everyone else is standing quietly on the sidelines. 
 By offering the public a series of different visions for how to rebuild, officials hope to provoke debate and discussion. Those planners who are involved in creating these options promise that they will include some proposals that will be bold and provocative, as well as some that will seem very predictable and conservative. Every week it becomes clearer how difficult a task it will be to balance the concerns of all those who believe they own a part of Sept. 11. Families, residents, corporations, public authorities, politicians -- a wide range of New Yorkers all have their varying and sometimes conflicting demands. None of these groups alone can be permitted to control the future of this site. 
 Looking at the decision-making process from the outside, we can see the pressure building. Some business executives are lobbying hard for a large network of stores with covered streets so that stoplights and walk signs will not distract shoppers from their mission as consumers. If we are looking for a splendid urban plan that revives the area and restores the spirit, a mall is hardly the answer.
On the other side of the emotional spectrum are the families, many of whom are grieving and understandably see the site only as a place where their loved ones died. Mayor Michael Bloomberg expressed himself clumsily recently when he said that workers and residents do not want to live and work around a cemetery. Still, he revealed the concerns of many people who have their own large stake in the planning and revival of Lower Manhattan. As Madelyn Wils, a representative of downtown residents, put it last week, downtown should be revitalized, not consecrated.
That does not mean any lessening of the importance of the memorial that must be at the center of any rebuilding on ground zero. But there are many ways to memorialize those who lost their lives Sept. 11. Some of those monuments could feature a tranquil park or a cultural center with the best music and art that this ambitious city has to offer. With the hiring of a new director to focus on the memorial, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation should be able to listen to the many evolving ideas while holding the memorial's design to the high standards the site and the city demand.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers In Hartford Send Budget To Governor 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 30 

 BODY:
Six hours before the start of Connecticut's 2003 fiscal year, lawmakers approved a revised $13.2 billion state budget this evening that would cut spending, increase taxes and avoid potential layoffs and state-agency shutdowns that Gov. John G. Rowland had warned of two days ago.
 Lawmakers also voted today to reduce the legal blood alcohol limit for drivers to 0.08 from 0.10. 
 The revised budget would increase a smattering of taxes by a total of $270 million, roughly 2 percent, and reduce state spending by approximately $305 million, though the new 2003 budget would still grow by 3.4 percent, double the rate of inflation, over the fiscal 2002 budget. 
The governor is expected to sign the revised 2003 budget into law Monday, the same day he has scheduled three appearances around the state to officially announce his bid for a third term in November. 
Connecticut passes state budgets two years at a time, in odd calendar years. The Legislature passed the original budget for the fiscal year 2003 last year, but since then revenue has fallen more than $800 million short of projections, forcing Democratic lawmakers who control the Legislature and Mr. Rowland, a Republican, into protracted talks recently over how to balance the books.
The governor criticized the Legislature's Democratic leadership as unrealistically wishing for no spending cuts, while the Democrats hammered Mr. Rowland for refusing to consider a temporary tax on millionaires to offset the deficit. 
As the new fiscal year drew closer without a spending plan in sight, Mr. Rowland began speaking publicly about the possible need to lay off state workers, freeze the wages of others and even consider limited shutdowns of certain programs. 
None of it came to pass, but today Republicans and Democrats in the State Senate and House of Representatives each voiced only limited satisfaction with their compromise. 
"This is not the best budget we've ever done," Kevin B. Sullivan, the Senate president pro tempore, told reporters after the Senate approved it by a 20-to-11 vote. "It's somewhere between, 'It's not too bad' and 'It's good.' "
Marc S. Ryan, Governor Rowland's budget chief and lead negotiator, said the new plan would give the state agencies and municipalities enough to keep most programs intact, but not as much as everyone would have liked. 
The new budget cuts $30 million from the Department of Higher Education, University of Connecticut, community colleges, Connecticut State University and the University of Connecticut Health Center. It also imposes a minimum $250 corporate tax and a $250 annual charge to small businesses. 
The budget will also keep 350 to 500 unfilled state jobs vacant, Mr. Ryan said, and freezes salaries of more than 3,000 managers in the executive and judicial branches. Deputy commissioners of six state agencies will be eliminated, he said.
Legislators from both parties said today that they realized the new budget would not solve the state's fiscal problems. Economists are already predicting deficits through 2005. To mitigate that, Democratic lawmakers said they would press for the millionaire's tax again next year.

HEADLINE: Tilting at Windmills, Only This One's a Bridge; 
Walkway Over Hudson Is One Man's Fixation

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
About a decade ago, Bill Sepe uncorked a doozy of an idea. The old Poughkeepsie Railroad Bridge -- an engineering marvel in 1888 but a delinquent eyesore ever since a spectacular fire closed it in 1974 -- should be transformed, he said, into a pedestrian skyway over the Hudson River.
 The old rail bed, wrapped in its Victorian-era lattice of steel, 200 feet above the water, would get a second life, he and others said, as strollers and bikers thrilled to the view and the history. 
 Central to the walkway plan was its seize-the-day enthusiasm. The bridge's owner at that time, in the early 1990's, had not paid taxes for years, and that made it an abandoned structure, according to Mr. Sepe, then a self-employed handyman. He began leading volunteer crews out on the rail bed to see what could be salvaged. Local politicians and business leaders, envisioning hordes of weekenders with bulging wallets, cheered the effort on. 
"He had that dream, and he infected people with it," said Robert Shepard, town supervisor in Lloyd, N.Y., on the bridge's western side. "I believed in it."
Today Mr. Sepe (rhymes with peppy) is still living the dream, but it is an increasingly lonely one. The old bridge sits silent behind a chain-link fence, locked in legal limbo. Many of the volunteers have drifted away. Some local officials have begun worrying that pieces of rusting steel, unpainted for three decades, could fall into the river. Developers of a network of hiking trails being built on old rail lines were planning a link to the bridge, but they have plotted out an alternate route.
Mr. Sepe said he blamed narrow-minded politics for the impasse. Other people, including even some of his ardent admirers, said the problem was that the bridge's fortunes became bound up too much with the vision, and the foibles, of Mr. Sepe himself. Although the dream is not dead, people on both sides of the river agree that what eventually happens will depend less on rusting rivets than on the temperament and tactics of the man who would be the walkway king.
"The bridge is his life," said Dick Coller, a retired electrical engineer who has worked closely with Mr. Sepe for years and once led tourists out on the bridge to the viewing platform that the volunteers helped build about 1,200 feet from the western side. "But he wants to do it his way."
Town officials in Lloyd are more blunt. "The man is an idiot," said David L. Butler, supervisor of the Building Department and its chief code enforcement officer. 
He and other town officials say they have spent $30,000 in legal fees just for an unsuccessful effort to force Mr. Sepe's group, Walkway Over the Hudson, to comply with building and zoning regulations for the structures that were built within town boundaries. 
"If anybody else was running that organization, there would have been people walking on that bridge three years ago," Mr. Butler said. 
Mr. Sepe, now 54, said there was no doubt that the walkway consumed him and that he made some mistakes. Bridge affairs took over his home -- filling up his living room, then his dining room and his garage with files, posters and donated office equipment. It cost him his handyman business, he said, because customers objected to his running off for meetings. He has since taken jobs serving legal papers, driving a bus and most recently operating a tractor at a gravel mine in Rhinebeck three days a week, all to accommodate his bridge duties. The project was bad for his health, he said, as he gained weight from the stress. 
But he said he believed, whatever the cost and however sour things have turned out, that the original vision was right.
He insisted almost from the beginning, for example, that building the walkway would be a community affair -- a self-financed, volunteer effort that would not take a dime of government money. The government, Mr. Sepe preached, always takes control of what it pays for; conversely, any community that creates something through sweat and dedication will value it more, he said.
That idealistic view got hundreds of people involved in the early days, but later it came to seem quixotic, some volunteers said, as the dimensions of the project became clearer. Mr. Sepe said he thought a walkway could be built for $2 million; some experts have said it could cost $30 million just to paint the bridge. 
Mr. Sepe's freewheeling philosophy also ran afoul of local zoning laws after his group gained legal title to the bridge in the late 1990's.
He refused to post a $1,600 escrow payment for an engineering inspection, saying the bill was padded. Then, in the middle of the litigation, in 2000, a volunteer was seriously injured in an electrical accident while working on the bridge, and an angry State Supreme Court Justice said he'd had enough. The judge slapped a permanent injunction on Walkway Over the Hudson, barring any tours or repairs. Mr. Sepe appealed the injunction in May.
Standing on the unfinished walkway, Mr. Sepe said that if he lost the appeal, a civil disobedience campaign could be the next step. He might simply go back to work on the bridge anyway -- court injunction be hanged -- along with any volunteers who care to follow him.
"I won't be bullied," he said. 
Mr. Sepe said he believed that town officials in Lloyd had a political agenda behind their lawsuits and court orders. 
"To me, this is a right everybody has -- not to be harassed to take public money," he said. "Politicians would take money from soup kitchens. We've got a soup kitchen right here in Poughkeepsie that doesn't get adequate funding, and yet they would put money into this bridge." Town officials in Lloyd said taking the walkway group to court was simply a last resort.
"We think it's a great use for the bridge and have always been in favor of it, but we also have a responsibility to the general public to protect life, safety and welfare," said Mr. Butler, the code enforcement officer.
Many people in this part of the Hudson Valley, about 90 miles north of New York City, can claim an emotional ownership of the Poughkeepsie Railroad Bridge. For some, it stands for the days when Poughkeepsie was on every freight-hauler's map, linking New England and the Midwest. For others, it's a poignant symbol of the economic hard knocks that had begun even before the fire, as the heavy industries that once sent their freight clattering across the river faded away. It was the first bridge across the Hudson south of Albany, and for a time -- if its approach system is counted -- was also the longest in the world, at 6,768 feet. 
Judy Moran, a retired elementary school teacher, said the bridge was a link to her childhood and to her father, who worked as a switchman on the Poughkeepsie side. She was a member of Mr. Sepe's group and led walkway tours in the mid-1990's, before dropping out about three years ago in a disagreement with him over the issue of public financing. 
Mr. Shepard, the town supervisor in Lloyd, was a volunteer firefighter on May 8, 1974, when the blaze that closed the bridge broke out. It was a scary night, he said. Working high over the river, the fire crews had to tear out the oil-soaked railroad ties, which had been ignited by sparks from a train, and each tie that was removed left less for the firefighters to stand on as they worked.
Several members of the walkway group say that part of the story of the stalled walkway comes down to the question of who will, in the end, be the bridge's master. 
"Bill just doesn't want to lose control of it," said one person in the group who would speak only on the condition of anonymity, since he wants to be part of the project, which he believes will eventually resume. 
Mr. Sepe agreed that perhaps control was an issue, but he said the project was not about him. 
"I'm willing to give up control if somebody shows the commitment and wants to do it," he said. "My fear that if we give up, we'll lose the whole thing, that it'll be erased, it'll be something completely different than what we wanted. I want it to be something we did ourselves, something that we did."

HEADLINE: Part-Time Firefighter Is Held In Setting of Blaze in Arizona 

BYLINE:  By NICK MADIGAN with CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: SHOW LOW, Ariz., June 30 

 BODY:
A part-time firefighter was charged today with deliberately setting the Rodeo wildfire, which combined with another blaze a week ago to become the largest in Arizona's history.
 Prosecutors said he started the fire hoping to make money fighting it. 
 The firefighter, Leonard Gregg, 29, was arraigned this morning in federal court in Flagstaff on charges of setting two fires on June 18 near his home in Cibecue, on the Fort Apache Indian reservation.
One of them was the Rodeo fire, which on June 23 merged with the Chediski Fire to form a blaze that has devastated vast swaths of timberland, destroyed at least 423 homes and forced the evacuation of about 32,000 people.
"Can I say I'm sorry for what I did?" Mr. Gregg asked United States Magistrate Stephen Verkamp, who interrupted him before he could incriminate himself further. If convicted of the two charges, Mr. Gregg faces up to 10 years in jail and $500,000 in fines. A federal prosecutor, Paul K. Charlton, said at a news conference here that a grand jury could level more charges against Mr. Gregg, who is in custody. 
"There is evidence that he started the fire so as to earn money as a contract firefighter," Mr. Charlton said. 
In the federal courthouse in Flagstaff today, as smoke drifted overhead from the wildfires 90 miles to the south, the handcuffed Mr. Gregg was led into court wearing black jeans and a black T-shirt. Mr. Gregg, who is single and has a ninth-grade education, told the judge that he worked part time for the forestry department of the Bureau of Indian Affairs. 
The criminal complaint against him said he had used matches to burn brush, timber and other flammable material about two miles from Cibecue. He then told a woman he was with that he had to get home because a fire call was imminent, the complaint said. Mr. Gregg responded to the call to help fight the fire, which he had not expected to grow so much, the document said. He was arrested on Saturday evening and is to appear in court again on Wednesday.
It was the second time in a month that blame for a devastating wildfire had been placed on a federal employee paid to control fires. On June 16, Terry Lynn Barton, 38, a Forest Service worker whose responsibilities included enforcing a ban on fires in the Pike National Forest in Colorado, was charged with starting the Hayman fire, the largest ever in the state. It has burned 137,000 acres. She had told friends she hoped to become an arson investigator, the authorities said.
Law enforcement officials in Arizona are still trying to find who set the Chediski fire, which is believed to have been started on June 20 by a white woman who was trying to signal a helicopter after she got lost in the woods on Apache land.
The 452,000-acre Rodeo-Chediski blaze was about 35 percent contained today, with fire lines holding near here, on the fire's northeastern flank, and to the west near Forest Lakes and Heber-Overgaard. Conditions in Show Low, which seemed under clear threat of at least partial destruction just a few days ago, became so favorable early Saturday that the authorities permitted its 7,700 residents to return after being evacuated a week earlier.
To Native American firefighters, the news that one of their own had been arrested in the Rodeo blaze was a sickening blow. It seemed certain to worsen the racial tensions that have swept through the region since the fires began. Well before Mr. Gregg's arrest, some white people had accused the Apaches of setting the Rodeo blaze, and the Apaches did not dispute that.
Richardson Antonio, a Bureau of Indian Affairs supervisor for the Apache crews, who fought the fire on the northern rim in the devastated area of Heber-Overgaard, described the mood around Cibecue today as glum.
"It looks bad for the Apache firefighter," Mr. Antonio said. "A lot of white people are angry now."
"Our job is to fight fires, not set them," he said. "And I was angry this morning. I talked to the Indian men. What can we do? We got to do our job. The guys in the Cibecue crew are down. They feel betrayed. They know that guy."
Dallas Massey, tribal chairman of the White Mountain Apache Nation, said that, like many others, he was surprised to hear that one of his people might have been involved in setting the Rodeo fire. "All I know is all of our beautiful land is gone, people's homes were destroyed, we're like everybody else," he said. "I'm just in shock."
The fire is an economic disaster for the tribe. The Apaches are heavily dependent on their lumber industry, which pumps $30 million a year into a community with 60 percent unemployment. The ponderosa pines, the finest timber here, take 100 years to grow to maturity, but on the beleaguered western areas of the reservation where the rainfall and land quality is poor, it takes 200 years, Mr. Massey said.
With Mr. Gregg awaiting a court hearing on Wednesday, Chadeen Palmer, a spokeswoman for the White Mountain tribe, reminded reporters at the news conference here today that not all the facts in the case were known. 
"Until the entire investigation and criminal process are completed, we cannot rush to judgment against any individual," Ms. Palmer said. "However, the tribe expects that all persons responsible for the fire outbreak will be held accountable for the unprecedented destruction to homes, communities and forest lands."
Another firefighter who had toiled with Mr. Gregg against the Rodeo fire, Lionel Nachu, a member of Fort Apache's Swift 58 crew in Cibecue, said he found the news today hard to believe, and more so given the effort the fire required.
"We thought we had it out that first night, but the wind just took it," Mr. Nachu recalled. "We worked along with him. I can't believe it. I'm fighting for the white people's land, too. I hope they know that."
In all, about 25,000 residents of 10 eastern communities, some of them damaged by the flames, were allowed to return home, while most of those to the west of the fire, principally from Heber-Overgaard, Forest Lakes and Airpine, were not. Fire conditions there, while improved, were still volatile today, a Forest Service spokeswoman, Jennifer Byington, said. About 4,480 firefighters remained engaged in the overall effort to control the fire.
In Show Low, the sky was relatively clear today for the first time in a week, and the streets resumed something of a normal rhythm. Cars, vans, trailers and pickup trucks that had been hurriedly packed more than a week earlier rumbled into a town devoid of police roadblocks and the ominous threat of what officials had called a "wall of fire."
Still, the flames took some homes and came perilously close to others. "The cobwebs on the side of the house were scorched," said Lynne Louchart, who lives with her husband, Dennis, in Pinedale, on the road toward Heber-Overgaard. "You could tell somebody did hand-to-hand combat at our house."
Pine trees a few feet from the house were incinerated, and a shed that held two bicycles, a chainsaw and other tools was gone. A swing set in the garden was partly melted, and there were signs of flames a mere foot from a propane tank. Five of the 11 houses in the immediate neighborhood were destroyed, including that of the Loucharts' neighbor.
"We knew we were in the middle of it, but we didn't know how heavily we were impacted," Mrs. Louchart said. "We're ecstatic."
But the residents' return to the area brought fresh dangers from people with a bent toward arson. On Saturday afternoon, a fire spotter at a lookout post on Juniper Ridge near Linden, northwest of here, saw a plume of smoke rising near an area that had already burned and been extinguished days earlier. Firefighters dispatched to the spot discovered a patch of flames that they determined had been intentionally set.
"We found footprints, tire tracks that spun around, and an ignition source," said Jim Paxon, a Forest Service spokesman. "I just cannot believe that someone would do that after what we've been through." 
As he entered St. Rita's Catholic Church here this morning for the first time in a week, Ron Greene, a former engineer with the Phoenix Fire Department who retired to Show Low 22 years ago, said he had learned in training long ago that most arson fires were committed by active or retired firefighters.
"Maybe they have animosity or anger," Mr. Greene said. "They know from experience how to start a concealed fire. But anytime anyone does something this stupid or reckless, it saddens me deeply. Fire is so uncontrollable that you never know who you're going to kill or maim."

HEADLINE: Concession-Seekers in Legislature Hold Arena for Newark in Check 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 30 

 BODY:
With the major state budget bills having passed the Senate and headed for likely approval in the Assembly this morning, New Jersey lawmakers used the unresolved issue of whether to build a sports arena in Newark as the forum to win concessions for their districts, and in the process held up final approval of the budget.
 In a rare Sunday session filled with drama and political maneuvering, the bill that would allow financing and construction of a $355 million arena to house the New Jersey Nets and the New Jersey Devils, replacing the teams' current home at the Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands, appeared to be languishing in a Senate committee. It was weighed down by costly amendments. When the Senate convened late Sunday night to vote on various budget measures, Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, who also sits in the Senate, withheld his vote on two critical budget bills to protest the failure of the arena bill to advance to the floor. 
 Mr. James was then summoned to the office of Gov. James E. McGreevey. The governor agreed to pressure the Republican and Democratic Senate leaders to hold a late-night meeting of the committee that had bottled up the arena bill, according to lawmakers who were briefed later on what was said at the meeting. Minutes later, Mr. James cast his vote for one of the budget measures and, joined by the rest of the Essex County delegation, withheld his vote on the other one until the governor made good on his promise.
Earlier in the day, the printing operation at the State House was working furiously to churn out copies of the many amendments that were surfacing to the arena bill.
The arena measure, which Mr. McGreevey supports, would also create sports and entertainment districts for Harrison to build a soccer arena, and Pennsauken to build a minor league hockey rink. The districts would be allowed to keep some of the sales taxes collected at the venues to pay off construction costs.
Several amendments were proposed on Sunday that would create similar mechanisms for Mercer, Monmouth and Bergen Counties. Other amendments would give Harrison and Pennsauken access to income-tax revenues at their sites as well. These in turn prompted amendments from some Republicans to limit the revenues such mechanisms could generate.
Meetings of the key committees needed to advance the measure were postponed again and again.
"There are no rules on days like this, and anything could happen," said Jeff Tittle, a lobbyist for the Sierra Club, which supports the Newark arena as a sound environmental use of urban space. "By the end, we may have sports authority mechanisms for all 21 counties in the state."
In an echo of the past, Jack Collins, former Assembly speaker and now a paid consultant to several private interests in the state, was seen around the committee room where the Senate Economic Growth, Agriculture and Tourism Committee was scheduled to consider the many last-minute amendments to the bill.
Many legislators blamed Mr. Collins, who was speaker until this year, for loading up last year's failed version of the bill with unrelated spending measures intended to win votes. Eventually, even Governor-elect McGreevey withdrew his longtime support for the measure, saying that too much spending had been larded on to it, and the bill's tenuous legislative support dissolved. "They should have passed it when I was speaker and they wouldn't be here today," Mr. Collins said Sunday with a grin.
Some supporters of the Newark arena, like Senator Joseph Charles, a Democrat from Hudson County, and the Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, president of the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey, echoed that view, saying that Mr. McGreevey had miscalculated by opting to take on the measure now in a time of declining state revenues rather than allowing his predecessor and a Republican-controlled Legislature to approve it.
"I don't know why he didn't let Governor DiFrancesco do this," said Mr. Jackson, referring to Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican who had embraced passage of the arena measure as part of his political legacy at the close of a 25-year career in Trenton. Mr. DiFrancesco, who was acting governor for much of last year, had mustered support from several Republicans until the bill's many unrelated projects made it politically perilous.
That the stakes were high for the arena on the closing day of the Legislature was also evident from the presence of Raymond Chambers, the usually reclusive philanthropist and partner in the YankeeNets, which owns the Nets and the Devils.
A spokesman for the YankeeNets, James McQueeny, said Mr. Chambers was prepared to tell lawmakers that without their support for the Newark arena measure, the building could not open in 2005 and the ownership group would face financial losses. That would mean that members of the YankeeNets who do not share Mr. Chambers's desire to move the teams to Newark, the state's largest city, and presumably help in its renaissance, would gain leverage in their efforts to move the teams out of New Jersey.
Some Republican lawmakers said privately that many of their constituents had yet to feel any real fear of losing the teams. Still others said they had polled voters and found they did not care enough about keeping the teams to press lawmakers to support the measure, which proponents say would ensure the teams' presence in the state for at least 20 years.

HEADLINE: In Trenton, Budget Battle Keeps Legislators Working Into Morning 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 30 

 BODY:
The New Jersey Legislature worked into the morning today in an effort to adopt the largest budget in the state's history and close its largest projected deficit ever. 
 Early today, the extraordinary session that began Sunday afternoon dissolved in bitter fighting among the Democrats over the proposed sports arena in Newark. The State Senate's vote on the corporate business tax, the centerpiece of Gov. James E. McGreevey's budget proposal, was suspended to give Senate leaders and the governor time to placate Democrats who had defected in an effort to force a hearing on the arena bill. 
 The fighting behind closed doors led to threats and even shoving, according to one Republican senator. And after submitting enough votes to assure that the corporate business tax bill would pass, most Republicans went home. 
The $23.4 billion budget, which follows Governor McGreevey's blueprint, would restructure the corporate income tax, borrow against revenue expected from the state's share of the national tobacco settlement, nearly double the cigarette tax to $1.50 a pack and raise an array of fees. 
By midnight Sunday, Republican legislators had supplied the deciding votes for most of the budget measures in the evenly divided State Senate, but not until they had harshly criticized the Democrats for increasing spending and relying on bond sales to finance operating expenses. And they made their final protests against the business-tax overhaul.
The Senate's Republican co-president, John O. Bennett, addressed the Democrats, naming all 20 senators, and said, "Each one of you will be charged with the responsibility to explain this Democrat budget that increases state spending while raising countless taxes on all New Jerseyans."
The state's fiscal problems have consumed Mr. McGreevey's first five and a half months in office. As if extending his campaign, the new governor blamed his Republican predecessors for the state's fiscal straits, then sought to raise new revenue while insisting that he was keeping his promise not to raise taxes. 
Mr. McGreevey turned almost immediately to business as a source of new money, claiming that big corporations had escaped their "fair share" of the tax burden. The administration maintained that three-quarters of the corporations in the state, and 30 of the 50 largest employers, were paying only the $200 minimum required under the old law.
The new plan would impose an "alternative minimum" tax, on a graduated basis, that is calculated according to gross receipts or gross profits. The plan would also end an exemption for dividends that New Jersey corporations receive from out-of-state subsidiaries, and would tax out-of-state sales that are not already taxed by the other states.
The budget was also a test of whether the Republicans, who share control of the State Senate with Democrats, could check the new governor's moves. With business groups, they orchestrated an advertising campaign against the business-tax plan. 
In the end, they could wrest only a few concessions. Last-minute bargaining for Republican votes shifted some of the burden from small businesses, and provided for a commission to review the tax and report in two years on whether it should continue. But the revised tax is still projected to raise $1.8 billion, more than twice the amount collected this year.
There are few new spending programs in the budget. It provides for increased property-tax rebates, staff increases at centers for the disabled that are needed to keep their accreditation and $40 million for counterterrorism efforts. It freezes aid to school districts and municipalities at this year's levels.
The budget calls for spending about $500 million more than the budget adopted one year ago. But the increase in actual spending is expected to be considerably higher, since the state made unusually large spending cuts this year after the softening economy and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 began to depress tax collections.
Late Sunday, the Democrats were still dwelling on one of Mr. McGreevey's main themes: that the Republican-controlled budget for the fiscal year that ended Sunday night contained wildly optimistic projections. Some Democrats called them fraudulent.
"I am glad to say that in this year's budget, that number is real, and not an accounting gimmick designed to pull the wool over the people's eyes until the next election," said Senator Wayne R. Bryant, the Democratic chairman of the Senate budget committee. 
Republicans complained bitterly from the outset that they were shut out of budget decisions as Mr. McGreevey and Democratic lawmakers put off sharing details of their proposals. They did not release the appropriations bill until Thursday, which was to have been the last voting day of the session.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Estimates Increase On '02 Ad Spending

BYLINE:  By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
Two forecasters have adjusted their estimates slightly upward for American advertising spending this year. 
 The Zenith Optimedia Group in London, which in April predicted a decline of 1.8 percent in ad spending from 2001, is now forecasting a decline of 1.2 percent. 
Though the economy "shows intermittent strength," executives of Zenith Optimedia wrote in a report, there is "no sign of real recovery for the United States media industry." 
 Zenith Optimedia also revised upward its forecast for ad spending this year in the world's seven largest advertising markets, including the United States. The new forecast is for a decline of 0.5 percent from 2001, compared with a prediction in April for a decline of 1.8 percent. Zenith Optimedia is owned by the Cordiant Communications Group and the Publicis Groupe.
In addition, Jack Myers of Jack Myers Report, a media newsletter published by Myers L.L.C., revised his prediction for American ad spending this year to forecast no change from last year; in April, he had predicted a decline of 0.4 percent. Mr. Myers attributed the revision to increased sales of commercial time by broadcast and cable television networks and syndicators, offsetting weakness in sales of ad space by newspapers and magazines.
The revisions came days after another forecaster, David Peeler, president and chief executive at the CMR division of Taylor Nelson Sofres, increased his prediction for 2002 ad spending to a gain of 2.5 percent, compared with a gain of 1.5 percent that he had forecast in January.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY; 
N.H.L. Starts Shopping For Free Agents Today

BYLINE:  By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
Most workers do not begin a holiday by starting their shift at midnight, but Mike Gillis has a specialized job, and today is a special day.
 Gillis, a former N.H.L. player, is a player agent and he lives in Kingston, Ontario. While most Canadians celebrated Canada Day, Gillis planned to begin the most important part of his calendar by being in his office for the first minute of the bidding season for unrestricted free agents. 
 "It will be exciting," he said. 
Among his clients are goaltender Mike Richter, center Bobby Holik and right wing Tony Amonte. All are Group 3 free agents, meaning they are at least 31 years old and have played out their contracts. They can negotiate with any N.H.L. team.
"You have a finite number of good players and you have teams interested in signing them and that's the first possible time that they can talk," Gillis said of July 1. "And so they call just after midnight. I'm always in my office."
Goalies and right wings are the most prominent and abundant unrestricted free agents on this summer's market. Also available are goaltenders Curtis Joseph, Ed Belfour and Byron Dafoe. Other right wings available are Bill Guerin and Teemu Selanne.
The number of teams looking for goalies expanded last week when Dominik Hasek retired from the Detroit Red Wings, who won the Stanley Cup last month.
"Hasek's retirement obviously adds another team to the mix for a top goaltender," Gillis said. "Clearly, in the free-agent market, when you have more competition, the tendency is for the dollars to go higher."
Hasek made $8 million last season, plus a $1 million bonus for winning the Cup. Among available goalies, the highest paid was Joseph, at $6.575 million by Toronto. Among the right wings, Selanne made $9.5 million at San Jose. Holik was paid $3.5 million by the Devils. The top-salaried defenseman on the market is Chris Chelios, who was paid $5.5 million by Detroit.
Among the restricted free agents who are theoretically available are Calgary right wing Jarome Iginla, the league's scoring champion, and Montreal goalie Jose Theodore, who won the Hart trophy as most valuable player and the Vezina as best goalie in the regular season.
They have Group 2 status because they are younger than 31. Their teams have the right to match any offer. Should they choose not to match, their teams would get up to five first-round draft choices as compensation. No free agent of this status or stature has been offered a lucrative contract since 1998, when Detroit matched Carolina's bid of $38 million for six years to Sergei Fedorov.
The current formula for free agency emerged from the settlement of the 15-week lockout that delayed the start of the 1994-95 season. Although that negotiation produced a cap on base wages for rookies while reducing leverage and mobility for players younger than 31, it created more bargaining power for veterans.
In the season before the lockout, the average salary was $572,161. Last season, the average salary was $1,642,590, up 14.48 per cent from 2000-1.
N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said recently that teams need "cost certainty" after the collective bargaining agreement expires in September 2004. "High-spending teams create an inflationary environment which puts severe economic pressure on some of the lesser-endowed teams," Bettman said. "So we're going to have to address that."
One of those teams is Detroit, with a payroll of about $65 million last season. To replace Hasek, the Red Wings could court Belfour, Joseph or Richter. Gillis said Richter has recovered from a skull fracture and had no animosity toward the Rangers for not signing him before his free agency. Gillis spoke last week with Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, but Gillis said no negotiation took place.
They did agree, however, that no deals had been made unofficially between free agents and teams seeking them. This contradicts allegations made by William Wirtz, the owner of the Chicago Blackhawks, who said Amonte had an agreement with the Dallas Stars.
"I think the deal has been done already, but it's tampering if anything is done before July 1, so nobody is saying anything," Wirtz told The Chicago Tribune on June 21. "We hear eight or nine players already have agreed to sign and he's one of them."
In response to this, Gillis said: "There is nothing to it." Sather, on the same issue, said: "I don't think that anyone's even talked to anyone about it. If they had, I'd be shocked. You'd be nailed to the wall for that one."
Not all unrestricted free agents are older than 31 or top talents. An unusual case is that of defenseman Darius Kasparaitis, who finished the season with the Colorado Avalanche and earned $1.15 million. Because, at age 29, he is a 10-year veteran who earned less than the league average of $1.643 million, Kasparaitis can negotiate with any team and is likely to get a substantial raise.
Also unrestricted are the veteran defensemen Luke Richardson and Gary Suter; the experienced centers Adam Oates and Doug Gilmour; and specialists in rough play like Tie Domi and Donald Brashear. Center Mark Messier is technically a free agent, as is center Mario Lemieux. But Messier, 41, is expected to re-sign with the Rangers, and Lemieux, 36, is an owner of the Penguins.
