HEADLINE: Dreams of Land Collide as Israeli Settlers Grow in Numbers 

BYLINE:  By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: GIVAT ESHKODESH, West Bank 

 BODY:
There is no discernible charm to this barren hilltop, but the young, Israeli settlers who have occupied it say they will do whatever they must to defend it.
 "If you have faith, there is no force that can move you," one 24-year-old settler, Shalom Israeli, said, smiling as he clutched the grip of his M-16 assault rifle on a recent day. "This is just one hill, but it points straight up to God." 
 Palestinians in the village of Singil can see the outpost from their terraces. To them, it makes no difference that such settlements are not officially sanctioned by the Israeli government. Their land is disappearing, the villagers say, and only the settlers have the army on their side. 
"The Jews here believe they have been chosen by God and that we are animals," said Khaled Hussein, 35, a stonecutter in Singil. "They are coming closer all the time. Now, I think, there are only two possibilities: either Israel will destroy us, or we will destroy Israel."
Settlements like Givat Eshkodesh are at the epicenter of the consuming rage in the Middle East, as two dreams of land collide with renewed intensity in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
 On July 1, the Israeli Defense Ministry announced the dismantling of 11 small settler outposts, all but 2 of which were uninhabited. Defense officials said 9 more of the illegal outposts, which they would not name, would be removed in the coming weeks. 
But despite repeated Israeli pledges to halt their expansion, the occasional evacuation of outposts and sporadic appeals from the United States, the settlements have grown steadily. Although the number of recognized settlements has remained fairly stable in recent years, their population in the West Bank has about doubled over the last decade, rising from 100,500 in 1992 to an estimated 198,000 last year, according to official figures.
Behind the growth, officials and analysts said, lies an elaborate system of government incentives and a powerful network of political support. The government provides the settlers with cheap land, discounted loans, tax breaks and other aid. The settlers, in turn, have become a potent constituency of the right-wing political parties that support them -- a force powerful enough to command the actions of important ministers or to destabilize government coalitions.
Israeli policy has largely been shaped by the most militant settlers, Jews who occupy land they believed was deeded to them in the Bible. But as the incentive system has evolved, officials said, it has steadily lured more and more secular families looking for affordable suburban homes.
Asaf Mani, a 27-year-old computer programmer, said it was an easy choice for him and his young wife, Almog, to leave behind a cramped Tel Aviv apartment and join some of her family in the isolated West Bank settlement of Homesh.
Their new hilltop home, with views that stretch for miles, cost only about $60,000 before renovations. The government gave them a cut-rate mortgage, and they will receive a 7 percent break on their income tax. Schools, public transportation and community activities are all heavily subsidized. 
"I am a dreamer," Mr. Mani said, looking past the army bunker in his front yard to the distant haze of the Mediterranean. "I can already see the chicken and the sheep over there, the little steps down to the road. A little time. A little money. It will come."

An Obstacle to Peace Talks
How much Israel spends to sustain and defend the settlements remains a closely held secret. Estimates run upward of $1 billion a year, including security costs, even as the country struggles with its most severe economic crisis in decades.
A former finance minister, Avraham Shochat, calculated the cost of the government's incentive system at perhaps $400 million. Based on supplemental defense appropriations since the Palestinian uprising, or intifada, began in September 2000, he estimated that the security forces are also spending more than $1 billion in additional funds each year, part of it to protect the settlements.
As the United States seeks to revive the peace negotiations and help formulate boundaries for an eventual Palestinian state, American officials say that Israel's settlement machine stands as one of their most formidable obstacles. The sharp rise of the settler population over the last decade has come despite Israel's vow, under the Oslo peace negotiations, not to "change the status" of the occupied territories pending final negotiations.
 In his speech on the Middle East on June 24, President Bush echoed the familiar American appeal, saying, "Israeli settlement activity in the occupied territories must stop." 
Israeli governments have pledged repeatedly to stop building new settlements, insisting that any expansion of those in place (now about 125 in the West Bank and 10 more in the Gaza Strip) would be limited to the "natural growth" of the population. But while the West Bank settlement population grew at an annual rate of about 8 percent over the last decade, the birth rate alone would have caused an annual increase of only 3.1 percent, analysts said.
Until recently, the government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon has also shown tolerance for the outposts -- the clusters of trailer homes that sprout among Palestinian villages in the West Bank regions that the settlers call Judea and Samaria. According to the advocacy groups that monitor them, about 40 new outposts have appeared since Mr. Sharon took office in February 2001.
In Givat Eshkodesh, which was forcibly evacuated during peace efforts three years ago and remains unauthorized, signs of official support are now everywhere: new electrical lines, a new government-built road, and a flush confidence among the settlers that the country is again behind them.
But while the outposts are major sources of friction between settlers and Palestinians, much more of the new building has taken place within the expansive municipal boundaries of existing settlements. Local officials refer to those new communities as "neighborhoods."
On the hills in and around East Jerusalem, where more than 175,000 settlers now live, the communities rise in gleaming stone blocks of duplexes, town houses and single-family homes. A short commute from Tel Aviv, they come in neat rows of tile-roofed tract homes that look like the gated suburbs of the American Southwest. "People don't come here for ideology," said Zvika Ma-Yafit, the can-do mayor of Oranit, a community of about 5,200 people near Tel Aviv. "They come here for the quality of life."
Drive through Oranit's well-guarded gates and there is a swatch of tennis courts, a busy community swimming pool and a matched set of good schools. Behind the soldiers and sturdy fencing, the settlers often say they feel safer than they do in the cities, what with suicide bombs that have killed hundreds of Israelis.

Surging Political Strength
That such settlements thrived during the 1990's under the left-leaning Labor Party was in part the victory of right-wing ministers in the governing coalition. Under Mr. Sharon, who was once the most ardent of those minister-advocates, the settlers' political strength has surged and their tactics have grown more sophisticated.
"P.R. used to be a bad word in Judea and Samaria," said Yuli Edelstein, the deputy minister in charge of absorbing Jewish immigrants and an important advocate for the settlers within the government. "But we live in the modern world. You had to show that you had a right to be there, that you were not some crazy fanatic."
Yet after waves of attacks by Palestinian militants, the character of some less "ideological" settlements has begun to shift in the opposite direction. In Homesh, where Mr. Mani, the computer programmer from Tel Aviv, now lives, the community's 20-year-old charter stipulates that it should remain secular and democratic. But after a relative and a friend of Mr. Mani's wife were killed last year in Palestinian ambushes, some families began to move out. Yossi Dahan, the settlement administrator, said that while the government has provided more security, he had little choice but to turn to religious settlers' groups to replace those who had left.
"I am sure that if the government came here today and said it would give people homes in a safe place, 75 percent of these people would go," Mr. Dahan said. "Maybe all of them."
Mr. Sharon, however, has insisted he will defend the settlers to the last, saying of one of the smallest and most isolated settlements, "The fate of Netzarim is the fate of Tel Aviv." 
Despite new fiscal austerity, his government has maintained the flow of incentives and subsidies, cutting bus fares, bulletproofing settlers' cars and financing activities for children who can no longer travel safely outside their communities. 
The government is also taking at least an indirect role in promoting the settlements to new immigrants. Although Israeli policy is to allow new immigrants to live wherever they choose, several officials acknowledged privately that government-financed agencies are helping the settlements to market themselves to prospective immigrants.
The government's aid to the settlements is difficult to trace because much of it moves through complex bureaucratic conduits or is hidden in vaguely described budget items. Housing support, for example, might be spread across both settlement communities and other "national priority areas" like the Negev Desert.
There is little question, though, that such support has been the will of the prime minister and his Likud Party, of which settlers are an important constituency. As agriculture minister in the late 1970's, Mr. Sharon called for the settlement of two million Jews in the territories by the year 2000. As foreign minister in 1998, he called on settlers to "grab hilltops" before they were ceded to the Palestinians in negotiations.
As under previous coalitions, government support for the settlers is also the work of independent-minded ministers with important portfolios and of settlement officials who administer central-government funds.
Natan Sharansky, the housing minister, said he spends only a modest part of his budget on the settlements. But settlement officials said his support also includes helping them with strategy, lobbying Parliament and cajoling other ministers. Chief among those is the defense minister, Benjamin Ben-Eliezer, who has authority over new settlement construction but also faces critics of the settlements within his Labor Party.
"There is no doubt that we are paying an increasing price, and an increasing financial price as well," Mr. Sharansky said in an interview. "But the major price is paid by the settlers themselves. And as long as there is no decision to the contrary, we have to defend the settlements."

Power and Population
Political operatives like Pinchas Wallerstein are a critical line of that defense. An old-guard veteran of the militant settler movement Gush Enumim, Mr. Wallerstein once orchestrated roadblocks and rock-throwing against Palestinians, and protests against Israeli prime ministers. Now, he fashions himself a pragmatist.
As the rough equivalent of a county executive for the settlements that surround the Palestinian administrative capital, Ramallah, Mr. Wallerstein's power is partly financial: He administers government grants that are twice what comparable municipalities within Israel receive, according to a recent study, along with local revenues and increasing donations from abroad. He has easy access to government ministers, and consults with them closely.
But he also pursues his own agenda, with an ostensible independence that often suits officials in Jerusalem. He makes no secret, for example, of his dream to use outposts like Givat Eshkodesh to link isolated settlements in the Jordan Valley all the way across the West Bank to Ariel, the settlement city that is a gateway to Tel Aviv.
"In a few years, all of this area will be covered by Jewish population," he said as he stood on a hilltop near the settlement of Shiloh. "I can show you how you can connect this area to Tel Aviv without any major Arab population inside."
Mr. Wallerstein helped establish one new outpost, called Migron, by using a permit for a cellphone antenna to put down a road, fencing and power lines. While the work went on, settlers quietly moved into trailer homes that had supposedly been brought in for the workmen.
Palestinians look out on the same landscape, but see it more darkly.
In Singil, a contractor traced a map of what had been lost: Palestinian farms swallowed by a settlement over there, Palestinian lands taken for an outpost, Palestinian olive groves that had been placed off-limits by the military to safeguard the transit of the settlers.
"Every day that the occupation continues, we lose more of our land," the contractor, Fathi Shabaneh, said. "Every day that the occupation goes on, more of the hope that we have for a just peace evaporates."

HEADLINE: Law Firm Plans Move to Times Square Skyscraper 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A week after Arthur Andersen abandoned plans to move into new headquarters in Times Square, a major downtown law firm is negotiating to move into the same space in the skyscraper, which is under construction on 42nd Street.
 If the deal is completed, the law firm, Pillsbury Winthrop, would move to the Times Square Tower, a 47-story building between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, from Lower Manhattan, where it has made its home for nearly 150 years, according to real estate executives and a partner at the firm. 
The deal would help in efforts to get other companies to lease space in the building, which is being developed by Boston Properties. But it would also undermine efforts to rebuild the economy downtown after the attack on the World Trade Center last Sept. 11. 
Andersen signed a contract two years ago to be the anchor tenant and to lease about half the 1.2-million-square-foot tower. But the Enron scandal doomed the company's fortunes. Last week, Boston Properties and Andersen tore up the lease.
The deal with Pillsbury Winthrop would signal the continuing viability of the Times Square project, the executives said, at the expense of Lower Manhattan.
To offset the departure of investment banks and other financial companies from downtown, state and city officials have offered cash grants and tax breaks to retain jobs or lure new ones there. KPMG, the accounting firm, and several law firms have considered taking advantage of the incentives and lower rents. But few deals have been signed.
"I hope they don't leave downtown," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York. "Many Midtown law firms are considering moving down here, because the economics are so compelling and the opportunity to be in on the revitalization of one of the great districts of the world is so exciting."
John F. Pritchard, vice chair of Pillsbury Winthrop, said yesterday that the firm had "made no decision yet on what it is we're going to do."
He added, "All our options remain open."
But real estate executives and a partner at the firm said that Pillsbury Winthrop was negotiating the terms of a deal for about 200,000 square feet with Boston Properties and that a "substantial faction" at the firm favored the move uptown. The firm, which is currently at 1 Battery Park Plaza on State Street, hired brokers at Julien J. Studley to look for a new home when its lease expires in 2004.
Pillsbury Winthrop's roots date from the 1800's in Lower Manhattan.
After a slowdown in business last fall, Pillsbury Winthrop and other firms cut their staffs by 10 percent. But it would cost millions of dollars a year more in rent every year at a new Midtown tower. The firm has told city and state officials that its competitors and its clients are uptown, while many of its partners find it easier to get to Times Square.

HEADLINE: Now, at Least in Math, Those Who Can, Teach 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
By some standards, it seems a rather odd state of affairs. Schools cannot find enough mathematics teachers. Yet people proficient in math -- engineers, accountants, stockbrokers and others who want to teach math -- are often turned away because they did not major in the subject in college.
 Consider Malia Jackson, who majored in astronomy at Cornell University, took advanced differential equations and linear algebra and earned a perfect score on the mathematics portion of the Graduate Record Examinations. When she decided to teach high school math rather than college astrophysics, she discovered she did not qualify to become a certified math teacher. 
 Or Lisa Culbertson, another Cornell graduate, who completed two years of calculus in high school, took advanced statistics in college and taught a math SAT prep course for Stanley Kaplan. The New York City Board of Education told her that she also would not qualify.
Both of these aspiring teachers are now part of a new program intended to help certify people who would not qualify as math teachers.The program, which started last month with 120 participants, plunges recruits into classes in square roots, quadratic equations and other high school topics, as well as 200 hours of pedagogical training and student teaching. If they pass the necessary state licensing exams by the end of the summer, including a math test that covers the high school math curriculum, they will begin teaching in city classrooms in September. 
Much is riding on the pilot program because both the State Education Department and the federal government are requiring that only qualified teachers be allowed in classrooms. Finding qualified math teachers is also a severe problem across the country because many states, wanting teachers to have depth in the field, require that math teachers major or minor in math, or take the equivalent number of courses.
But the number of college math majors has dropped steadily. Only about 1 percent of all college graduates are math majors, and they have better-paying career opportunities.
New York City's two-year-old Teaching Fellows program, which has attracted thousands of desperately needed new teachers in other subjects, failed to solve the math teaching problem. Of 1,100 fellows last year, only about 15 majored in math.
Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy created the new immersion program for people who showed proficiency in mathematics.
"We needed to jump-start the process," he said. "Investment bankers, bond traders and C.P.A.'s who choose to become teachers need training to know how to teach teenagers. But they shouldn't have to become math majors to do that."
In May, the State Board of Regents approved the pilot program, which Last month started at City, Lehman and Brooklyn Colleges and at St. John's University.
Johnny W. Lott, president of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, argues that anything short of a major is not enough.
"Teachers have to know more than their students know to be good teachers," he said. 
However others like Chester E. Finn Jr., president of the Thomas B. Fordham Foundation and a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute say that requiring a certain college major is not necessarily the best guide for screening potential teachers.
"The problem with a major is that you could find a math major who spent all his time in an obscure area of topology and did not know much at all about algebra, geometry or trigonometry."
Johanna Duncan-Poitier, deputy commissioner for higher and professional education at the State Education Department, said the state would study the pilot program, to see how teachers do.
"We are not lowering standards," she said. "These individuals will still have to pass the mathematics content specialty test, and they will continue their studies in mathematics.
"We're not saying the math major isn't necessary yet. But if this works, it may be a way for us to bring in more science teachers and teachers in other shortage areas as well. Or we may find this is not as promising as we expected."
Some of the new recruits come from Ivy League colleges. Others left lucrative jobs in finance and consulting. Most were good at math when they took it, though some, like Levi Litman, a Trinity College economics graduate who worked in investment banking and consulting, took little or no math in college. The Board of Education selected them because their college records and current jobs suggested they had an aptitude in math.
"They would not have qualified under state rules," said Alfred S. Posamentier, dean of education at City College, "but the board has not had such qualified applicants in years."
The students in one of the math immersion classes at City College last month seemed to have little problem following their teacher as he moved rapidly through secants, tangents and geometric proofs.
It was 4:00 p.m. on a Friday. Class had been in session for seven hours. But neither the teacher-trainees nor their instructor, Michael R. Richardson, a former high school math teacher, showed any sign of fading as he drew circles and secants on the board with colored markers and quizzed them on exponential numbers.
"What's five cubed?" he asked. "What about five squared? Five to the first power? Five to the zero? Five to the negative one? Five to the negative two?"
The material was not difficult, but many trainees said they were grateful for the refresher.
"My high school math is not that rusty, but some of the stuff is in the recesses of my brain," said Ms. Jackson, the Cornell astronomy major.
State Education Department officials said they did not have specific guidelines for certifying whether the trainees had enough math, but would rely on the judgment of the colleges and on the trainees' scores on the state math test.
The City College instructors cobbled together a practice test last month. Of the 16 students in Mr. Richardson's class, most did very well. Only two failed. Ten scored 95 or above. Six -- including Ms. Jackson, Ms. Culbertson and Mr. Litman -- earned perfect scores.

HEADLINE: G.M. Bucks Detroit Trend And Reports Higher Sales 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 2 

 BODY:
A day after introducing an aggressive incentive plan, General Motors reported stronger June auto sales today even as sales by its Detroit-based rivals and the rest of the industry sagged.
 G.M. said its vehicle sales rose 4.3 percent in June compared with figures in the month a year earlier. Its market share climbed both for June and for the first half of 2001, thanks in part to its willingness to continue stimulating the market with incentives. In contrast, sales at DaimlerChrysler dropped 3.6 percent in June, while Ford Motor's sales dropped 10.7 percent. 
 Though analysts say the latest round of incentives is costing the auto companies about $2,200 a vehicle, Paul Ballew, G.M.'s chief industry sales analyst, said the automaker saw no reason to hold back. "We have the ability and we have the desire to be on the offensive in the marketplace and show leadership," Mr. Ballew said.
"G.M. has a lot of energy and they are trying" to keep pressure on their rivals, said Ron Pinelli, an industry analyst with Autodata Inc. of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. "You have to get in there and play the game. Either that, or you lock the doors."
But G.M.'s better performance is not translating to higher showroom prices, even as it has been publicizing the healthy sales of its overhauled lineup of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, which were intended to help the company gain both market share and improve its profits.
Prices paid for G.M. vehicles dropped 2 percent in the second quarter on top of a 1.5 percent decline in the first quarter, Mr. Ballew said. He contended the declines reflected the inability of a variety of companies to persuade consumers to pay more. "We are not unique," he said. "Many industries have negative pricing, and the question is how you grapple with that."
But industry analysts noted that the lower prices reflected G.M.'s inability, or unwillingness, to wean the market from incentives. By contrast, several foreign companies have discounted their vehicles far less than has G.M., which on Monday reintroduced the interest-free loan programs that helped it increase sales after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
John McCandless, a spokesman for Toyota, said his company had no plans to match the G.M. program, even though its sales dropped 0.6 percent in June, saying its main problem was a shortage of vehicles as the end of the model year approaches.
Ford, however, announced its own incentive program almost immediately, though it is less generous than the G.M. plan. And DaimlerChrysler said today that it, too, would offer a zero-percent financing plan. It had hesitated in the wake of G.M.'s original offer last year to match the program but its sales plunged as a result.
A DaimlerChrysler executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he hoped G.M.'s offer would spur showroom traffic this summer and help his company clear its inventories of 2002 vehicles ahead of the 2003 model year, which officially begins in October. "We'd like to take advantage of their backdraft," he said.
June's performance translated to an annual selling rate of 16.4 million vehicles, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank. That was better than the 15.7 million rate recorded in May but below the 17.4 million rate in April. In all of 2001, automakers sold 17.2 million vehicles in the United States, their second-best performance in history despite the effect on the economy from the Sept. 11 attacks.
For the most part, foreign companies turned in a mixed performance last month. Among Japanese companies, Honda said its sales rose 1.8 percent last month, when it began selling the new Pilot sport utility vehicle, but Nissan, like Toyota, had flat sales. Sales at Mercedes-Benz of Germany dropped 3.1 percent, but sales at its rival BMW, which last spring introduced the latest version of its 7-series sedan, were up 15.2 percent. Hyundai of Korea reported a 19.6 percent increase in June sales, while Kia, another Korean automaker, said its sales climbed 10.3 percent.
Mr. Ballew said he did not expect the latest incentives to have the same effect as last fall's programs. Indeed, some buyers may find that the vehicles they want to buy are not covered by the plans, which apply generally only to 2002 models, not to 2003 vehicles that have been introduced before the start of the model year.
Also, Mr. Pinelli, the Autodata analyst, said the soft economy was making many consumers cautious, a reason that he thinks that sales by Korean companies are surging. "They are not looking to spend money foolishly," he said of consumers.
Unless, of course, a vehicle strikes their fancy. Attracted by a special lease offer, Mr. Pinelli went to his Porsche dealer two weeks ago to check out a Boxster, which runs for about $56,000 fully equipped. Instead, he took home a $90,000 Porsche 911, to the delight of his teenage son. Asked why he spent nearly twice as much as he initially planned, Mr. Pinelli replied, "It was talking to me."

HEADLINE: World Bank Deal to Help Poorest Nations 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2 

 BODY:
The World Bank welcomed a deal today to provide an additional $13 billion for projects in 79 of the world's poorest countries, reached after months of bickering by donors on how the money should be used.
 Talks had been delayed by heated debate over a proposal by the United States to increase the amount of money given as grants from less than 1 percent to around 50 percent. 
 The plan met with stiff opposition in Europe, and delayed an agreement on the increased financing by more than half a year. The donors eventually agreed that 18 percent to 21 percent of the financing should be given out in grants.
Including this new money, funds available to the bank's lowest cost financing arm, the International Development Association, will total $23 billion over the next three years, up 18 percent over previous levels.
The agreement is "an important step forward in addressing the goals highlighted at the recent development conference in Monterrey," said the bank's managing director, Sven Sandstrom, who headed the lengthy negotiations. 
The previous three-year deal expired at the end of June.

HEADLINE: Construction Is to Start in Fall On Central Harlem Supermarket 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Construction will finally begin this fall on central Harlem's first full-size supermarket, a long-delayed project that is expected to be a catalyst for further development in the Bradhurst section, city officials said yesterday.
 The new 45,000-square-foot supermarket, a Pathmark, is part of Bradhurst Court, a $52 million project that is being financed in part with $6.4 million in grants and low-interest loans from the city. It will take up a full block from 144th Street to 145th Street and from Frederick Douglass Boulevard to Bradhurst Avenue, and will include 126 cooperative apartments for middle-income buyers, 6,000 square feet of other retail space and underground parking for 118 cars. 
 Christopher Cirillo, the director of large-scale development for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said that this site, one of the largest undeveloped tracts in Harlem, has been the key element in the city's long-term goal of building up Bradhurst as a middle-class community. "This is the thing that is going to tie this together," Mr. Cirillo said. "This is such a pivotal piece. Its impact will be felt throughout the area."
The project has already led to plans for two other nearby residential buildings, one with 77 units and the other with 200, he said. Several other buildings are being rehabilitated, and other requests for proposals will be issued this summer to develop city land to the north of Bradhurst Court, Mr. Cirillo said.
The development team for Bradhurst Court, which is headed by the Related Companies, the company building the AOL Time Warner headquarters on Columbus Circle, was chosen by the city in June 1999. A lot of time was lost because two candidates to operate the supermarket, Pathmark and then ShopRite, withdrew from consideration and subsequently sought bankruptcy protection.
"That was a real stumbling block," said Jerry Salama, one of the developers, "finding a viable supermarket that knew how to run a big store in the Bradhurst area. There were others that expressed interest, but they didn't know Harlem."
Pathmark, which had opened East Harlem's first full-size supermarket on Lexington Avenue and 125th Street in 1999, eventually recovered and renewed its bid for Bradhurst, a site the company had been considering for more than a decade. As the time for signing a lease approached, Pathmark faced opposition from Mauricio and Matthew Fernandez, who own several medium-size grocery stores in Harlem. 
The Fernandez brothers argued that the city was favoring a large chain at the expense of local entrepreneurs. They enlisted the help of Richard Lipsky, the lobbyist who had battled the East Harlem Pathmark on behalf of local grocery store owners, many of them Dominican.
They had the support of a number of Hispanic politicians and of Rudy Washington, a deputy mayor in the Giuliani administration who was able to block financing for the project from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a federal, state and city economic development program. Other city officials, however, questioned whether the Fernandez brothers were ready to make the leap to a 45,000-square-foot store.
Mr. Lipsky said yesterday that he hoped the city would find another location where the Fernandez brothers can open a supermarket.
The new Pathmark, which is expected to be completed in 2004, will create about 200 jobs, said Harvey Gutman, a senior vice president. Its lease requires the company to hire three-quarters of its workers from the local community. "That is something we do because it's good business," Mr. Gutman said. "People want to shop in stores where their friends and children work."

HEADLINE: Argentine Leader Moves Election Forward 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 

 BODY:
With his political support crumbling and his country's economic crisis showing no signs of abating, Eduardo Duhalde, the caretaker president of Argentina, moved up the election to choose his successor by six months today so he could leave office early. 
 "We need a government strengthened by the popular vote that is capable of putting into practice the great reforms" that Argentina needs to emerge from the worst economic crisis in its history, Mr. Duhalde said in a brief television address to his nation tonight. He said primary elections would be held within four months and a new president selected four months after that. 
 Mr. Duhalde took office on Jan. 1, designated by Congress to head an emergency "national unity government" in hopes of ending a period of street rioting and political chaos in which Argentina had four presidents in a little more than two weeks. At that time, he said he would serve until the end of 2003, when elections were scheduled. He said that he would not seek a full four-year term in the elections.
From the start, however, Mr. Duhalde has found it difficult to exercise the authority that normally goes with his office. He has had to share power with the 14 provincial governors from his own party. They have repeatedly challenged and sometimes even defied his efforts to get them to reduce spending and stop issuing currencies of their own, which they must do for Argentina to reach any agreement with the International Monetary Fund and other lenders.
Hoping that the government could regain access to an $18 billion credit line suspended in December, Economy Minister Roberto Lavagna traveled to the United States late last week and met with Argentina's creditors. But he was unable even to persuade some lenders to roll over debt payments due at mid-month, and returned to Buenos Aires today empty-handed.
Mr. Duhalde also has been shaken by violence that erupted last week, when two demonstrators participating in a march demanding jobs and food were shot and killed, apparently by the police. The protests were organized by groups closely allied with and in some cases financed by Mr. Duhalde's own Peronist Party. They made clear that Mr. Duhalde's support, which had fallen to 8 percent in recent polls, was shrinking even within his own party.
"The economic and social deterioration and the situation of public security and conflict control are making the government go back and forth," said Carlos Maestro, the Senate leader of the opposition Radical Party. "The situation is getting out of hand," he said, adding: "Duhalde realizes things are getting complicated."
Before, in moments of frustration, Mr. Duhalde had threatened to step down early, seeking to force unruly party leaders to confront the unwelcome possibility of having to manage the crisis by themselves. But he had also implied he would leave only if Argentina's economy was growing again, a prospect that now seems more distant than ever in spite of his claim tonight that his country "is very close to an accord" with the I.M.F. and other creditors.
Mr. Duhalde's decision to move the presidential election forward by six months means that Argentina will shift almost immediately into campaign mode. 
As many as half a dozen members of Mr. Duhalde's Peronist Party had been expected to make a run next year, with the former race car driver Carlos Reutemann and the former president Carlos Menem, Mr. Duhalde's bitter personal enemy, the favorites in early polls.
But a prominent constitutional lawyer, Ricardo Monner Sans, suggested tonight that by advancing the date of the vote, Mr. Duhalde has in effect blocked Mr. Menem, who left office in December 1999 after a decade in power, from running again. The Argentine Constitution, he noted, clearly states that a former president must be out of power four years before he can hold office again.
For his part, Mr. Maestro complained that Mr. Duhalde's decision, which he said was taken "in haste and without consultation," would complicate the electoral chances of his Radical Party, which had been in power until December.
"We are not even halfway well positioned," he said. "In reality, we are badly positioned."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Eduardo Duhalde wants to leave office early. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: U.S. MIGHT REFUSE NEW PEACE DUTIES WITHOUT IMMUNITY 

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER and JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2 

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld warned today that America might not send its forces to join future peacekeeping missions without a grant of full immunity from the jurisdiction of the new International Criminal Court.
 Mr. Rumsfeld aggressively defended the administration's demand that American troops and government officials be exempt from the court, two days after the United States vetoed a Security Council resolution extending the United Nations' peacekeeping mandate in Bosnia. The veto, which was based on American perceptions that the court violates American sovereignty, has generated sharp criticism from Britain and other American allies, which see it as further evidence that the administration is adopting a go-it-alone, unilateralist stance. 
 Mr. Rumsfeld and senior administration officials insisted that the United States would not withdraw wholesale from its current peacekeeping commitments overseas. But they did say that without promises from the international community or host nations that American troops would not be handed over to the court, the United States would carefully review the importance of its international missions, case by case.
"It would be inaccurate to say that the United States would necessarily withdraw from every engagement we have in the world," Mr. Rumsfeld told reporters at the Pentagon. "We have no plans to do that. In other words, we're engaged. We have forces in countries all over the globe. We have no intention of pulling back."
The administration worries that the new court could be driven by politically motivated prosecutors and that American military personnel would not have the constitutional rights granted all Americans in criminal proceedings -- for example, the right to be tried by a jury of peers and to have access to evidence.
A senior Defense Department official said the United States was seeking three types of protections for its military personnel and civilian government officials: a Security Council resolution granting blanket immunity to Americans taking part in United Nations peacekeeping missions; bilateral agreements with countries around the world guaranteeing that Americans on their territory would not be transferred to the court without American consent; and adjustments to current Status of Forces Agreements -- pacts negotiated with nations accepting American military personnel -- to reflect Washington's wishes on the court.
One proposal was being discussed late tonight at the United Nations, where diplomats are working against a deadline of midnight Wednesday to resolve the United Nations dispute over the Bosnia mandate. It would give 12 months of immunity in cases involving peacekeepers from any country that had not yet ratified the treaty establishing the war crimes court. The immunity could then be renewed by the Security Council.
The administration's concerns about the International Criminal Court extend beyond protecting American soldiers: it is also worried that the court could prosecute police officers or civilian officials involved in formulating peacekeeping policies and American combat operations.
"The I.C.C. is broad enough to not only prosecute those within the military chain of command, but also people in the political and policy chain of command," a senior administration official said.
"When you look back to Nuremberg, to Yugoslavia and Rwanda, there are people that need to be prosecuted for their decisions and policies," the official said. "But the broad end of the spectrum is that the process could be politicized."
The administration policy toward the court says much about how the lone superpower will project force abroad. It also presents America's partners and the world with a stark choice: If American military power is needed to quiet international trouble spots, the rules of that operation will be written by America. 
"The very fact that countries do want to cooperate with us and do want our protection and do want our participation in peacekeeping and other missions gives us the ability to go and talk with them and be listened to," a senior Defense Department official said.
The official said the administration was trying to defend the nation's sovereignty from subjugation to a treaty that carried neither a president's signature nor Senate consent.
Over the objections of the Pentagon and Congressional Republicans, President Bill Clinton signed the treaty that brought the court into being. But he expressed deep reservations and did not submit it to the Senate. His argument for endorsing the treaty was that Washington's ability to improve it from inside would be strengthened. The Bush administration revoked Mr. Clinton's signature on the treaty this year.
"The United States is not attempting to impose its will on other countries," a senior Pentagon official said. "In this debate, it is the parties to the International Criminal Court Treaty who are attempting to impose their treaty on non-parties."
The international lawyer who was chairman of the committee that wrote the court's statutes said today that it was "far-fetched" that a prosecutor was "going to run away with the process and target some poor American service member holding a peacekeeping function in some remote part of the world, just because that prosecutor dislikes the United States."
The lawyer, M. Cherif Bassiouni, a professor at DePaul University's law school in Chicago, said prosecutors for the court were selected by its 75 member-states.
He said the court's statutes also "contain all of the due process guarantees available in the U.S. legal system, and even go beyond that." He added, "The only thing it does not have is a trial by jury." 
At the State Department today, officials acknowledged that the administration had taken a hard line on the criminal court precisely because the United States' unmatched military, economic and diplomatic power made it unique in the world.
"We're going to end up having to deal with this issue for Americans all around the world, because we do have a special role," Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, told reporters. "The United States plays a role in the world unlike any other, and therefore this affects us unlike any other nation."
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has spoken on the subject to more than half a dozen European ministers over the last three days, including, today, the European Union foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, and the British foreign secretary, Jack Straw, Mr. Boucher said.

HEADLINE: Corporate Tax Deal Ends Trenton Budget Standoff 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 2 

 BODY:
An exhausted State Senate finally delivered a budget for New Jersey today, in a quick vote that approved a restructured corporate income tax that is expected to raise $1.8 billion, more than twice the amount collected this year.
 The 21-to-17 vote to provide enough revenue for a $23.4 billion budget was the result of a deal to resolve an ugly dispute between Gov. James E. McGreevey, a Democrat, and mutinous members of his own party who scuttled a budget agreement Sunday night. 
 The dispute, concerning a proposed $355 million sports arena for Newark, was put aside today as arena supporters led by Mayor Sharpe James of Newark agreed to support the budget in return for an agreement to hold committee hearings this summer on plans for the state's professional sports teams. 
The budget plan pulls together enough revenue to close the largest shortfall in the state's history, estimated most recently by Mr. McGreevey at $6 billion. Its centerpiece, and the proposal that nearly paralyzed the Legislature for weeks, was the corporate tax proposal. 
The Senate had already approved other new taxes, fees and borrowing in an extended legislative session Sunday when Mr. James and several other Democrats stopped the vote on the corporate tax bill, the last part of the budget package, to force a hearing on the arena. 
The budget was the first big test of the new governor's leadership. He had labored and bargained for nearly six months to stitch together a plan that avoided raising the personal income tax or sales tax, both politically perilous in this state, but steps that seemed practically inevitable as revenue began to plummet last year.
It was an enormous political hurdle in a state where the last Democratic governor, Jim Florio, doomed himself in 1990 with a $1.2 billion income tax increase, a decision that is still providing a campaign theme for Republicans.
Mr. McGreevey always referred to "closing loopholes" in the corporate business tax, although the law was substantially rewritten.
In a statement today, he said the legislation "will necessarily ensure that major corporations pay their fair and equitable share" after 20 years of declining business tax revenue, and he pointed out once more that the budget did not raise income or sales taxes. 
The budget itself, the appropriations for the 2003 fiscal year, was approved by both houses Sunday, the last day of the fiscal year, and the governor signed the bill early Monday morning, averting a government shutdown. 
Mr. McGreevey ordered the Senate to meet until it approved the $1 billion in new revenue from the corporate business tax to finance it. 
In the last few days, Democrats and Republicans alike questioned Mr. McGreevey's leadership as he lost control of the Democratic caucus, and Republicans continue to attack the budget. "It's unfortunate that the governor looked unfocused Sunday when the tail of the Newark arena was wagging the dog of the entire state budget," said State Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican and a member of the budget committee. "This budget is still a dog." 
In addition to the business tax, the budget relies on borrowing $1.1 billion against the state's expected share of the settlement with tobacco companies. It also raises the cigarette tax by 70 cents, to $1.50 a pack, increases scores of state fees, like those for boat licenses and construction code violations. About half the new revenue comes from sources known as "one-shots," like the diversion of money from the state unemployment insurance fund.
Soon after winning election in November, Mr. McGreevey anticipated the budget shortfall and loudly and consistently blamed years of borrowing and spending by Republicans, who had controlled the governorship and the Legislature for eight years.
His own budget plan turned to the business tax as a source of new money. The governor, arguing that many big corporations had escaped their fair share of the tax burden, said three-quarters of the corporations in the state and 30 of the 50 largest employers were paying only the $200 minimum required under the old law.
His plan came under attack, though, as an advertising campaign and thousands of faxes and calls to legislators' offices called it an undue burden on small and medium-sized businesses and a drag on the state's economy. 
The retooled plan imposes an "alternative minimum" tax on a graduated basis, which is calculated according to gross receipts or gross profits, whichever is higher. The plan also taxes royalties from out-of-state subsidiaries of New Jersey companies and taxes out-of-state sales that are not already taxed by other states. 
Since the budget package draws on borrowed money and one-shot revenue raises, it does not significantly reduce the recurrent imbalance between steady revenue and state spending. 
Wall Street bond-rating agencies, worried about the gap, have lowered New Jersey's credit rating in the last year. 
Republicans and Democrats have never agreed on the size of Mr. McGreevey's budget increase. Total spending is about $500 million more than the budget adopted a year ago, but fiscal problems forced spending reductions of about $1.5 billion during the year. 
In the end, the Republicans agreed to supply the one vote needed on each of the budget-related bills to get them through the Senate. On Sunday night, they did so, and were delighted when it was the Democrats who tripped up the governor. 
Last night and this morning, after Mr. McGreevey and Mr. James had each made a public show of intransigence, the two men met in Newark. With other Democratic leaders, they worked out a deal to approve the budget today and convene hearings this summer on the arena and other sports facilities in North Jersey. 
The senators spent less than five minutes this afternoon on the vote, then scattered for the doors amid calls of "Have a nice summer!" Mr. McGreevey signed the bill quickly, in his office. 
Republican leaders, emerging with little to show for months of budget negotiations, stayed long enough to take a last shot at the legislation just enacted. Senator John O. Bennett, the Republican Senate co-president, called the corporate business tax a horrible piece of legislation that had been somewhat improved.
"It's his budget," Mr. Bennett said of Mr. McGreevey. "It's a Democratic budget. If the people like it and they think it's a great budget, then Jim McGreevey will be a happy man." 
Senator Bennett would speak only obliquely about the chaos of Sunday night and the Democrats' disarray. He said he and the Democratic Senate co-president, Richard J. Codey, had talked about how to make it a more orderly process.

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Looking Anew at Value Of a Corporate Pedigree

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2 

 BODY:
George W. Bush is the first president with an M.B.A., and his administration once proudly promoted its corporate experience as evidence of how it could bring boardroom smarts to governance and policy.
 But as the hard-charging, profit-producing, globe-conquering chief executive of the 1990's gives way in popular culture to the disgraced, book-cooking defendant of the post-boom era, the political appeal of a corporate pedigree is no longer so certain. 
 It could hold particular peril for Mr. Bush and his team as they respond to the wave of corporate financial scandals by taking a hard line against executives found to have misled investors. In essentially saying there should be a zero-tolerance policy when it comes to corporate ethical breaches, the president has opened the door to a re-examination of his own business record, as well as the records of Vice President Dick Cheney, members of his cabinet and other administration officials who have logged time in the corner office. 
While Mr. Bush and other officials have always said they have nothing to hide, they are already finding their effort to position themselves as guardians of investor trust complicated by questions about their own handling of accounting issues, stock sales and the like.
Just today, Mr. Bush was asked about his sale of stock 12 years ago in the Harken Energy Corporation, a company whose board he had joined after selling it another company he had run. Mr. Bush sold the stock as it was falling in value, and before the company publicly disclosed a loss that sent the stock down further.
The transaction was examined at the time by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which took no action against him. The issue came up again today after Paul Krugman, a columnist for The New York Times, recounted the transaction and noted that the commission's decision not to pursue the case came while Mr. Bush's father was president.
"Everything I do is fully disclosed, it's been fully vetted," Mr. Bush said when asked about the topic by reporters as he visited Milwaukee today. "Any other questions?"
As the corporate scandals have unfolded, driving down stock prices as the economy struggles to recover from last year's recession, Mr. Bush has been increasingly outspoken about the duties and responsibilities of corporate executives -- and about his belief that executives who defraud investors and cost employees their jobs should be prosecuted aggressively.
He has proposed initiatives to tighten oversight of accounting, make better information available to investors and to hold executives more accountable for any wrongdoing. He is expected to lay out additional proposals next Tuesday in a speech in New York.
"No violation of the public's trust will be tolerated," Mr. Bush said on Saturday in his weekly radio talk. 
But Democrats sense in the corporate scandals an issue that might finally dent Mr. Bush's approval ratings. They are making a case that Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney, during their time in the corporate world, would not have been able to live up to the policies they are advocating now.
"Perhaps the reason the Bush administration took so long to take action on this issue is because they want to avoid having fingers pointed at the president and vice president who engaged in the behavior they are now attempting to reform," the Democratic National Committee said today in documents it distributed to reporters.
As Democrats pointed out, the Securities and Exchange Commission found that Mr. Bush filed the required disclosure forms about his Harken stock sales weeks or even months late. Yet this spring he proposed that corporate officers be required to disclose sales of company stock within two days.
There is also increased attention on Mr. Cheney's tenure as chief executive of Halliburton, the oil field services company. The securities commission disclosed in May that it had begun an inquiry into Halliburton's accounting practices during 1998, while Mr. Cheney was running the company. Mr. Cheney has declined to comment on the inquiry.
Harvey Pitt, the commission chairman, said last weekend that his agency would follow the inquiry wherever it led. "We don't give anyone a pass," Mr. Pitt said on ABC's "This Week."
Given that his cabinet includes former corporate executives like Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, who ran Alcoa, and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, who headed G. D. Searle and General Instrument, Mr. Bush is sure to find the rest of his administration's corporate past scrutinized by journalists and his political opponents. Political analysts and pollsters also said the change in public opinion about business and its relations with politics and fund-raising might be only beginning, presenting a continuing challenge to Mr. Bush and his party -- especially since more and more voters own stock directly or through retirement plans.
"The transformation is clearly under way, and I don't see any signs that it's about to peak and go away," said Kevin Phillips, the political commentator and the author of "Wealth and Democracy: A Political History of the American Rich." "The nature of the transgressions makes it likely that we're only seeing the one-tenth of two-tenths that are above the surface. This is a major problem for the administration."
Republicans said that Democrats had failed to do any political damage to Mr. Bush on other issues and that they were unlikely to succeed in painting him as a tool of corporate interests now as long as the president continued to take a hard line against corporate wrongdoing.
"Bush is using the word that matters more than anything else, and that's 'accountability,' " said Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster. "That's exactly what Americans want to hear. The language the Democrats use is too angry, and it doesn't resonate because it's too political. No one thinks they're doing it for the average working man or woman. They're doing it for political reasons, and that's why they lose credibility."

HEADLINE: General Is Paid $183,372 For Domestic Security Role 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2 

 BODY:
If there was ever any doubt that there is money in security these days, just ask Maj. Gen. Bruce Lawlor. 
 As the director for protection and prevention in the Office of Homeland Security, General Lawlor is the highest-paid member of the White House staff, with an annual salary of $183,372. His job description: protect the nation in the event of chemical, biological or nuclear attack. 
 His pay level, which is higher than the vice president's, was reported in a list of salaries for all White House staff provided to Congress this week in response to demands by House Democrats.
For those with less dire duties, the rewards are less -- but only slightly, according to the list. Virtually all of President Bush's top advisers earn $145,000, the report shows.
Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff, earns $145,000, as do Nicolas E. Calio, the president's assistant for legislative affairs, and Alberto R. Gonzales, the White House counsel, Joseph Hagin, the deputy chief of staff, and Albert Hawkins, a presidential assistant.
Also in that top echelon are Lewis Libby, the vice president's chief of staff; Lawrence B. Lindsey, the director of the National Economic Council; Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser; and Karl Rove, the ubiquitous adviser.
President Bush's message makers also receive salaries of $145,000. That includes Karen P. Hughes, the influential presidential counselor who is leaving Washington with a "homesick" family, and Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, who admits that his job hinges at times on knowing what not to say.
Michael J. Gerson, the director of speechwriting, earns $130,000.
Vice President Dick Cheney's salary last year was $174,475, tax records show.
The C.E.O. of the operation, Mr. Bush, earns $400,000, more than twice as much as any staff member. 
A White House spokeswoman, Anne Womack, said tonight that General Lawlor, who is retired from the military, earns more than his boss, Tom Ridge, director of domestic security, who earns $145,000, because the general is detailed from the Pentagon.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Defining Failed Schools Is Harder Than It Sounds

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE Supreme Court ruled last week, in a case involving Cleveland schools, that public money in the form of vouchers could subsidize the tuition of students who choose to attend religious schools. It was only partly a legal judgment that such aid does not violate the separation of church and state. What propelled the court was also a policy conclusion that vouchers may be a way to rescue children from failing public schools. 
 Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said that his majority ruling was "not an endorsement of religious schooling," but only a means "to assist poor children in failed schools." Justice David H. Souter, in dissent, acknowledged that if ever there was reason to support religious schools, Cleveland's failed public schools would provide it. 
 But nobody really knows how to identify failing schools, the justices included. Policy makers have been so anxious to punish school failure that they have worried too little about defining what failure is.
Typically, a failing school is deemed one with low scores. By this measure, Cleveland schools do fail, prompting parents to seek radical alternatives.
But while low scores can result from failed schools, they can also have other causes. Poor performance can also result from parents who do not read to young children or otherwise support learning at home. It can result from inadequate exposure to art and music. It can result from insecurity bred of violent surroundings, from emotional stress in broken families or from parents suffering severe economic hardship. In combination, these factors almost ensure failure.
How can policy makers distinguish schools that fail because of low expectations, poor teaching and disorderly classrooms from those that seem to fail because of social and economic pressure?
Cleveland vouchers highlight the problem. The State of Ohio commissioned studies to evaluate the program. If Cleveland schools were truly failing, then public school students who used vouchers at successful private schools should have higher scores than comparable students remaining in public schools.
But if voucher students did as poorly as comparable public school students, then Cleveland's public school "failure" is likely attributable less to what public schools do than to obstacles all schools, public and private, face in educating disadvantaged children.
The studies were conducted by Kim K. Metcalf of Indiana University, and reviewed by outside experts, including supporters and opponents of vouchers.
In his most recent report, Dr. Metcalf compared students who got vouchers with public school students who wanted vouchers but did not get them because there were too few to go around. The two groups had no significant differences in scores.
When voucher students were compared with public school students who did not apply for vouchers, voucher students did better in language arts (like grammar) but not in math or other reading skills. The voucher students' language scores were only slightly higher. 
Susan Tave Zelman, Ohio's superintendent of public instruction, concluded: "We don't see anything one way or another from these studies on the academic results of vouchers. The lack of dramatic results is neither a negative nor positive judgment on the program."
Meanwhile, state test data show how complex definitions of failure can be. Cleveland, where 80 percent of students are from low-income families, certainly seems to be failing; most students are not proficient in most subjects.
Like many other urban areas, Cleveland is surrounded by suburbs with growing minority populations. Most people would think that these districts succeed because their overall scores are still above standard. But minority students' average scores are much lower, and the gap between white and black students in these "successful" districts is comparable to the gap in "failing" Cleveland schools.
Ohio permits Cleveland students to transfer not only to private schools, but also to public schools in these suburbs. But no suburb would take any Cleveland students. Officials at suburban schools that already had some poor students recognized that if they added too many more, their schools could be termed "failing" even if instruction remained adequate.
Of course, many Cleveland schools may fail because they do not rise to the challenge of educating disadvantaged students. Others may be more successful, although their test scores are still low. Roman Catholic schools in Cleveland, which accept most of the voucher students, may be in either category. We simply can't tell them apart because scores are low in both cases.
When Supreme Court justices thought they found a way for urban students to escape failing schools, they ventured into an area beyond their judicial expertise. They should not be blamed. The expertise is pretty scarce, no matter where you look.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (David Suter)

HEADLINE: Arabs at the Crossroads 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
President Bush was right to declare that the Palestinians need to produce decent governance before they can get a state. Too bad, however, that he didn't say that it's not only the Palestinians who need radical reform of their governance -- it's most of the Arab world. 
 By coincidence, though, some other important folks had the courage to say that just this week: The U.N. Development Program, which published, along with the Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development, a brutally honest Arab Human Development Report yesterday analyzing the three main reasons the Arab world is falling off the globe. (The G.D.P. of Spain is greater than that of all 22 Arab states combined.) In brief, it's due to a shortage of freedom to speak, innovate and affect political life, a shortage of women's rights and a shortage of quality education. If you want to understand the milieu that produced bin Ladenism, and will reproduce it if nothing changes, read this report. 
 While the 22 Arab states currently have 280 million people, soaring birthrates indicate that by 2020 they will have 410 to 459 million. If this new generation is not to grow up angry and impoverished, in already overcrowded cities, the Arab world will have to overcome its poverty -- which is not a poverty of resources but a "poverty of capabilities and poverty of opportunities," the report argues.
Though the report pays homage to the argument that the Arab-Israeli conflict and Israeli occupation have been both a cause and an excuse for lagging Arab development, it refuses to stop with that explanation.
To begin with, it notes that "the wave of democracy that transformed governance in most of Latin America and East Asia in the 1980's and early 1990's has barely reached the Arab states. This freedom deficit undermines human development." Using a standard freedom index, the report notes that out of seven key regions of the world the Arab region has the lowest freedom score -- which includes civil liberties, political rights, a voice for the people, independence of the media and government accountability. In too many Arab states women can't vote, hold office or get access to capital for starting businesses. "Sadly, the Arab world is largely depriving itself of the creativity and productivity of half its citizens," the report says of Arab women.
On education, the report reveals that the whole Arab world translates about 300 books annually -- one-fifth the number that Greece alone translates; investment in research is less than one-seventh the world average; and Internet connectivity is lower than in sub-Saharan Africa. In spite of progress in school enrollment, 65 million Arab adults are still illiterate, almost two-thirds of them women. No wonder half the Arab youths polled said they wanted to emigrate.
The report concludes that "What the region needs to ensure a bright future for coming generations is the political will to invest in Arab capabilities and knowledge, particularly those of Arab women, in good governance, and in strong cooperation between Arab nations. . . . The Arab world is at a crossroads. The fundamental choice is whether its trajectory will remain marked by inertia . . . and by ineffective policies that have produced the substantial development challenges facing the region; or whether prospects for an Arab renaissance, anchored in human development, will be actively pursued."
Well said -- and here's the best part: The report was written by a "group of distinguished Arab intellectuals" who believed that only an "unbiased, objective analysis" could help the "Arab peoples and policy-makers in search of a brighter future." 
There is a message in this bottle for America: For too many years we've treated the Arab world as just a big dumb gas station, and as long as the top leader kept the oil flowing, or was nice to Israel, we didn't really care what was happening to the women and children out back -- where bad governance, rising unemployment and a stifled intellectual life were killing the Arab future.
It's time to stop kidding ourselves. Getting rid of the Osamas, Saddams and Arafats is necessary to change this situation, but it's hardly sufficient. We also need to roll up our sleeves and help the Arabs address all the problems out back. The bad news is that they've dug themselves a mighty deep hole there. The good news, as this report shows, is that we have liberal Arab partners for change. It's time we teamed up with them, and not just with the bums who got them into this mess.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, It's Art For the City's Sake; 
Bloomberg's Hearty Embrace Signals A Whole New Approach at City Hall

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Something out of the ordinary happened when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg presented the annual Art Commission Awards this May. It wasn't the mayor's proclamation that public spaces should be beautiful, or that he stood around for an hour after the awards were presented, sipping cocktails. Rather, it was that he was there at all.
 "As an art commissioner with eight years of understanding that we were second-class citizens who were labeled obstructionists," said Bud Konheim, a commission member, "this sends a real signal. It always was, the mayor showed up once or twice and then the commissioner gave out the award. This year, we got reserved seats, he thanked each one of us personally and he gave out the award." 
 Since assuming office six months ago, Mr. Bloomberg has taken a quiet but significant interest in the arts, especially those in public spaces. His administration has borrowed sculptures from the Museum of Modern Art for the lawn at Gracie Mansion, and nine paintings and three sculptures on loan from the Whitney Museum of American Art came rolling into City Hall for use in Mr. Bloomberg's office. More sculptures will soon go up in historic City Hall Park.
Mr. Bloomberg has revived arts awards that were rarely given after Mayor Edward I. Koch left office, and he makes a point of attending the presentation ceremonies for them. When he swore in his cultural affairs commissioner, Kate D. Levin, he did so at Gracie Mansion, and invited the city's art world to attend. Even the most prosaic of city property -- the Green Book, which is the official directory of city government -- will now have its cover graced by a reproduction of a Keith Haring image of the Statue of Liberty.
The Department of Cultural Affairs received among the most gentle of cuts to the city's budget this year, about 5 percent, compared with the 7 percent to 15 percent cuts most agencies had to endure. And this fall, the mayor made an "anonymous" $10 million gift from his personal fortune to help out arts groups.
"Mike was a strong supporter of the arts at his company," said Deputy Mayor Patricia E. Harris, who plays an important role in all things art-related in the administration. "As mayor, he realizes the arts and culture are the reason people want to live and stay here, and that they are strong economic engines. An arts organization in a community often transforms the environment."
Mr. Bloomberg has a long history of philanthropy in the arts. Before he was elected, he served on the boards of three cultural institutions in New York, two in London, and regularly gave money to various arts groups. His company, Bloomberg L.P., sponsors audio guides to cultural attractions in New York, and various public art projects through the Public Art Fund, such as the erection of 13 Keith Haring sculptures along Park Avenue in 1997. He adopted a sculpture on Randalls Island and sponsored its restoration.
Mr. Bloomberg has extended his interest in the arts to public life, in large part through Ms. Harris, who worked in the Koch administration when the city was one of the country's biggest recipients of federal art money in the country.
"Excellence in public design will be one of the hallmarks of my administration," Mr. Bloomberg told those assembled for the Art Commission awards. "It will be a guiding principle in city projects ranging from the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan to the reclamation of the city's waterfront for public use and enjoyment to the economic revitalization of communities in all five boroughs." And when the arts do not have money, he has made it clear to friends that he will dig into his own substantial checking account, particularly to support smaller arts groups.
As with all things related to art, subjectivity plays a role in the civic life of art, and Mr. Bloomberg's sensibilities are not shared by everyone.
For instance, the mayor supports resurrecting Christo's "The Gates, Project for Central Park, New York City," a proposal to drape trees in the park in saffron -- an idea many New Yorkers loathe. And one of the great historic buildings of the city, the Tweed Courthouse, will not be used as a museum as planned, but will instead house the Board of Education. Then there are the dog sculptures to be placed all over the city beginning in August. Some consider them cute; Rodin would probably not be jealous.
Mr. Bloomberg's eclectic taste in art is demonstrated by the wide range of paintings and sculptures from the Whitney he selected for his office, which he sometimes uses for meetings (the mayor spends most of his time in an open bullpen with his staff). There is a "Standing Lincoln" figure by Daniel Chester French, who designed the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, and "Big Orange," by the abstract expressionist painter Robert Motherwell. There is another piece by Keith Haring (yes, him again, a favorite of Mr. Bloomberg's), and a stunning 1913 painting of the Brooklyn Bridge, by Samuel Halpert.
The museum's curator gave the mayor several pieces of work to choose from, with Mr. Bloomberg and Ms. Harris making the final cut. Many of the artists whose works were selected live or have lived in New York. Discussion of the work is encouraged. "My sense is that the mayor believes it is nice to work with beautiful objects," said Ms. Levin, whose agency was among the first Mr. Bloomberg visited after his election. "Just as important is being able to provoke discussion, to make people really think and be conscious."
Several of Mr. Bloomberg's more arts-friendly acts have garnered applause from the city's art leaders, many of whom were less than thrilled under the prior administration's sometimes combative stance toward the arts.
While Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani earmarked huge capital budgets for the city's larger cultural institutions toward the end of his term, he alienated many arts groups by constantly proposing deep budget cuts, taking on the Brooklyn Museum after he found its "Sensation" exhibition offensive and then forming a decency commission to study what type of art was suitable for public financing.
"The arts community was very demoralized at the end of the Giuliani administration," said Susan Freedman, the president of the Public Art Fund. And Ms. Harris said Mr. Bloomberg would ensure that the Art Commission would regain the autonomy it had lost in recent years, when City Council members and Giuliani officials wanted to close the agency. (Former Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern once derided it for "arrogance, elitism and a patronizing attitude.")
Deborah Bershad, the executive director of the Art Commission, said yesterday: "This administration has brought a great sensitivity for the arts and culture. I think as a businessman he knows that how the city looks is very important."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 19, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on July 3 about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's promotion of art in public places referred imprecisely to "The Gates," a project proposed by the artist Christo and supported by the mayor. It would festoon 26 miles of Central Park's walkways in swatches of translucent saffron fabric supported by thousands of metal gates; it would not drape trees in the fabric.
