HEADLINE: For Oklahoma's Teachers, Big D Is Dollars (and Dallas) 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 3 

 BODY:
Donya Shaffer, fresh out of teachers college this spring, always imagined herself standing before a classroom in Chickasha, the Oklahoma town where she and her husband, both children of teachers, have roots almost as deep in the soil as in the schoolhouse.
 But a couple of weeks ago, her husband handed Ms. Shaffer an advertisement in The Oklahoman newspaper. The Dallas schools were offering a salary of $34,000 for new teachers -- about $7,000 more than Oklahoma pays -- a signing bonus of up to $4,500, a $250 stipend for classroom supplies and extensive health insurance. They even threw in a free laptop computer. 
 It was then that her husband said the words Ms. Shaffer never expected to hear: "We'll all move there. I'll sell my part in the family business, and we'll go."
Last Thursday, the Dallas school board sweetened the pot, raising the starting salary to $37,000, a sum it would take Ms. Shaffer 20 years to earn in Chickasha (pronounced CHICK-a-shay).
In town for the annual teachers union convention, Ms. Shaffer plans to leave her resume with Dallas school officials before going home this weekend. And Oklahoma will probably lose one more link in its next generation of teachers.
"We have a real support network in Chickasha, and we'll have to leave it," said Ms. Shaffer, who gave birth to her first child, a son, seven weeks ago. "But I have to think of my family."
Much to the dismay of Texas' neighbors, which offer some of the lowest salaries and barest-bones benefits for teachers in the nation, Dallas is aggressively wooing certified teachers from adjacent Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana as well as Kansas and Mississippi.
With the federal Department of Education estimating that schools will need to hire two million new teachers by 2010, the competition for certified teachers is heating up, particularly in cities like Dallas. Signing bonuses are becoming common, but some school systems have gone further, said Michael Allen, director of programs at the Education Commission of the States.
Santa Clara, Calif., an almost prohibitively expensive place to live, has built housing for public school teachers. Baltimore -- short 1,200 teachers for the coming school year -- offers beginning teachers salaries that elsewhere in the state require three years of experience, on top of statewide incentives that include low-interest mortgages and tuition tax credits. School boards are giving away laptops, Palm Pilots and other gadgets the way banks once offered toasters for new accounts.
With the heightened competition there has also been a change in the way teachers view their jobs. When Glen Walton began teaching high school in Tulsa, Okla., nine years ago, he and his wife, Sherri, a kindergarten teacher, bought a stone house that Mr. Walton fixed up and landscaped for the decades ahead. The couple expected to retire in Tulsa one day.
Now, the Waltons are going to Texas, a move that will increase their family income by $20,000. Mr. Walton will drop the after-school programs he ran to bring in extra cash, and make $43,000, more than he ever could in Tulsa.
By the end of June, the Dallas system had filled about 400 of its 456 vacancies, said Donald Claxton, a school spokesman. Linda Davis, at the school district's personnel division, said her office had not broken down precisely how many of the newly hired teachers were coming from other states, and how many were home-grown, but she believed that after Texas, the second-largest number of teachers came from the other side of the Red River, in Oklahoma.
Even without advertising, Texas hires 3,500 to 4,000 teachers a year from beyond its borders, said Edward Fuller, co-director of research at the Texas Education Agency. In 2000, the last year the agency collected such data, 580 new teachers came from Oklahoma; the next most common states were Louisiana, Arkansas and Kansas.
Dallas's campaign is hardly winning it friends in nearby states. Education officials and state legislators lament that Oklahoma trains teachers at its state colleges and universities, then loses them to states paying salaries it cannot match.
"Obviously, it's all about money," said Sandy Garrett, superintendent of Oklahoma schools. "Oklahoma doesn't have it."
"We'd like to build a fence at the Red River," she said. 
Contending with a recession, Oklahoma lawmakers cut the education budget 4 percent more last week, trimming away money that some schools had already spent. In Ardmore, a city near the Texas border, school officials are waiting to see final enrollment figures to decide whether to hire four more teachers.
"Obviously, the more qualified teachers are already snatched up," said Geneva Matlack, assistant superintendent for personnel in the Ardmore schools. "By late August, we're stuck with the leftovers."
Ardmore lost 25 of its 263 teachers to Texas in the last three years, Ms. Matlack said. In an interview at her office, she recited the job titles of teachers who left. Many were in special education, math, science or other hard-to-fill areas.
In Oklahoma, the sweet talk from Texas is a balm to teachers who say they feel demeaned by legislative battles over salary and benefits. Gov. Frank Keating talks of teachers in terms that could easily apply to convicts, at one particularly low point describing some educators as "slugs," at another suggesting "homicide" as a way to deal with the state teachers union. He later apologized.
Most Oklahoma teachers "wouldn't spit on the governor if he were on fire," said Nela Foster of Oklahoma City, who plans to look for a job in Dallas when she finishes her teacher training at the University of Central Oklahoma next year.
Ms. Foster, 39, said that with her husband retiring from the Air Force next year, the plan was a simple matter of economics. With six children, the couple needs the extra income, she said.
"Money really is talking to us," said Ms. Foster, the incoming president of the Oklahoma student chapter of the National Education Association, the teachers union.
Ms. Shaffer, the departing president, is picking up that same message. She loves Chickasha, but said that providing for her family has become a priority with her son's birth. Ms. Shaffer's parents were teachers, but salaries were so meager that their five children qualified for reduced price lunches, she said.
Ms. Shaffer went down a list she had written out, with columns comparing Texas and Oklahoma: a $37,000 starting salary in Texas versus a $27,000 starting salary at home. Complete versus partial health coverage. Laptop or no laptop. She shook her head, remembering those cheap lunches.
"If there's any way teachers in Oklahoma can get to Texas," she said, "they're going."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
June Employment Report Reflects a Jobless Recovery
As the government reported a rise in the unemployment rate to 5.9 percent last month, it seems increasingly clear that the economy is stuck in a jobless recovery resembling the sluggish growth of the early 1990's.
 "In a sense, the recession is over, but the recovery has not begun," said Mark Vitner, the senior economist at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C. Nonfarm payroll jobs rose by only 36,000 last month. Page A1. 

Stocks Surge in Light Trading
Ignoring a plethora of warnings of possible terrorist attacks, the main stock indexes rallied, though the strong move higher was not underpinned by heavy trading volume. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 324.53 points, or 3.6 percent, to 9,379.50. The Nasdaq jumped nearly 5 percent, or 68.19 points, to 1,448.36. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 35.04 points, or 3.7 percent, to 989.03. C4.

Prozac by Surprise Mail Spurs Suit
Experts in medical privacy have long been critical of mailings to patients who have been singled out based on information in their medical records. Now, some people who have been mailed actual samples of Prozac, and who believe the privacy of their medical records has been violated, are taking legal action. A1.

WorldCom Continues Its Review
An internal investigation at WorldCom into accounting irregularities is continuing despite a report that indicated the Justice Department was seeking to curtail those activities as the agency conducts its own investigation, according to the head of the internal inquiry. C2.

Qwest Denies Criminal Investigation
Qwest Communications denied that it was the subject of a criminal investigation. Qwest is under examination by the Securities and Exchange Commission for its accounting. C4.

Long Island City Becomes a Priority
For years, Long Island City in Queens has struck many people in real estate as a wasted asset in New York City's struggle to keep companies from moving jobs to New Jersey. Now, the Bloomberg administration says it has made Long Island City one of its top five economic development priorities. B1.

Conditional Approval of Energy Deal
The German government granted conditional approval to a 10.3 billion euro ($10.09 billion) takeover bid by the energy giant E.ON for Ruhrgas, Germany's largest natural gas distributor, a decision that could result in a powerful new player in the global energy market. Ulrich Hartmann, E.ON's chief executive, above, said, "Together with Ruhrgas, we can now build up a leading international position in the gas business." C3.

U.S. Banks Seek to Aid Mexicans
Illegal Mexican immigrants typically do not have bank accounts in the United States, but American banks want to get in on the billions of dollars these immigrants earn, spend and send home. So they have become allies of the immigrants and the Mexican government in pushing for recognition of Mexican-issued consular cards as valid identification. C3.

Trading Bloc Backs Argentina
Heaping blame for their countries' woes on the global economy and a rise in protectionism in industrialized nations, leaders of South America's main trading bloc, Mercosur, closed ranks behind Argentina, urging international aid for the country, whose economic collapse has sent neighboring markets into a tailspin. C3.

PlayStation 2 Outpaces Rivals
Sales of Sony's PlayStation 2 in North America more than doubled in May, outpacing sales by its rivals, Microsoft and Nintendo, an industry report said. C2.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE AT 5.9% IN JUNE; A SLIGHT INCREASE 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate rose slightly, to 5.9 percent, last month, the government reported yesterday. The economy appears to have fallen into a so-called jobless recovery that resembles the slow growth of the early 1990's, economists said.
 "In a sense, the recession is over, but the recovery has not begun," said Mark Vitner, the senior economist at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C. "Companies are still focusing on cutting costs and are still reluctant to hire additional workers." 
 A rise in consumer and government spending apparently brought the recession that began in early 2001 to an end several months ago. But many companies have decided that economic growth is likely to be too mild to justify new hiring; instead, they are trying to meet new demand by becoming more efficient. 
Since the start of the year, about 150,000 jobs have been lost over all among the more than 130 million Americans on nonfarm payrolls. Most economists expect the jobless rate, which is adjusted to account for normal seasonal variations, to inch up further this year and surpass the recent high of 6 percent it reached in April.
The increase in unemployment, up from 5.8 percent in May and a 30-year low of 3.9 percent in late 2000, suggests that the Federal Reserve will not raise its benchmark interest rate until at least the end of the year, analysts said. 
On Wall Street, the stock market continued its rebound from the post-Sept. 11 lows that a few major indexes had hit early this week, although trading was light yesterday and the stock market closed early for the holiday weekend. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped almost 325 points, or 3.6 percent, to 9,380, it biggest one-day gain since Sept. 24.
Some investors said they were cheered by the absence of a major terrorist attack on July 4, and thought they had overreacted to recent accounting scandals. Yesterday's jobs report also played a role in the stock gains, making an interest rate increase less likely in the coming months and offering evidence that companies are trying to lift sagging profits by keeping payrolls lean, analysts said.
Other recent signs of economic strength make a serious deterioration in the job market unlikely this year, economists said. Factory orders are continuing to rise in a sign that the manufacturing sector, battered worse than any other since 2000, is slowly recovering. The housing market remains buoyant. In addition, new requests for unemployment benefits dropped last week to their lowest level in 15 months.
"The labor market is not strong," Elaine L. Chao, the secretary of labor, said in an interview, "but it has stabilized."
The economy now seems to have entered a transition period, growing much less quickly than it did in the late 1990's and slowing from the spike that produced growth at about a 6 percent annual rate during this year's first quarter, when business executives and consumers realized that the economic effect of Sept. 11 would be fairly limited.
In June, companies and government agencies added 36,000 workers to their payrolls, not enough to make up for the usual increase in the labor force caused by population growth. The Labor Department also announced that its earlier estimates of hiring in April and May had been too optimistic, with the economy adding only 3,000 jobs in those two months, not 47,000. 
The lack of widespread hiring, on the heels of substantial layoffs late last year, has caused an increase in the number of people who have been out of work for months at a time. More than 3.1 million people have been unemployed for at least 15 weeks, twice the number who were in that category a year ago and the most since 1993.
To be considered unemployed by the Labor Department, a person must be actively looking for work.
The recession of the early 1990's ended in March 1991, when the unemployment rate was 6.8 percent. But joblessness continued to rise through the summer of 1992 and did not fall below 6.8 percent until late 1993.
In earlier decades, hiring often boomed immediately after a recession's end as factories rushed to meet the demand that had built up like water behind a dam during the downturn. In recent years, however, service companies, whose business is less volatile than that of manufacturers, have become a larger part of the economy. The Fed also appears to have become more successful at moderating the business cycle's swings, making recessions less frequent but rebounds slower to take off.
"The question on many of our minds is when should we think of a this recovery as a 'jobless recovery,' too," said Jared Bernstein, a senior economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research group in Washington. "My answer is now."
Beyond the broad numbers, the jobs report for June offered little evidence that hiring is on the verge of accelerating, although such turning points can happen with little if any real warning.
As has been the case for much of this year, the public sector did more hiring in June than private businesses, accounting for almost two-thirds of total job growth. While government agencies, including schools and the military, have added about 100,000 new workers this year, companies have cut their payrolls by 250,000 people.
The contrast offers some reason for concern, economists said, because budget deficits in many states are likely to prevent them from remaining a source of new jobs. 
Within the private sector, employment in almost every sector was flat, noted Thomas J. Nardone, the Labor Department economist who oversees the survey. That left little reason to believe that any industry would soon emerge to play the central role that information technology and telecommunications did in the 1990's.
The one exception was health care, which added 34,000 jobs in June and employed 295,000 more people last month than it had a year earlier. New treatments and the aging of the population have increased demand for medical care.
Elsewhere, most companies have done little permanent hiring in recent months, relying instead on temporary-help agencies. Temporary jobs typically do not pay as well, in salary or benefits, as permanent jobs do, but they frequently offer a hint of the labor market's future direction. 
In June, the agencies added 9,000 jobs, down from an average of 44,000 during the previous three months. Economists cautioned that one-month changes often prove to be fleeting and that temporary employment could rise solidly again in July. 
The brightest signs in the report were the small increase in the workweek for people in production and nonsupervisory jobs -- to 34.3 hours, the most since January 2001 -- and the $9.49 weekly raise those workers received. 
A rise in the workweek often foreshadows an increase in hiring. Meanwhile, the continued growth of wages, while below its pace of the late 1990's, offers a reminder that unemployment remains lower than it has been at the end of every other recession since 1970.

HEADLINE: Treasuring Blacks' Long Memories 

BYLINE:  By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
Eight years ago, Camille Cosby used the Broadway stage to give two African-American centenarian sisters a chance to share their stories. The play, "Having Our Say," based on the best-selling 1991 book about Sadie and Bessie Delaney, was a virtual oral history.
 Now, Mrs. Cosby, a co-producer of the play and the wife of Bill Cosby, has established a videotaped oral history archive that is gathering the reminiscences of other older, distinguished African-Americans. 
 The National Visionary Leadership Project, a nonprofit organization, was established last spring by Mrs. Cosby and Renee Poussaint, a former correspondent for ABC News, to record and videotape the experiences of blacks in their 70's and 80's. The interviews will be made available through a digital database accessible through the project's WWeb site, www .visionaryproject.com, with the hope that it will ultimately reach a broader audience through television and CD-ROM.
Mrs. Cosby provided all of the funds for the project and hopes to raise additional money through corporate, foundation and individual contributions. The project has an annual budget of $1.5 million. 
Mrs. Cosby, who has a doctorate in education, said her organization aspires to do for black Americans what Mr. Spielberg's Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation has done in recording the memories of aging Holocaust survivors, although it will be far more modest in size. Since its establishment in 1994, Mr. Spielberg's organization has collected and preserved videotaped testimony of more than 50,000 people. Mrs. Cosby's project plans to begin by completing 60 interviews a year for five years. 
While the Holocaust is the common thread for Mr. Spielberg's subjects, racism runs through the lives in Mrs. Cosby's project, she said. In the interviews, Mrs. Cosby and Ms. Poussaint asked the subjects to talk about race and racism in America. Each said in the interviews that racism had been a fact of life, but none said it had been an insurmountable obstacle.
"We have decided to record oral histories and present them just the way the elders have said it," said Mrs. Cosby, who holds the title of president and co-founder. "It is the only way to protect these histories, for people all over the world to use these oral histories as resources to know the truth. And our young people can use these histories as resources to learn leadership skills."
Most oral history projects are at the state or local level or are collected as parts of larger historical archives, like those for labor or politics. Mrs. Cosby's project is the first that is solely devoted to the history of black Americans and that is aimed at a national audience.
Among the 30 subjects who have already been interviewed are the former mayor of New York City, David N. Dinkins; the poet Maya Angelou; former Representative Shirley Chisholm; Gordon Parks, the noted photographer and filmmaker; and Dr. Dorothy I. Height, president of the National Council of Negro Women.
Their lives may seem well documented, but Mrs. Cosby and Ms. Poussaint have managed to coax their subjects to speak their minds in ways seldom heard before.
When asked to describe the biggest obstacle that she faced during her bid for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1972, Mrs. Chisholm smiles at the camera and says without missing a beat: "Men."
"All kinds of men," said Mrs. Chisholm, the first black woman to run for the presidency. "Black men, Latino men. Men."
Ms. Angelou, looking regal in an Afrocentric head wrap, says she has married and left many men in her life, but at 73, she is "still looking."
"Oh, the 70's are delicious," she said of aging. "I'm having a wonderful time."
The visionaries, as the project calls them, also share poignant anecdotes about personal triumphs and struggles, regrets and hopes, and other dramatic events of private and public life.
Mr. Dinkins said, half-jokingly, that his newspaper obituary will probably lead with the racial riots that took place in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn in 1991 during his tenure in office. He said that one of his "strongest regrets" was not telling his police commissioner sooner to change the department's tactics in handling the riots. 
Andrew Young, formerly the mayor of Atlanta and the United States ambassador to the United Nations, talks about the difficulty that his son, Bo, has faced growing up as the son of a national black leader.
"His teachers would say to him: 'Why aren't you like your dad? When he was your age, your dad did this or did that,' " Mr. Young said. "The problem is, when I was Bo's age, I was exactly the same as Bo. A total screw-up." 
The project's headquarters is in an attractive, historic brownstone in downtown Washington. The building houses the archives, a resource library, a reading room, the latest in production facilities, a "hall of fame" featuring the oral history subjects and an art gallery
Ms. Poussaint, the project's executive director and co-founder, said the interviews had opened her eyes in unexpected ways.
"I'm having a wonderful time discovering the total humanity of these wonderful people," Ms. Poussaint said. "The elders are sharing things that they couldn't share before, particularly about their own vulnerabilities, because many of them were involved in the civil rights movement and grew up under segregation. So to show vulnerability, to acknowledge mistakes and have that kind of freedom to be open about such things could be costly."
Mrs. Cosby said she hoped that the interviews would also serve as a teaching tool. The project has established 30 student fellowships at institutions including Howard, Georgetown, Fisk, Oberlin, Spelman and Berkeley, for independent course study on researching and collecting oral histories of older people who have been community leaders.
"We not only want the young people to learn from the elders, but have the elders learn from the young," Mrs. Cosby said. 
At a gala at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington last spring, Mrs. Cosby and Ms. Poussaint gathered student fellows and potential oral history subjects to watch the videotaped interview of Dr. Height.
Among those in the audience from Washington were Doris Thomas, 77, a poet and founder of a theater company; William E. Bolden, 76, a World War II veteran, bricklayer and cabdriver; and Pauline Johnson Jones, 93, who has worked actively to promote and preserve the history of her church, St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church in Washington.
"Renee and I are in our 50's, the middle group, and we're bringing these two generations together," said Mrs. Cosby, who is 58. "We want young people to look beyond the stereotypes about African-American elders, that they're disempowered people.
Speaking of the prevailing societal images, Mrs. Cosby said: "The only elders that are shown as powerful people are white male elders. They're on our dollar bills, and we see them in positions of economic and decision-making power. Oral histories are a way to get to the truth. And the truth is, the Constitution wouldn't be what it is, were it not for the contributions of these elders."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 9, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the National Visionary Leadership Project, an oral history archive for distinguished African-Americans, misspelled the surname of the centenarian sisters depicted in the 1995 Broadway play "Having Our Say," which was presented in the style of oral history. They were Sadie and Bessie Delany, not Delaney. The article also referred erroneously to precedents for the archive. A similar project indeed exists -- the National Video Oral History Archives, established in Chicago in 1999.

HEADLINE: All the President's Enrons 

BYLINE:  By FRANK RICH; E-mail: frankrich@nytimes.com

 BODY:
George W. Bush is so peeved about corporate America's "wrongdoers" -- not to be confused with "evildoers" -- that last week he spoke out about them four times in four days. By the time he took a breather, the markets had hit their worst half-year finish since 1970, the Nasdaq was at a five-year low, the dollar was on the skids and, despite much evidence to the contrary, a majority of Americans had told CNN/USA Today pollsters that the country was in a recession.
 On Tuesday the president returns to the subject in a full-dress speech on Wall Street. Maybe it's time to try pinning the whole mess on Ann Richards again. 
 Mr. Bush keeps saying all the right things. He is "deeply concerned." He will "hold people accountable." But words, like stocks, lose value when nothing backs them up. It is now more than six months since the president promised "a lot of government inquiry into Enron." Since then, Playboy has done a better job of exposing the women of Enron than the Bush administration has done at exposing its men. Just as the Justice Department rounded up some 1,000 alleged Sept. 11 suspects and failed to indict a single one of them for terrorist activity, so it has made a big show of its shaky Andersen conviction while failing to indict a single Enron executive or individual Andersen accountant. (Not that all the law-enforcement news is downbeat: last month John Ashcroft's minions held a press conference to boast that a 13-month investigation had led to the arrest of 12 prostitutes in New Orleans.)
The sight of a corporate crook being led away in handcuffs, Giuliani-style, would do far more to restore confidence in Wall Street than any more presidential blather. Mr. Bush says that only "a few bad actors" are at fault. Why is the administration so lax about bringing them to justice? 
That may have something to do with who those "few bad actors" are. Speaking on ABC's "This Week," Richard Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, tossed out a range of 1 to 15 as the rough count of corporate culprits, "in comparison to more than 10,000 publicly traded corporations." The fact remains that so far at least five members of that theoretically tiny club have direct ties to the Bush administration: Enron, Halliburton, Andersen, KMPG and Merrill Lynch -- the last three all former clients of the president's choice as Wall Street's top cop, the S.E.C. chairman Harvey Pitt. Five for 15: Mr. Bush could have used a batting average that high when he ran the Texas Rangers. 
Despite this record, there has been only balking, not housecleaning, at the White House. Thomas White, who was vice chairman of Enron Energy Services when it allegedly hid $500 million in losses and manipulated the California energy crisis, is still secretary of the Army, despite having been cited by the Senate Armed Services Committee for violating his signed ethics agreement. (Even worse, Mr. White has threatened to bring to the Army his "understanding of best business practices.") The record of Enron contacts by him and countless other administration officials remains incomplete and in constant revision. What information does dribble out often emanates from the White House counsel, Alberto Gonzales, who himself had an attorney-client relationship with Enron while a partner at Vinson & Elkins in Houston. 
Perhaps it's Mr. Gonzales who, as the administration's chief ethics maven, advised the White House this week on how to handle the 1991 S.E.C. report showing that Mr. Bush had filed disclosures of his stock trades in Harken Energy, where he was a director, as much as eight months late. The ethical call? Blame Harken's lawyers. A presidential spokesman assured us as well that this infraction amounted to nothing more than driving 60 in a 55-mile-per-hour zone. That will surely bring good cheer to those Harken shareholders who were left holding the stock that Mr. Bush sold, with no insider's knowledge, of course, just before it tanked. 
WorldCom is a political boon to the president because it allows him to moralize about epic-scale crime without mentioning Enron, Halliburton or Harken. But the Enron bomb hasn't been defused. Its next detonation may come the day someone outside the administration unearths the as-yet mostly secret names of those buddies of Enron executives who were let into the hundreds of side partnerships that overnight yielded multimillion-dollar plunder on nominal stakes (with ordinary stockholders left paying the bill). "Not in memory has a single major company grown so big in tandem with a presidential dynasty and a corrupted political system," wrote the Republican political analyst Kevin Phillips in The Los Angeles Times five months ago, tracing Bush family favor-swapping with Enron back to 1988 and likening Enron's potential damage to that of the Harding administration's Teapot Dome scandals. "The question now is whether what went up together will come down together." 
It's a question only Mr. Bush can answer. He can give the oil cronies within his administration an ethical pass, much as Harding did. He can keep trying to finesse the Wall Street crisis with rhetorical panaceas as empty as his father's "Message: I care" response to his own economic storm. Or he can fulfill a campaign promise and become a reformer with results, a Teddy Roosevelt who cleans up capitalism to make it stronger. 
No flowery speeches are required to describe the reforms needed now, from fully independent policing of accounting firms to the complete prohibition of conflicts of interest that encourage both accountants and stockbrokers to cut corners. "No off-balance-sheet or offshore entities, no shell corporations, no sham transactions," adds Robert Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, who is pursuing Enron more aggressively than the administration is. Arthur Levitt, the former S.E.C. chairman, urges legislation that increases the legal liability for investment bankers, lawyers and accountants who aid, abet and also profit from corporate Ponzi schemes. 
The president could get real reform "in a heartbeat," says Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, who went after Merrill Lynch while the Pitt S.E.C. slept. "All he has to do is call Oxley" -- Michael Oxley, who is steering a weak Republican "reform" bill through the House -- "and say this is the bill we're passing instead." But that's about as likely as Martha Stewart discovering a cure for cancer instead of trying to cash in on one. Mr. Bush has already opposed the notion of requiring corporations to count executive stock options as expenses -- a simple fix endorsed by Alan Greenspan and Warren Buffett as an antidote to fictional profits. The Treasury Department, Newsweek reports, is hard at work stifling a bill that would end the offshore shenanigans that allowed Enron (with 800-plus such entities) to evade taxes in four out of five years. 
Even within existing law, the Bush administration's notion of enforcement is the antithesis of T.R.'s: it speaks loudly and carries a small stick. On Wednesday a judge threw out an S.E.C. action against the accounting firm Ernst & Young because the S.E.C. could not muster the quorum of conflict-free commissioners required by law to bring its case; both Mr. Pitt and another Bush S.E.C. appointee had previously worked for Ernst & Young. Mr. Pitt's conflicts also include meeting privately with Xerox and KPMG executives while their companies are under investigation by his agency. "It's like the mob's consigliere running the F.B.I," in the words of Marshall Wittmann, a T.R.-minded conservative Republican at the Hudson Institute. 
As Mr. Bush blames others for his Harken mishaps, so Mr. Pitt's new shtick is to hide behind Bill Clinton, telling Matt Lauer, "this is, unfortunately, a mess that I inherited from the prior administration." But it was Mr. Pitt who invited the likes of WorldCom to play fast and loose by implying last fall that no one need fear the "kinder and gentler" S.E.C. he would install in place of Mr. Levitt's, which initiated the Xerox and Rite Aid cases that Mr. Pitt would now like to take credit for. 
It's not that Democrats are clean. When Al Gore blasted Mr. Pitt last weekend for having led the accounting industry's drive "to open up loopholes" in the 1990's, he could have been describing his own ticket mate, Joe Lieberman, who was second to none in doing the accounting industry's bidding. But the Democrats don't have the power to undo the damage anyway. It is Mr. Bush who is C.E.O. If he doesn't bring zero tolerance of corporate cheating to his own White House, it's hard to imagine Americans rushing back into the market trusting that his administration will enforce it anywhere else.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 719 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks 

BYLINE:  By Scott Veale

 BODY:
 A COLD CASE, by Philip Gourevitch. (Picador USA, $11.) Nearly three decades after an unsolved double murder stemming from an argument in midtown Manhattan, an appealingly straight-arrow investigator tracks down the culprit, a hot-tempered veteran of the mean streets of Hell's Kitchen. Gourevitch's nonfiction account is "a sort of moral fable, in which the avenger nabs the killer," Luc Sante said in the Book Review last year.

SKIRTS AND SLACKS: Poems, by W. S. Di Piero. (Knopf, $15.) The author mines ordinary life in these poems, many of which explore feelings of loss and the ways the past consumes the present, whether in Di Piero's personal relationships or in his memories of the gritty South Philadelphia neighborhood of his youth. "With language that's as simple as it is musical, Di Piero sets dazzling moments amid plainsong," Albert Mobilio wrote here in 2001.

INDIA UNBOUND, by Gurcharan Das. (Anchor, $15.) Part memoir, part history and part management bible, this account by a former chief executive of Procter & Gamble focuses on the nation's economic development since independence, in particular how "a rich country became poor and will be rich again." "Something tremendous is happening in India, and Das, with his keen eye and often elegant prose, has his finger firmly on the pulse of the transformation," Akash Kapur wrote here last year.

THE ABOMINATION, by Paul Golding. (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) Set in contemporary gay London, this angrily intelligent first novel about a handsome narcissist peels away the protective surface of its bitter yet sympathetic antihero, exposing the ways in which a child's innocence can be corrupted by the predations of adults. Last year our reviewer, Louis Bayard, praised the writing as "at once highly wrought and exquisitely violent -- an entire garden, grown from scar tissue and still-twitching nerves."

SELECTED LETTERS OF DASHIELL HAMMETT: 1921-1960. Edited by Richard Layman with Julie M. Rivett. (Counterpoint, $25.) This collection, edited by Hammett's biographer and his granddaughter, isn't likely to solve many puzzles about the great noir writer, McCarthy opponent and paramour of Lillian Hellman. The mystery of the Thin Man "keeps growing," David Thomson wrote here in 2001, "but the emerging portrait is more than ever a hero for sour times: a laconic gentleman, brave and tough and honest."

THE CHRONOLITHS, by Robert Charles Wilson. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $6.99.) In the latest novel by an acclaimed science-fiction writer, an American journalist in Thailand witnesses the mysterious arrival of a series of colossal monuments from the future. "Wilson deftly interweaves a plausible time-travel thriller with the tender tale of a likable but immature loser who responds to adversity by growing up," Gerald Jonas said here last year.

ZIGZAGGING DOWN A WILD TRAIL: Stories, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Modern Library, $11.95.) The author's new collection of miniature reports from the sprawling mid-South feature characters who feel stung by their limitations. Even as they watch too much TV, drink too much beer and make bad choices in love, they sense both the opportunities and dangers of the wider world. "Mason works with a fixed set of materials and pours her ambition into feats of craftsmanship," Walter Kirn wrote in these pages in 2001.

DEVICES AND DESIRES: A History of Contraceptives in America, by Andrea Tone. (Hill & Wang, $15.) A history professor recounts the development of the American contraceptive industry, which dates to the 1800's, and the persistent attempts to suppress it through moral condemnation and intimidation of manufacturers. Last year our reviewer, Daniel J. Kevles, called this a "marvelously eye-opening book" with "fascinating vignettes of small-time birth control entrepreneurs."

THE LOVE-ARTIST, by Jane Alison. (Picador USA, $13.) Why was the Roman poet Ovid exiled at the height of his glory? The answer, according to this novel, has to do with a destructive entanglement among the poet, an exotic, nymphlike alchemist (and eventual inspiration for "Medea") and the emperor's vengeful granddaughter. The result is "a swirling parable that touches on the opposed sorceries of art and magic, on tyranny and rebellion, and on the struggle of male and female," Richard Eder wrote here last year. Scott Veale
