HEADLINE: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Reaction to Fires Hurts Colorado Tourism

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER 

 BODY:
THE physical damage of fires plaguing Colorado since March has been bad enough, with the size of one blaze last month at about 140,000 acres, a record for the state. Now, officials are beginning to assess the economic damage, a large component of which is tourism and recreation.
 While California has suffered the largest number of large wildfires this year, more than 125, its governor did not alight from a helicopter after a tour of fires and pronounce that all of his state was burning, as Colorado's Bill Owens did last month. 
 It was a hyperbolic assessment, inspired by the nine wildfires burning at the same time. But it had a dramatic effect. Ever since, the state tourism industry has struggled to get out the word that most of Colorado -- a major warm-weather state for fishing, hiking and dude ranch vacations -- is and has been a safe distance from fire. 
"That first week, the calls were relentless," said Elizabeth Youngquist, a spokeswoman for the Colorado Springs Convention and Visitors Bureau. "People were asking us if, when they got to our borders, would they be turned away?" Jill Strunk, a Denver Metro Convention and Visitors Bureau spokeswoman, said, "We must have gotten 500 calls from people asking if the fires were bearing down on Denver."
Colorado has endured fewer than two dozen large wildfires this year, a fifth of the number in California. Yet the perception of their impact has exacerbated the actual damage. In many parts of Colorado near the worst of the fires -- and even at a distance -- tourism officials say business is off and did not have to be. In Colorado Springs, for example, Ms. Youngquist said that at the Summit House, a restaurant and souvenir shop on Pikes Peak, a major attraction, sales were up 5 percent for the year through May, then fell 30 percent in June.
Pikes Peak has not been threatened by fire this year, but the worst wildfire in state history, the Hayman, began to the north in the Pike National Forest in June and scorched almost 140,000 acres.
"Most people do not realize how big Colorado is," said Sean Duffy, a spokesman for Governor Owens. "They don't know that Estes Park is not near Denver." Estes Park, more than 50 miles northwest of Denver, was nowhere near the Hayman fire. 
Of all Colorado's fires, the Hayman got the most attention. It was started by a United States Forest Service worker, who goes on trial next month. While the fire never got much closer than 10 miles from Denver's southernmost suburbs, Mayor Wellington E. Webb held a news conference just to get out the word that Denver was open for business.
Randy Myers, owner of the M Lazy C Ranch, a popular dude ranch in Lake George near where the Hayman fire started, used his Web site to assure vacationers his ranch was open. He blasted news coverage, which he said led the public to panic and cancel reservations. "The fire has slowed our business to a trickle," he said, adding that coverage has hurt local ranching, restaurants and other attractions.
Other fires this year have caused similar problems. The Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad, which has run continuously for 120 years, scaled back its schedule by more than two-thirds because of the Missionary Ridge fire in June near Durango, though the fire did not reach the tracks.
"For folks in the East, 130,000 acres can be a whole county," Mr. Duffy said. "Our challenge is to let people know that with 24 million acres in the state, 23.8 million of them are not on fire."
While there has been an unattractive haze hovering around some Colorado cities, including Denver, off and on during the past month, officials said it's not a big concern. "There's probably a greater risk with coming to altitude and getting sick than any risk from forest fire smoke," said Christopher Dann, public information officer for the state pollution control division. He said the Web site apcd.state.co.uk and two phones lines, (303) 758-4848 or (303) 782-0211, are updated twice daily with smoke forecasts.
In northern Arizona, where the Rodeo-Chediski fire, still burning, became that state's largest ever, at well over 400,000 acres, the challenge may be even greater. The Rodeo wiped out a large part of the White Mountains, a favorite escape from the summer heat in Phoenix and home to an Apache tribe of 13,000 that depended on timber mills as well as a casino for its income. The fire destroyed hundreds of homes and businesses and forced the tribe to close the mills and casino. Even businesses that were undamaged are likely to suffer without the attraction of the lush forest. 
In Colorado, the Coal Seam fire in Glenwood Springs last month sent vacationers packing in the middle of the night as the fire flared up, but town officials say they are ready to move forward even if other fires still burn.
"I don't know how long it will take to get back to normal because we've never had a disaster like this before," said Marianne Virgili, executive director of the Glenwood Springs Chamber Resort Association. "We have clean air and blue skies and all of our businesses opened up again in two days, but we have to deal with the public perception of what's going on statewide."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Retelling The Tales Of Vanguard

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
JOHN BOGLE is, in many ways, an American hero. The founder of the Vanguard Group, Mr. Bogle redefined the mutual fund industry, building Vanguard into the country's second-largest fund company, behind Fidelity Investments, with a relentless dedication to low costs and a focus on index investing as the best long-term strategy for individual investors.
 His undergraduate thesis on investment companies, better known as mutual funds, submitted in 1951 at Princeton, deserves inclusion in the Museum of American Financial History, an affiliate of the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. Bogle's first three books on investing deserve a place on the bookshelf of every serious investor, particularly those who run mutual fund companies. 
 There is a compelling history to be written about the founding and evolution of the Vanguard Group. Unfortunately, Mr. Bogle's latest book, "Character Counts: The Creation and Building of the Vanguard Group," is not it.
Instead, "Character Counts" (McGraw-Hill) is a generally uninspiring collection of speeches that Mr. Bogle has delivered since he began his sojourn at Vanguard. Unlike a previous collection of speeches that addressed the ills of the fund industry, these were delivered to employees to commemorate various corporate milestones.
The latest volume provides a serviceable overview of what is to many investors a familiar story. Mr. Bogle got his break when his Princeton thesis, "The Economic Role of the Investment Company," was read by Walter L. Morgan, founder of the Wellington Management Company. He then offered Mr. Bogle a job when he graduated in 1951. 
While Wellington and Mr. Bogle prospered during the postwar boom in the financial markets, the firm and its flagship fund were outpaced by the managers of aggressive equity funds. In 1965, Mr. Morgan made Mr. Bogle, then 35, an executive vice president, his heir apparent and told him to fix Wellington's problems.
Mr. Bogle bought a firm that managed one of those aggressive funds. By the early-1970's, however, a worsening bear market began pulling Wellington's investors toward the exit, and the board fired Mr. Bogle as chief executive of Wellington Management.
Unemployed but undeterred, Mr. Bogle set about remaking the mutual fund industry. First, he started a new company, Vanguard, and then persuaded the directors of the Wellington Fund to make Vanguard responsible for accounting, legal and record-keeping duties. Today, Wellington manages several funds for Vanguard.
Barred by his contract from managing a portfolio or distributing a fund, Mr. Bogle employed what he calls "a touch of disingenuousness." He created the first index mutual fund, which by its strict adherence to mirroring the performance of a stock market index, essentially required no investment manager. By selling shares without a sales charge directly to investors, Mr. Bogle created a low-cost marketing organization that technically was within the boundaries of his contract with Wellington.
The jewel in the crown of Mr. Bogle's achievement was the way he structured Vanguard: as a truly mutual mutual fund company, in which shareholders in the funds owned the management company. As the columnist Jason Zweig would write years later in Money magazine, it was "an act of spectacular altruism."
He christened his new company Vanguard, after Lord Nelson's flagship at the Battle of the Nile. It was a fateful decision, for it anchored the company and its employees -- known around the Valley Forge, Pa., headquarters as "crew members" -- to a lifetime of tortured nautical metaphors.
"Our ship must be staunch and true, well braced and put together, with sailors on their mettle, no less in command for all their reverences in the presence of a power mightier than their own," saith Mr. Bogle in a 1993 speech titled, "When Breezes at Our Back Turn to Headwinds at Our Bow." 
IN other places in "Character Counts," Mr. Bogle displays his modesty: In 1996, at the dedication of a bronze statue of him on the Vanguard campus, he described himself as "a normal -- if flawed -- human being who had just a few good -- if common-sense -- ideas."
Over all, however, such sentiments hardly provide a case study in the challenges of building a company that has bucked the status quo time and again. Some interesting incidents in Vanguard's history are glossed over -- not least Mr. Bogle's battle with a hand-picked crew of directors who, when he turned 70, forced him to accept the mandatory retirement that he instituted but apparently never dreamed would apply to him.
His previous books, "Bogle on Mutual Funds" (McGraw-Hill Professional Publishing, 1993) and "Common Sense on Mutual Funds" (John Wiley & Sons, 1999), provide just about everything an investor needs to know. And "John Bogle on Investing: The First 50 Years" (McGraw-Hill Professional Publishing, 2000), the previous collection of speeches, offers a richer profile of Mr. Bogle as the industry's biggest critic.
"Character Counts," unfortunately, feels like the leftovers from the files of one of investing's great innovators.

HEADLINE: Grown, and Still at Home 

BYLINE:  By PAULA GANZI LICATA 

 BODY:
CHERYL CARUSO says she once declared, "I would rather live in a refrigerator box in Penn Station than move home." But a divorce, a broken engagement, foreclosure on her home, eviction from her apartment and insurmountable debt to the I.R.S., lawyers and creditors changed her mind. In November 1996 she moved back in with her parents, John and Therese Caruso, in Fort Salonga.
 Nearly six years later, she's still there. "No one loves you like your parents, even when you are intolerable," said Ms. Caruso, now 42. 
 Moving back home enabled Ms. Caruso to complete a two-year seminary program --last month she was ordained an interfaith minister at St. John the Divine in New York City. She also was certified recently as a nutritional consultant and is pursuing a Ph.D. in nutrition and working as an office manager and nutritional consultant for a rehabilitation center in Manhasset. 
The living arrangement has also had some emotional benefits. "My Dad and I had some things to work through," Ms. Caruso said. "Moving home gave us an opportunity to heal wounds of the past."
John Caruso is 72. "There are no negative impacts to us financially, to our lifestyle or to family dynamics," he said. "In fact we are very comfortable with Cheryl at home."
Of course there are drawbacks. Cheryl Caruso scoffed at the inevitable question. "What social life?" she said. "Dating is impossible when you live with your parents. Even at 42, I'm still their little girl." 
The situation is much the same for Matthew Murphy, 30, who moved back into his parents' Wantagh home in December 2001. "I live with Mother Theresa and Father Mulcahy, so there are no girls in my room," he said.
His mother, Donna Murphy, 67, defended her position. "They are the same ground rules that were in place before he left home: no girls sleeping upstairs," she said.
Matthew Murphy returned to his boyhood bedroom to pay off debt and save for his dream house in Long Beach by living rent-free. But money does change hands. "The contractual verbal agreement was, 'You're going to pitch in. You pay the cable bill,' " Mr. Murphy said.
According to the Census Bureau, almost 300,000 children over 18 in Nassau and Suffolk counties were living in the home of one or both of their parents in 2000. More current estimates that might reflect recent economic trends have not been tallied. But anecdotal reports suggest the statistics are edging upward. Many adult children who went home temporarily in the 90's have been stranded there by the economic downturn of the new millennium, while others were forced to move home only after they were hit by some combination of layoffs, bursting dot-com bubble, sliding stock market, rising real estate costs and shrinking stock of low- and middle-income housing.
"The trend to move back with parents seems to be increasing, primarily due to the financial difficulties of living on one's own," said Robert H. Phillips, a psychologist with a practice in Hicksville. 
Long Island's unemployment rate has risen from a December 2000 low of 2.5 percent, but it remains comparatively low, 3.8 percent for both counties in April compared with 6 percent for the country and 7.7 percent for New York City.
But Irwin Kellner, an economics professor at Hofstra University, noted that the cost of living on Long Island is very high. "Long Island is perhaps the second most expensive area to live in, the first being New York City," he said. "When an adult child has financial difficulties in an area like Long Island where it's so expensive to live, that adult child is more likely to go back to his or her parents, as would not be the case where the cost of living is cheaper."
"Housing is extremely expensive," Dr. Kellner said. "And we have the sales tax on top of property tax, so taxes and housing make the cost of living very high. I think that's why we see adult children moving back to the nest whenever they have financial difficulties."
Watching her son struggle to make it on his own as a salesman for a Manhattan company that provides emergency power systems, Donna Murphy worries about the next generation's ability to become homeowners.
But Matthew Murphy is hopeful. "I'm starting to show a little bit of savings," said Mr. Murphy, who lived with a roommate in Bayside, Queens, before moving back home in December. But he doesn't figure he'll be back on his own anytime soon. "At a minimum, I'll stay here for two years," he said.
Asked about her son's plans, Mrs. Murphy said, "I have no objection to that if in the future he can afford it." 
Joseph Mottola, chief executive of the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island, said, "Moving back to the family homestead sometimes is the only option in order to accumulate funds." Mr. Mottola said that in May the median sale price of a house in Suffolk County was $268,000, and in Nassau it was $350,000. For May 2001, the figures were $217,500 for Suffolk and $285,000 for Nassau.
This trend also translates into higher rents and fewer rental units, as landlords take rentals off the market and sell them to cash in on rising real estate values. "The problem is the law of supply and demand," Mr. Mottola said. "As long as there are more buyers than sellers, house prices will go up." 
High rents have kept Lynda Stratton and daughter, Chelsea Stratton, 10, living at Lynda's parents' home in Massapequa, according to her mother, Virginia Lehman. But Lynda, who is now 43 and has been living with her parents eight years, demurred. She said she returned to her childhood home to give Chelsea the benefits of family life.
"I was in the Navy in San Diego, got married to a Navy man, things didn't work out," said Ms. Stratton, now a service manager for C&S Building Services, an air conditioning company in Plainview. Referring to her finances, she added, "I could have moved out a while ago." 
Her mother disagreed. "Let's face it, on Long Island you have to make at least $1,000 a week to have an apartment," Mrs. Lehman said. "And Lynda does not earn anywhere near that. She couldn't live on her own in terms of finances."
Ms. Stratton pays monthly rent of $950 to her parents. She and Chelsea live upstairs in the split colonial. In addition to financial arrangements, there are emotional and social issues to address. "If I bring male friends home, my parents are there to question and make sure he's not staying," Ms. Stratton said. "Yes, lifestyle has changed a little bit, but in the long run it's good."
Mike and Virginia Lehman said they are happy to help their daughter and granddaughter, but don't know how much longer they can afford it. 
"We have a big house," Mrs. Lehman said. "I'm 68, my husband's going to be 70. We already have a gardener, but there are still things we have to take care of and it would be a heck of a lot easier if we had a condo." Recently they looked at condominiums in Florida, but Mrs. Lehman said the couple was reluctant to leave their daughter and granddaughter on their own.
"It depends on my daughter," Mrs. Lehman said. "She's got to be able to stand on her own two feet. How long will we be able to take care of this house? Maybe we won't be able to afford the gardener after awhile. I'm retired now. The money has gotten tight. We still have our heads above water, but don't make any waves. And the way taxes are going up on the Island, it's difficult."
Cheryl Caruso has been a straw in the economic wind. "The economy has been a great dictator of my actions in the past few years," she said. "Just about the time I had saved enough for a down payment on a co-op, the market turned, hence prices soared as my accounts went south." 
She said she remains confident that sooner or later she'll be in her own home. "Until then," she said, ' "What's for dinner, Mom?' "

HEADLINE: ART; 
Behind Each Stroke, The Art of Eloquence

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
DAVID DUNLOP'S stock of aphorisms, ideas and lore about art is roughly equal to the supplies that he takes with him on a trip to paint landscapes. 
 He has a fat bundle of brushes that he keeps in a plastic bag and carries in a suitcase with wheels. Such other essentials as a board divided into squares for six small paintings are carried under his arms, and the many pockets of his fisherman's vest hold other handy tools. 
 In the late afternoon on a day in which rain alternated with bright sunlight, Mr. Dunlop chose a spot on the Mianus River in Stamford to demonstrate how a veteran plein-air painter proceeds. He situated himself with a view of the river making a distinct bend, a meander. 
"Meander comes from the Meander River in Turkey, which snakes in a tantalizing way," he said. "Our landscape conventions are very old. They go back to ancient times: the Garden of Eden, the myth of Osiris, Arcadia. Our ideas of color recession and design go back to Plato. People don't know they're using these ideas but they're embedded constructs that are always covertly present."
Mr. Dunlop, who is 51 and has lived in Norwalk since 1979, said he paints every day. He came to painting in a roundabout way, after studying philosophy and religion. He was born in St. Louis within, he says, easy biking distance of the art museum.
He has taught at the Silvermine School of Art in New Canaan since 1986. Beginning this month, he is teaching an eight-week summer course titled "How to Paint a Really Good Landscape." 
"The students will explore a variety of locations from the seashore to old farms," he said. "Exploration keeps you fresh, but I tell them that when they first get to a site to relax and listen to the muses. I listen to the muses all day every day. For me mixing paint is relaxing." 
He laid out squiggles of transparent oil paint on his palette, only the primaries. There was to be no green at all that day -- despite what one might assume about an outdoor painting session.
"I tell my students not to get caught up in issues of resemblance," he said. "I quote the art philosopher Ernst H. Gombrich: 'It's a poem, not a police report.' Also there are no nouns here, no rocks, no trees. I'm not painting language. My intention is to seduce the viewer, like the sirens."
Before he began his first oil sketch, Mr. Dunlop put on a pair of sheer plastic surgical-style gloves. He had reasons for this: some paints are toxic, and the gloves reduce inhibition about absorbing paint into his skin. Also, he can have clean hands for holding the edges of a newly painted work without smudging it.
"You know that it's only been since the late 19th century that the hand has been wedded to the brush," he said. "Painters have always protected themselves. They used a handkerchief, or a sleeve."
He spent the entire painting session, about an hour and a half, on his knees against an outcropping with a shallow slant. 
Only a comment late in the session -- "I should have brought my kneepads" -- revealed that he was in a difficult position.
But for Mr. Dunlop, the soreness was worth it because he seeks out different vantage points. 
"I painted in the middle of this river not that long ago, but then the water wasn't as deep as it is now," he said. "I'd like to paint from a rock in the river. It would probably be too dangerous. I usually don't realize that I'm in a dangerous situation until my wife or somebody tells me that I am. Then there's the story that's told about Corot in Rome in the 1820's. He would simply turn his chair in a different direction every two weeks."
The view in front of him included the Mianus making a turn, but what especially caught the eye was a triangular rock close to the left bank that looked as if it were pointing at the middle of the river.
"It's very directional," he said. "It's like a 19th-century sign of a hand with a finger pointing telling you to buy something." 
A fat Sumi brush was recruited to make the first oil sketch in the first of the squares. It was remarkable that the same brush could put in not only dark colors but also a light blue. "Different parts of the brush hold different colors," Mr. Dunlop said.
The seemingly implausible dark purplish color that was used for the foliage turned out to describe the sensation of an afternoon full of shadow. 
The second square on Mr. Dunlop's board held a sheet of gold leaf.
"It kicks back more light," he said. "I learned the recipe from Cennini's 'The Craftsman's Handbook,' written in the late 14th century. I always make sure to keep the sunlight off my paintings when I work. It washes out the color."
He knew rain was on the way but wanted to make a watercolor sketch in the manner of Turner. "I'm referring to those watercolors that are rich with atmosphere and suggest only a tone and subject for later elaboration," he said. "They're so pensive."
It started to rain and Mr. Dunlop packed up quickly. If there was a keeper from this afternoon's session, it would become a full-fledged work in his studio.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Redrawing Class Lines And Redefining Jobs

BYLINE:  By By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
IN pursuit of the American dream, one truck driver joins the union in the belief that collective bargaining will give him the opportunity to slice himself a bigger piece of the pie. Another driver scrimps and saves to buy his own truck. Then he buys another and hires a driver himself, in the belief that business ownership will lead to individual prosperity.
 The "unionism vs. entrepreneurship" debate recurred several times, with slight variations, during a conference called "How Class Works," held over four days last month at the State University at Stony Brook. The point was that the issue of class is rarely discussed in America these days but nevertheless shapes decisions people make every day as workers, professionals or business owners, as well as in their roles as voters, neighbors, shoppers and family members. 
 The conference was the first major effort by the 40 faculty and staff members at Stony Brook who call themselves the Group for the Study of Working Class Life.
The galvanizing force behind the group and the conference itself is a bearded and graying economics professor, Michael Zweig, a self-described radical labor economist whose organizing experience goes back to the 1960's and the formation of the Students for a Democratic Society chapter at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor.
"When you look at economic issues, such as the income differential between workers and their bosses, you find tremendous inequality in America today, and inequality is rising," Professor Zweig said. "The questions involved are questions of class, even though people get uneasy when you mention the word. Class has become something that isn't discussed openly in our society. It's time we stopped playing with words and began dealing with these issues openly."
The conference, in fact, borrowed prodigiously from the language, mores and missions of the Left, Old and New, in asserting the imperative of class consciousness.
"To me, class is a question of power, rather than income or lifestyle," Professor Zweig said. "People in the working class go to work and don't have much control over what they do. They are given a job, and they do it. They don't supervise anyone. Someone supervises them and controls the pace of their work as well as the content of their work."
Working-class jobs, especially those that are unionized, often pay better than middle-class professions but provide less autonomy, suggesting erroneously, in his view, that the worker has achieved middle-class status. "A sanitation worker in a big city can take home $100,000 a year, but he's still working class," Professor Zweig said.
Addressing about 200 people, most of them academics but with a smattering of labor representatives and people associated with causes they described as progressive, Professor Zweig and other speakers made the case that blurring the distinction between middle class and working class benefited primarily the capitalist class, which stood to gain the most from their labors.
The conference brought in a number of speakers with national or international reputations, including Zwelinzima Vavi, an official with the Congress of South African Trade Unions, and Stanley Aronowitz, a City University sociology professor, the author of a number of books on class issues and the Green Party's candidate for governor.
But mostly, it was Professor Zweig's moment in the sun, or at least in the spotlight of the student center auditorium. He took the opportunity to espouse the premise of his latest book, "The Working Class Majority: America's Best Kept Secret," (Cornell University Press, 2000): that the working class's influence has been minimized by the blurring of its identity.
"If you look at where you fit on a power grid, you see that most people work on behalf of the capitalist class," he said. "The capitalists own the big companies, which make the big profits."
"Just over one-third of the country is middle class," he said. "These are professionals like doctors, teachers and airline pilots. The rest are working class. And the working class makes up about 62 percent of the population. In other words, most people are working class, but think they're middle class. It's time we addressed this issue honestly if were going to make progress on behalf of the working class."
Picking up on the theme, Fred Rose, a labor organizer and author from Springfield, Mass., defined the working-class experience as being externally controlled, in contrast to the middle class, which expects to determine its own pace at work.
"Working-class people are familiar with punching a timecard and dealing with the mechanization of their work," he said. "In a working-class community, you're socialized to do this kind of work the rest of your life. You're taught to follow the rules."
In contrast, the middle class values self-determination and self-expression. "In the middle class, standing on an assembly line is something we haven't been socialized for," he said. "Growing up, I was taught to develop my own judgment, find a career that would be meaningful and above all, to think for myself. Working-class kids experience authority as a restrictive force."
Arnold Wishnia, a chemistry professor at Stony Brook who was in the audience, took issue with Mr. Rose.
"What you're saying is a caricature at best and reductionist in the extreme," Professor Wishnia said. "Why don't you read Mike Zweig's book?"
Mr. Rose did not respond.
The distinctions between worker, professional, manager or owner eluded easy definition, but it was not for lack of effort.
"The worker who starts a business of his own becomes middle class, but still identifies in a lot of ways with the workers he hires, more so than with the true capitalists who own the big companies," Professor Zweig said. "He may identify with the workers, but that doesn't mean he's going to welcome a union to his plant."
Harry T. Cason, a political science professor at the College of Staten Island, said it was important to distinguish between the capitalists, who own the means of production, and the management class, who do not. "The capitalist class sets the context for all decisions," he said. "That's the real power."
David Sprintzen, one of the founders of the Long Island Progressive Coalition and a philosophy professor at the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University, said he thought the ideas raised during the conference deserved further exploration.
"I find it extremely strange that people give up their individual freedom when they go to work every day," Professor Sprintzen said. "Democracy seems to stop at the door of the workplace. At the same time, people don't think about this and aren't able to articulate their feelings about what's really oppression, what's actually a form of second-class citizenship."
Professor Sprintzen said that while the speakers raised important issues, the conference seemed more geared to academics nationally than to workers, managers or business owners locally. 
"The notion of class consciousness on Long Island seems like a contradiction in terms," he said. "After the conference I sent Mike an e-mail suggesting we work together on doing something specifically for Long Island. I haven't heard back from him yet."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Some of the 200 people, above, who gathered at Stony Brook for a conference called "How Class Works," organized by Michael Zweig, left, an economics professor there. (Photographs by Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Incorporation Fails, but Debate Continues 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

DATELINE: YAPHANK 

 BODY:
THEY are still not amused in Yaphank by a cartoon published in The New Yorker 20 years ago that comically suggested that this hamlet in the Town of Brookhaven with the hayseed name wasn't worth a second look.
 The cartoon showed an off-ramp sign that advised: "Exit 66, Yaphank. If You Have Already Been to Yaphank, Disregard This Exit." 
 "We are fiercely proud of our little community," said Herbert W. Davis, the chairman of the board of fire commissioners for the Yaphank Fire District, who said he failed to see what was so funny. 
Community pride in Yaphank is no laughing matter, but it apparently has its limits. Last month, residents rejected by nine votes a proposal to become an incorporated village.
In a solid turnout, 481 of about 900 eligible voters cast ballots at the one and only polling place, inside the firehouse, the hamlet's largest building. The tally was 245 to 236 against becoming a village.
The result, now being challenged in the courts, puzzled supporters who said residents had missed a golden opportunity to reap cash from two giant developments that were coming anyway to sites within the proposed 2.75-square-mile village boundaries.
One is a 580-megawatt electric generating station, a $500 million project proposed by American National Power on 28 wooded acres. Its 120-foot stacks would be visible from Exit 66 north of the Long Island Expressway. The company is awaiting final state approval to proceed.
The other project is a $200 million regional shopping mall that a developer, Wilbur Breslin, has planned for several years on a 100-acre former woodland along the William Floyd Parkway. Building has yet to begin.
Supporters of incorporation, led by the Yaphank Taxpayers and Civic Association, said becoming a village would not only help retain a greater share of the economic benefits from these behemoths but would also give residents control over future zoning and planning and end the dominance of a remote and often unresponsive Town government.
"We just felt the town has never really reached out to us," said Nanette Essel, the co-president of the taxpayers group. "And for the village, these would be two very substantial revenue sources."
Mr. Davis and others who voted against incorporation disagreed.
"No matter how you slice it, it would have increased taxes," said Mr. Davis, a lifelong resident and a former Suffolk County legislator. "Yaphank is not ready for incorporation because it doesn't have the assessed value. This would just be another layer of government on people's backs."
Mr. Davis said a proposed budget for the village circulated before the vote underestimated expenses. 
Mrs. Essel said a second vote could be held within a year for the same boundaries or sooner if the boundaries were changed. She said support would be stronger when the tax benefits from the plant and the mall were made clearer.
Charges swirled in the wake of the vote. Some grumbled that many in the 100-member fire department had opposed the village because it would have taken away power from the fire district, currently the only taxing entity in Yaphank. Others said the defeat turned back a power grab by the taxpayers association.
A suit backed by the taxpayers group filed in State Supreme Court in Suffolk County this month charged irregularities at the polling place. It said that voters had to run a gantlet of incorporation opponents to get to the voting machine and that opponents electioneered too close to the poll. "Some people felt intimidated," Mrs. Essel said.
The Town of Brookhaven, meantime, expressed dismay that the taxpayers group had withdrawn its opposition to the power plant. The town opposed the Exit 66 site and wanted the site of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, which is now defunct, considered as an alternative. It spent more than $200,000 opposing the Yaphank site before a state board.
"We were disturbed to learn that while the town was fighting to protect the residents of Yaphank, the Taxpayers and Civic Association had already cut a deal," said George Hoffman, the chief of staff to town supervisor John J. LaValle.
The deal reportedly entailed a $1 million payment by the company to an environmental and historic preservation fund set up by the association.
Mrs. Essel and the plant project manager, Guy Marchmont, would not comment on the amount. Mrs. Essel said her group had reached an understanding with American National Power that included company pledges on noise abatement, landscaping and environmental protection. She said the group dropped its opposition and sought concessions only after learning from a lawyer retained by the town that the state was going to approve the plant.

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
An Iranian Musical Spectacle That Draws Audiences In

BYLINE:  By RON JENKINS; Ron Jenkins, author of "Dario Fo and Franca Rame: Artful Laughter," is the translator and director of Fo's "Peasants' Bible" which opens next month at the 7 Stages Theater in Atlanta.

 BODY:
IN 1969 a young Iranian actor named Mohammad Ghaffari took the British director Peter Brook to the village of Neyshabur in northeastern Iran to watch a performance of "Ta'ziyeh," an indigenous form of Persian music-theater. Part ritual, part spectacle, "Ta'ziyeh" is presented once a year to tell the story of the Battle of Kerbala, in which Muhammad's grandson, Hussein, and his followers were killed in A.D. 680.
 Mr. Ghaffari, who had been fascinated by "Ta'ziyeh" since childhood, took great pleasure in Mr. Brook's astonishment as they watched actors re-enact the massacres, betrayals and decapitations that led to the martyrdom of Hussein, one of the most sacred events in the history of the Shiite Muslim religion. As they still do throughout Iran, audiences responded with howls of grief. 
 Encouraged by Mr. Brook's enthusiastic response, Mr. Ghaffari, who is 58 and lives in New York, has devoted much of the last 33 years to preserving the genre, searching out the best "Ta'ziyeh" performers in Iran and staging their work at international festivals. Now, from July 12 to July 21, he will direct a three-play cycle of "Ta'ziyeh" with a cast of 18 actors, four camels, four horses and six sheep in a tent in Damrosch Park as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. 
Although "Ta'ziyeh" is not well known in America, many theater scholars and artists consider it one of the world's great theatrical art forms. In a 1979 interview in Parabola magazine, Mr. Brook remembered his visit to Iran 10 years earlier: "I saw in a remote Iranian village one of the strongest things I have seen in the theater: a group of 400 villagers, the entire population of the place, sitting under a tree and passing from roars of laughter to outright sobbing as they saw Hussein in danger of being killed, and then fooling his enemies and then being martyred. And when he was martyred, the theater became a truth: there was no difference between past and present. An event that was told as remembered in history 1,300 years ago, actually became a reality in that moment." 
The literal meaning of "Ta'ziyeh" in Arabic is "mourning," and Mr. Brook is only one Western director who has been impressed by the form's ability to involve the audience in the actions onstage. The Polish directors Tadeusz Kantor and Jerzy Grotowski and the Romanian director Andrei Serban were also influenced in different ways, according to Mr. Ghaffari, who has acted in several plays directed by Mr. Serban and was an assistant to Grotowski when he visited Columbia University in the 80's.
"Kantor saw 'Ta'ziyeh' when his company performed at the Shiraz festival in Iran," Mr. Ghaffari said, "and he liked how the director of the show would adjust the actors and the props during the performance. I don't do that, but it was one of the things that made the audience feel closer to what was happening."
Peter Chelkowski, a professor of Middle Eastern Studies at New York University and the author of books on "Ta'ziyeh" and Iranian culture, said "Ta'ziyeh" accomplishes on a large scale the level of audience participation that Grotowski could achieve only in small groups. "In 'Ta'ziyeh,' there is no division between the spectators and the actors," Mr. Chelkowski said. "The audience members become participants in the performance. Grotowski tried to do the same thing by limiting the number of audience members and directing them what to do, but in 'Ta'ziyeh' it is spontaneous."
At a performance in Iran, the audience is responding to more than a theatrical experience. 
"It is also a ritual," Mr. Chelkowski said. "The whole purpose of seeing rituals is to remove the factor of time. In other words, what happened 1,300 years ago is happening now. And space disappears as well. The action takes place anywhere that Shiites gather together." Mr. Chelkowski will give a talk on "Ta'ziyeh" at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Tuesday as part of a series of symposiums.
Lincoln Center's staging emulates Iranian tradition. In Iran, "Ta'ziyeh" is performed in courtyards or tents; the actors are encircled by the audience, putting the spectators in the ambiguous position of representing both the enemy and the mourners. Audience members respond in various ways to the action. "Sometimes they sing," Mr. Chelkowski said. "Sometimes they express their disagreements through small skirmishes on the outskirts of the playing area. The action moves out and comes back like a wave in the sea, and suddenly the audience is swept up in that wave."
Mr. Chelkowski remembered a performance in which a wedding was taking place onstage and the men in the audience left with the groom to give him a traditional prenuptial bath. The women, meanwhile, washed the bride's hands and feet in henna, also a traditional wedding ritual. While the audience was celebrating and eating wedding cookies distributed by the actors, a riderless horse entered the stage, signifying the death of the groom's brother and triggering a ritual of mourning in which the audience sang funeral chants with the performers.
But "Ta'ziyeh" is not all grief and ritual. It also has humor. When a foreign soldier arrives onstage, he is usually in a costume that makes him look like Napoleon Bonaparte. "If there is no Napoleon suit," Mr. Ghaffari said, "the actors playing foreigners just wear a golf cap or a leisure suit."
"Ta'ziyeh" has a complicated political history. In the 16th century, the precursor of "Ta'ziyeh," a ritual procession of mourning for Hussein, was patronized by the Safavid Dynasty; it was an expression of patriotic support for the Shiite regime, which was surrounded by two hostile Sunni Islamic states, the Ottoman Turks and the Uzbeks.
During the Iranian revolution of 1978 and 1979, the Ayatollah Khomeini referred repeatedly to the battle of Kerbala, identifying Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi with the seventh-century caliph responsible for Hussein's death. In "Ta'ziyeh" performances, "the mournful groan 'Hussein is dead' changed in the same breath to an angry shout, 'Down with the Shah!' " Mr. Chelkowski and Hamid Dabashi wrote in their 1999 book, "Staging the Revolution."
Nigel Redden, director of the Lincoln Center Festival, said that he had decided to invite the Iranians to New York before the terrorist attacks of last fall and that his reasons had nothing to do with politics. But, he acknowledged, "Sept. 11 has changed many things for many people."
Mr. Redden hopes the performance will give New Yorkers an opportunity to gain insight into an unfamiliar culture. "Here is a story that has thousands of people weeping on the other side of the world and I had never heard of it," he said. "This is an indication of how provincial education can be in this country."
Getting the Iranian performers into the United States was not easy. The State Department refused to grant visas to 10 of the 28 performers; Mr. Redden even spent a day in Washington, trying to convince officials to reverse their decision. The denials had nothing to do with terrorism, State Department officials and Mr. Redden said. The immigration authorities were afraid the performers would try to stay in America for economic reasons. To accommodate the reduced cast, Mr. Ghaffari was forced to change the repertory of plays.
It's unlikely that audiences at Lincoln Center will respond as the audiences in Iran do. Mr. Ghaffari and his daughter, Rabeah Ghaffari, a 30-year-old filmmaker, recorded a performance in Iran a few months ago during the holy month of Muharram. Their documentary includes devastating scenes in which hundreds of women sob so violently that the dark chadors covering their bodies shiver communally, as if sadness had swept across the audience like a dark shadow.
Yet Western audiences have had strong, if different, emotional reactions to the plays as well. Two years ago, when Mr. Ghaffari staged a performance at the Festival d'Automne in Paris, audiences sobbed at the finale of "Imam Hussein," which will also be staged in New York. In the scene, an actor in a lion's costume grieves over the dead after the last battle. As the lion visits each corpse it throws dirt and chaff over its head, a traditional sign of mourning in Iran. 
In the aftermath of Sept. 11, New Yorkers will undoubtedly bring their own associations to this scene of carnage. Some may be moved by the lion's compassion, viewing it as an act of consolation. Mr. Ghaffari believes the scene transcends the particulars of culture. "It is a powerful statement," he says, "against war in all its forms."

HEADLINE: In Camden, On the Brink Of a Beginning 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
THE third time's the charm. 
 At least that's what Melvin Primas is hoping as he sits poised to take on what may be his most powerful role yet in shaping the city where he grew up. 
 One could argue that Mr. Primas has already held the top two posts here -- City Council president and mayor. But the newly created position of chief operating officer -- for which he is the leading and perhaps only contender despite the misgivings of some -- comes free of obligation to the electorate, and with a huge pot of state money. 
Even before the state's legislators and the governor could agree to turn over $175 million to help resurrect Camden -- New Jersey's poorest city and the second-poorest city in the United States -- it was clear to most of them that the city's elected officials were not up to the job of managing the money themselves.
In a city where 33 percent of the population lives below the poverty level, the average house is worth $40,000 and three of the last six mayors have been found guilty of mishandling funds, the Legislature needed greater assurances that the money would be spent properly.
"If the state is making an unprecedented investment in the city of Camden, it should have an unprecedented voice," said Joseph Roberts, the Assembly majority leader from Camden who co-sponsored the recovery bill.
With that clearly etched in the minds of Governor McGreevey and the legislators, the Camden Recovery Plan included a provision for appointing a chief operating officer whose stated function would be to focus on the economic development of this troubled city of 79,900 residents.
But in fact the job -- which will exist for five years -- will entail much more, extending not over only spending decisions but municipal appointments and the awarding of city contracts through an unparalleled veto power over the mayor and council as well as the city's zoning, planning and redevelopment boards.
The knottier details of how the money will be raised -- and particularly how the bill will be tied into school board reform -- were subjects of intense discussion in Trenton over the past several weeks.
Yet surprisingly, there was little debate over the notion of installing someone appointed by the governor whose job included executive powers superseding those of the city's elected officials. One explanation for the relative calm -- less than a year after city leaders stormed the state capitol protesting what they saw as a state takeover -- was that the name being bandied about was Mr. Primas, or as he is known, Randy.
Indeed, Camden's mayor, Gwendolyn Faison, who scurried about the State House a couple of weeks ago trying to get updates on amendments to the revitalization bill, expressed little concern this time around that her power was being usurped.
"This bill is larger than Mayor Faison," she said. "I can't think about egos. I'm still at the table, that's what counts," she added, referring to the 15-member review panel that she and the council president will sit on to oversee financing plans.
That she is now comfortable with a chief operating officer -- despite the fact that she will, at best, share the seat at the head of the table -- is because the other person being considered is Mr. Primas. "I welcome a person like Randy, someone I can trust," she said.

Strong Ties to the Mayor
Mayor Faison's newfound equanimity may be traced to the fact that Mr. Primas was the one who first brought her into politics, when as mayor in 1983 he asked her to run for a seat on the City Council on his ticket. It also does not hurt that Mr. Primas's and Mayor Faison's mothers worked together at GTE. Or that the mayor's son lives in nearby Gibbsboro across the street from the Primases, who have been known to fish-sit for their neighbors on occasion.
Nor is the goodwill for Mr. Primas limited to Mayor Faison and her family. The president of the Camden City Council, Angel Fuentes, who has had his share of turf wars with the mayor, is ready to yield a portion of his leadership to Mr. Primas.
"I don't see it as a power struggle," Mr. Fuentes said "He's going to be the main broker for the council, the mayor and the citizens of Camden. We need a good power broker who can be the link between all these institutions and the state and county."
Being selected chief operating officer is not a foregone conclusion for Mr. Primas, who would have to be appointed by the governor -- possibly after a formal search has been conducted. But his strong political ties, not only in Camden but at the county and state levels as well as to the business community, make him the most obvious choice. 
"The governor should look around for the best person for the job, but I think that's going to end up being Randy Primas," said Assemblyman Roberts.
For his part, Mr. Primas said recently that he did not want to be presumptuous about the likelihood of the new position. Then he proceeded to talk openly about the Camden Recovery Plan and the job he hoped to fill.
"Here we are, one of the top three richest states in the nation housing the second-poorest city in the nation," he said. "It's important for New Jersey to get this fixed. The state recognizes that Camden needs a systematic change, and that they need to make a significant investment."
Born in East Camden in 1949, Mr. Primas attended Woodrow Wilson High School before going to Howard University, where he says he was politically awakened in 1968 after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. and the ensuing riots just outside his dormitory in the nation's capital.
"I went up on the roof that night and it looked like a war," he said. "Fires were breaking out all over. The next day I was down in the street. The police had tried to contain everyone in our neighborhood, but when it started moving downtown, that's when the nightsticks came out. That was a defining moment for me."
Mr. Primas said that until that time his goal was "to get a good job, a house in the suburbs, two kids."
Eventually that original goal was met, but along the way Mr. Primas immersed himself in the politics of his hometown. After graduating from college, he returned to Camden to work for the Black People's Unity Movement Impact Corporation, a grass-roots economic development organization providing assistance to minority businesses. 
As part of a lawsuit settlement, former Mayor Angelo Errichetti agreed to put someone from the Black People's Unity Movement on his ticket to run for council. Mr. Primas, then a 23-year-old political neophyte, was chosen, largely because of his name recognition as the grand nephew of one of the city's first black doctors and the nephew of the city's first black fire chief.

Smooth Rise to Power
Mr. Primas sat on the city council for eight years, serving as its president for the last four. When Mr. Errichetti was forced from office in 1981 after his conviction for accepting bribes, Mr. Primas became the heir apparent to the mayor's seat. Re-elected twice, Mr. Primas left the city in 1990 at the start of his third term to serve as the state commissioner of community affairs for three years, and then joined Commerce Capital Markets as vice president, working in the bank's bond division in Cherry Hill.
But it was during his tenure as mayor that Mr. Primas made some decisions that still haunt him today and could have an effect on the new post he is pursuing. After 10 years of no tax increases under Mayor Errechetti but with the city facing imminent bankruptcy, Mr. Primas was forced to raise local taxes by 88 percent within days of taking office.
He was also pressured to accept the Riverfront State Prison on Camden's waterfront in exchange for bailout funds from the state. In response to critics, Mr. Primas said he takes full responsibility for his actions, but explained that with notes due to the bank and no money to pay them, "we really didn't have much choice."
Howard Gillette, a professor of history at Rutgers University, who is writing a book on the last 50 years of Camden, called Mr. Primas' re-emergence "a kind of extraordinary circle" after being absent from city government for more than 20 years.
While Professor Gillette acknowledged that Mr. Primas might be the right person for the position, he said he had concerns about the process, which he saw as disenfranchising voters.
"He brings experience, but he also brings baggage," he said. "It looks good from the outside. He's a seasoned person who's political and knows the community. The big challenge will be to regain the confidence of the people he's going to be working for. I don't think Primas and Faison would see each other as enemies, but there is an inherent conflict in putting somebody with superpowers over an elected official."
One community activist here, Frank Fulbrook, who ran against Mr. Primas for mayor in 1989, agrees, and is considering filing a lawsuit against the portion of the bill that deals with governance, based on what he calls "excessive power embodied in one person, a person who doesn't even live in Camden."
If the governor does decide to conduct a national search for the post, Mr. Primas said he would submit his application, noting that he was "not afraid to compete."
"I've worked all my adult life trying to improve the city I was born in," said the 52-year-old Mr. Primas. "I see this as an opportunity to finally really make a difference."
As for sidestepping voters' constitutional right to elect leaders, Mr. Primas conceded this was a price the city would have to pay to get itself back on track.
"I don't believe the Legislature will be prepared to put the kind of resources we're talking about without additional controls," he said. "If I had to choose, I think it's more important to see progress and improvement in the quality of life and temporarily suspend some of the autonomy of local government."
Taking the position and leaving his job at Commerce would mean a substantial pay cut for Mr. Primas, according to Mr. Roberts, who said the post would pay in the range of $150,000 to $175,000, commensurate with similar jobs like the head of a regional authority. And while the assemblyman cited this as one more example of Mr. Primas's dedication to the city, Mr. Fulbrook doubted that the former mayor would be willing to make such a financial sacrifice.
"Money was always a big thing to Randy. If he takes this job at $160,000, you better start searching where he'll get the rest of his income because he's not going to take a pay cut," said Mr. Fulbrook, noting that even in their high school yearbook, Mr. Primas stated that one of his desires was to "make a lot of money."
In a city such as Camden, where politics plays an inordinately large role, the easygoing Mr. Primas stands out for having ruffled few feathers while forming some powerful bonds, including those with the Camden county Democratic boss, George Norcross III, and State Senator Wayne Bryant, one of the people to put Mr. Primas's name forward for the job.
"Being a former mayor and a state commissioner, he has all the pre-requisites to do the job,' said Mr. Bryant, the co-sponsor of the bill. "I don't need a C.O.O. whose ego is going to get in the way. I need someone who's going to get the work done. I don't think he's looking to have any more stories written about him."
Because the position is not an elected one, and because he insists he has no future political aspirations, Mr. Primas predicts he will be able to get more done than he did as mayor in the 1980's, a period when the city saw sections of its waterfront and downtown revitalized while the outlying neighborhoods suffered.
"When you are an elected official, there are many more political considerations one has to take into account in order to keep getting re-elected," he said. "Since I have no desire to run for elected office, I have no need to win friends."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATBUSH; 
Victorian Area Is Tired of Being Discounted

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
The other day, the 99-Cent Gem store on Cortelyou Road temporarily slashed its prices to a bargain basement 93 cents per item. It may have been a smart business move, but it was hardly the kind likely to attract the growing numbers of upper-middle-class families and young professionals moving to the area, which is known as Victorian Flatbush. 
 Last year, three local residents formed a group called Friends of Cortelyou Road with the aim of attracting a bank branch, sit-down restaurants and other amenities to the seven-block-long strip of discount stores, dry cleaners and beauty salons surrounded by streets of grand Victorian houses. Their vision: convenient places to take their families for dinner, meet friends for coffee or shop for groceries. 
 "There are a lot of professional people around here," said Kathlene Mobley, a costume designer who was one of the group's founders and who moved to the neighborhood with her family six years ago. "But you never see them except when they go to the subway and go home. Why would they shop here if there's nothing?"
Working with the Flatbush Development Corporation and other local residents, the women have been pleading their case with banks and restaurateurs in neighboring Park Slope and Fort Greene. "It's been hit or miss, so far more miss than hit," said Jan Rosenberg, a sociologist at Long Island University and a founder of the group. 
One strategy is keeping track of when leases expire and trying to link landlords with desirable entrepreneurs. "After a few restaurants are successful, the market takes off and we won't have to intervene," said John Broderick, the executive director of the development corporation. But those first victories have been hard to come by. Some landlords have balked at tenants like restaurants, regarding them as less stable.
Still, some progress has occurred. A Duane Reade opened in January 2001, and the local Associated supermarket recently began stocking fancy salads like orzo with feta cheese. 
The city's Economic Development Corporation is designing a $1.2 million streetscape project that may include old-fashioned overhead lamps, decorative trash baskets and other new street furniture. Phillip Davis is planning to open the strip's first full-service restaurant, the Rug-B Cafe and Restaurant, this week, serving Caribbean continental fusion cuisine, with dishes like mussels, shrimp and smoked salmon in a callaloo and coconut broth.
The next prize is the site once occupied by Boxers, an odd combination of seedy bar and ice-cream counter that closed last summer. A restaurateur is poised to sign a lease for an upscale pub-style restaurant. But residents are still nervous: last summer, another restaurateur pulled out just when a deal seemed imminent. And Friends of Cortelyou Road groaned in unison recently, when the street's third 99-cent store, Midwood International, expanded into a vacant space next door. SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
His and Hers, For History's Sake

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: NEW YORK CITY 

 BODY:
DAVID LEVERING LEWIS met W. E. B. Du Bois in 1948 on the campus of Wilberforce University in Ohio. Mr. Du Bois was 80 years old; Mr. Lewis was 12.
 Mr. Du Bois, a founder of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People whom Dr. Lewis calls "the premier architect of the civil rights movement in the United States," was scheduled to give a talk there that day. Mr. Lewis's father, the dean of the university's theological school, was chatting with him. 
 As Mr. Lewis, now 66 year old, recalls that moment long ago, Mr. Du Bois asked him what he planned to do with his life. 
"That would have been a typical Du Boisian question at the time," said Dr. Lewis, sitting in his book-filled apartment with his wife, Ruth Ann Stewart, like him a professor at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "And I have no idea what I might have said to him." 
But Ms. Stewart, a forceful woman who sees herself as his first-line editor, gives a hearty laugh, and interjects her own version of what he could have said: "I'm going to spend the rest of my life writing about you." 
And she would be exaggerating only slightly. Dr. Lewis spent 15 years of his life -- and hers -- writing a landmark biography about Mr. Du Bois, a charismatic intellectual but not necessarily a likable man who had numerous adulterous affairs and ended his days in self-imposed exile in Ghana, an advocate of communism. 
Each of its massive volumes -- the first at 735 pages, the second at 715 -- won Dr. Lewis a Pulitzer Prize for biography, "W.E.B. Du Bois: Biography of a Race, 1868-1919" in 1994 and "W.E.B. Du Bois, 1919-1963" in 2001, both published by Henry Holt and Company.
If the book is a labor of love, it has less to do with Du Bois and more to do with the loving but sometimes labored relationship between the husband as writer and the wife as reader-editor. 
Dr. Lewis acknowledged as much by dedicating both volumes to Ms. Stewart for her "take-charge resiliency and untold hours of critical reading," (Vol. 1) because "her endless re-readings and suggestions improved the book and the biographer" (Vol. 2) and for "saving the quality of our lives." (Vol 2.)
"I intruded on her privacy and concentration and whatever it was she was wanting to do," he said. "Not a week went by when I did not come out of my hole and say, 'Look here. Would you listen to this?' "
"I understood," said Ms. Stewart, herself the author of a biography, "Portia: The Life of Portia Washington Pittman: The Daughter of Booker T. Washington," (Doubleday 1977.) "For David," she said, "writing is such an unforgiving thing in that's it's being alone, it's concentrative, and David has an extraordinary ability to concentrate and just keep things at bay. I could go by his study and say the house is on fire and he would say, 'Yes dear," and keep on writing."
For his efforts, Dr. Lewis has received many honors. Within recent months, he has been notified of his election to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, which was established in 1780 by John Adams, John Hancock and other founding fathers, and to the American Philosophical Society, founded by Benjamin Franklin in 1743. 
Mr. Lewis was born in Little Rock, Ark., into an intellectual atmosphere (his father was a Yale graduate, his mother a teacher) and grew up in Wilberforce and Atlanta, where he attended high school and graduated after only one year. He enrolled at Fisk University in Nashville, Mr. Du Bois' alma mater. 
After graduation as a Phi Beta Kappa, he acceded to his parents' wishes and studied law at Michigan State. But he dropped out after a semester and hopped a bus for New York City where he sought out Jacques Barzun, the noted historian and dean of Columbia University. 
"So," said Dr. Lewis, "I walked into Jacques Barzun's office and said, 'I've just quit the University of Michigan Law School; it was a mistake, and I want to do history.' " 
It worked, he said.
He received his doctorate in French and European history from the London School of Economics and Political Science, and after a stint in the Army, took a job teaching at the University of Ghana for a year, not because Mr. Du Bois had ended his days there at age 95 in 1963, he says, but because he was interested in working in an African country that was emerging as a democracy.
He has also taught at Howard University, Notre Dame and the University of the District of Columbia. He was working at the University of California at San Diego, when Rutgers enticed him away in 1986 to become the Martin Luther King Jr. professor in its history department. 
Ms. Stewart, the daughter of a Chicago postal supervisor and a mother who sold encyclopedias, has her own impressive list of accomplishments.
An expert on the role of the arts in economic and community development, she is research professor in cultural policy at the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers where she is designing a curriculum in cultural policy. 
"In the post-industrial world," she said, "the arts are emerging as a way in which cities and towns can define themselves and attract new interest in themselves as a place to live, a place to work and a place to invest -- the perfect and closest example being the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark."
Ms. Stewart attended the University of Chicago for a year, then received her undergraduate degree from Wheaton College in Norton, Ma., where she majored in biology with the aim of becoming a veterinarian.
But an interest in the arts drew her to New York, where she attended Columbia and received her M.S. degree in library science. She has also completed the arts management program at Harvard University and the senior management program in public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government there. 
Professor Stewart has served as associate director for external services of the New York Public Library and assistant chief of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture before being recruited by Daniel Boorstin to become assistant librarian of Congress for national education and cultural programs.
That position led her to become associate director and senior policy analyst in the arts, humanities and social legislation at the Congressional Research Service, the legislative analysis arm of Congress.
Professors Lewis and Stewart met in 1975 while she was working at the Schomburg and he was doing research for a book about the Harlem Renaissance, "When Harlem Was in Vogue." (Alfred A. Knopf, 1981.) But their relationship didn't flower until they met again in 1985. They have been together since. He has three grown children -- a daughter and two sons -- from a previous marriage and she has a grown daughter. 
Dr. Lewis began the Du Bois project in 1985. He traveled thousands of miles - sometimes with Ms. Stewart -- across America, the former Soviet Union, West Africa and Mexico and interviewed 200 people. 
Professor Stewart said she enjoyed sitting down after a hard day of work to read, as she phrases it, "my husband's elegant prose." But life in the house had to go on and she sometimes found him "inaccessible," to which he responds, perhaps protesting too much, "I wasn't all that inaccessible." "Well, I mean a different kind of inaccessibility," she said. "David wrote in the next room but the inaccessibility to family life is a common complaint of spouses, the companions of writers."
But she seems to relish her supporting role. "I felt very much a part of the book in the sense of meeting and coming to know a number of people that David interviewed; I felt involved," she said.
For all the inequities that remain in the racial divide, there is something to be celebrated in the fact that a biographer of one who labored at the beginning of the 20th century to elevate the status of blacks, is a beneficiary of that labor, receiving honors that include membership into two of the nation's most prestigious societies -- organizations established by America's founders, some of whom had slaves.
It is, in a way, Dr. Lewis says, "a shift in the plates underneath society."
But then, he adds, somewhat mischievously, "It can be intoxicating, a little risky too, because of all the blandishments. Having lived with Du Bois is a good thing because both he and Woody Allen would agree that when anybody wants you to join something, you're always suspicious."
And his wife, ever the editor, reshapes his thought, saying, "Who would want to be part of an organization that would have me as part of the organization?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Levering Lewis with his wife and editor, Ruth Ann Stewart. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q & A; 
Filing Verification of Income Forms

 BODY:
Q I live in a rent-stabilized apartment. Last year my rent went above $2,000 a month. I understand that for my apartment to be deregulated, two criteria must be met: my adjusted gross income must be more than $175,000 a year for the two prior years and my rent must be more than $2,000.
 In May 2001 I completed all the required state forms and said that I did not qualify as my income for 2000 did not exceed $175,000. Last week I received the same verification of income letter I got last year asking me to again complete the paperwork regarding my income, this time for the years 2000 and 2001. 
 Since I didn't qualify last year because my 2000 income was not above $175,000, and will not qualify this year for the same reason, why should I have to go through the trouble of completing all the forms again? . . . Lyn Familant, Manhattan. 

A Errol A. Brett, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that the letter writer's understanding of the rules regarding what is known as high-rent, high-income decontrol is accurate. The letter writer is also correct in suggesting that she should not have to complete this year's forms because her 2000 income -- provided in last year's response -- was below the $175,000 threshold. But it would probably be wise for her to file the requested information.
Mr. Brett explained that previously, when the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal denied a deregulation request after verifying a tenant's income, the department would not advise the landlord as to which year or years the tenant's income was below the required threshold. 
As a result, if a tenant's income was below the threshold for both of the preceding years, the landlord would have no way of knowing that and would have to file a new request for verification of income the following year. 
Under current procedures, however, the state agency informs the landlord of the year or years in which a tenant's income was below the threshold.
In other words, he said, when the state agency advised the landlord of the letter writer's continuing regulated status for 2001, it also said that the income for 2000 was below the $175,000 threshold. 
As a result, Mr. Brett said, since the landlord already knows that the letter writer will not be deregulated this year, he should not have sent a new verification of income request.
The letter writer, therefore, probably has no legal obligation to file this year's forms -- and could use last year's filing as a defense to any claim by the landlord that she has defaulted by failing to file the forms. But it would probably be less bothersome to simply file the forms and be done with the matter than to expose herself to a potential claim by the landlord that she is in default.

Can Board Member See Sponsor's Vote?

Q We just had our annual co-op meeting and I was re-elected to the board. As a shareholder and board member, I asked to see how many shares the sponsor had to vote and how his shares were voted. I was refused on the grounds of confidentiality. Don't I have a right to know how the sponsor voted? . . . Harry N. Brownstein, Manhattan.

A Dennis H. Greenstein, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that co-op shareholders and board members generally do not have a right to know how the sponsor -- or any other shareholder -- voted.
"There is a great sensitivity on the part of shareholders to be able to submit ballots without having other shareholders know how they voted," Mr. Greenstein said. As a result, he said, the board typically designates either the managing agent or special inspectors of election to tabulate the ballots and announce the results.

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Mt. Vernon Dreams Buoyed by Empire Zone

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM S. BEAVER 

 BODY:
IMAGINE that abandoned warehouses, brownfields and deteriorating businesses are hotels, a convention center and thriving commerce, and you join the ranks of Mount Vernon officials who believe New York State's Empire Zone program is the answer to the city's economic woes.
 Two weeks ago the city received permission from the state's Empire Zone Designation Board for the state's 64th Empire Zone, a two-square-mile area with a 10-year property tax abatement and sales tax breaks. These tax incentives have already helped line up $282.2 million in new investment and nearly 2,000 new jobs for the city, according to Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon. 
 Mount Vernon is only the second Westchester community to receive an Empire Zone designation since the businesss-incentive program began in 1987. The city of Yonkers has had an Empire Zone for nearly six years, and though initially it was slowed by a complex application process and lack of business interest, the zone now has $2.1 billion in planned investments, creating nearly 4,500 jobs and retaining another 2,500, according to Yonkers officials.
Mount Vernon officials have been clamoring for an empire zone for the last nine years. New York State rejected the city's first application in 1994 and city officials briefly considered a joint application with Yonkers and the Bronx.
The zone, which encompasses the downtown commercial area, the MacQuesten Parkway industrial corridor and East Sandford Boulevard, is open to all Mount Vernon businesses that make new capital and personnel investments that are certified by the city.
The zone includes an area where a $40 million redevelopment project, planned as the site of two malls with stores including Target, TJ Maxx and Bed Bath & Beyond, has been opposed by residents in neighboring Pelham, as well as some Mount Vernon residents. 
Though no one has yet been certified under the new Empire Zone rules in Mount Vernon, Constance G. Post, the city's commissioner of planning and community development, said companies are already inquiring about moving into the zone.
"We're expecting to attract considerable new business," Mrs. Post said. "It could be millions of dollars and thousands of jobs. We've already received requests from out-of-state companies, people who want to expand; the creation of the Empire Zone is the catalyst to get these businesses to invest."
Empire Zones offer investors a full complement of tax benefits, including real property tax credits, sales tax exemptions, wage tax credits and utility rate reductions. Companies operating inside a zone may reduce their tax liability to as little as zero.
Unitex, a uniform and linen rental service, is in the middle of the certification process. The company, which has had a building in Mount Vernon for 18 years, has planned a $15 million expansion largely because of the Empire Zone, said Michael Potack, the company's president.
"The overall savings will be about 15 percent of the total project cost," Mr. Potack said. "We're talking upward of $2 million on a $15 million project -- so it pays to go with the Empire Zone."
Some businesses, however, are hesitant to commit to the new zone. Michael Paolercio, chief executive officer of Michael Anthony Jewelers, the largest private employer in Mount Vernon, said his company would evaluate the Empire Zone before he applies for the tax credits.
"This Empire Zone is hot off the press and we want to be able to get a feel for it," Mr. Paolercio said. "We haven't completed any paperwork yet, so we'll wait and see if it's successful and what it would mean to us."
Michael Anthony Jewelers, which has been in Mount Vernon since 1980 and employs 650 people, is considering an expansion that some Mount Vernon officials thought the Empire Zone would ensure. But difficulties in getting out information about the designation and uncertainty in the state's Empire Zone application process have left even veteran Mount Vernon businesses with questions.
"We were a little shocked that Mount Vernon was awarded this status," Mr. Paolercio said. "There were a lot of other municipalities in the running. They're sure Mount Vernon is right for this Empire Zone, but is it right for Michael Anthony?"
With the varying needs of businesses, and marketing to a diverse group of companies from global corporations to mom-and-pop stores, soliciting for a tax-free zone has its difficulties. Ed Sheeran, who runs the Yonkers Office of Economic Development as well as the Industrial Development Agency, said the first few years of the Empire Zone program in Yonkers brought little interest.
"It was pretty slow to get off the ground," Mr. Sheeran said. "The bottom line is you have to make it a priority to get anything to happen. We made it work by pushing it as part of an overall development program."
THOUGH most of the investment in the Yonkers Empire Zone is recent, Mr. Sheeran said the city has seen only $164 million in completed projects despite the more than $2 billion planned. Mr. Sheeran, who leads the local administration of the Empire Zone, said the zone allows cities to compete effectively with any other site in the region.
"When I would talk to a company, I could say Yonkers, New York, will provide you with the best tax package in the tri-state area because of the Empire Zone and prove it on paper," Mr. Sheeran said.
Despite the sales pitch, development in Yonkers zone often snagged on investment details and blueprints, Mr. Sheeran said. The largest problem in Yonkers, he said, was including the small businesses in the benefits of the Empire Zone program.
"One of our biggest hurdles has been getting retail business and small businesses to participate," Mr. Sheeran said. "We've had to push them hard so they could understand these zones could save them money. But when they don't find out right away about everything, they feel left out."
Just last week business owners and residents protested the planned municipal stadium in downtown Yonkers, which calls for 22 small stores to be demolished. Many claim they were not adequately consulted about the construction and were never considered for economic investment themselves. The stadium plan in the Empire Zone illustrates the pressure and difficulty to turn investment into reality, Mr. Sheeran said.
Still facing difficulties in Yonkers, Mr. Sheeran said the process for Mount Vernon is far from over. Mapping out the two-square-mile zone -- Yonkers recently remapped its zone, removing government buildings and parks to stretch the zone's boundaries to include more businesses -- and the complex process of certifying companies is only the beginning, he said.
"Mount Vernon has the zone designation," Mr. Sheeran said, "but now they have to produce by securing the money to create new jobs for their residents."
