HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Chelsea; 
A Building Used for Storage Now Houses Artists

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE remains of the High Line railroad over 25th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues is ample reminder of the industrial past of west Chelsea. But today buildings that once housed garment manufacturers and, later, moving and storage operations are being converted into spaces for artists' and photographers' studios and the galleries that exhibit their work.
 Jack Fuchs, the president of Whitehall Business Archives, has already converted one nine-story building at 511 West 25th Street from the storage of corporate records to artist and gallery space and is considering doing the same at a second building he owns immediately to the west. 
 That building once housed a printing company that, like so many other manufacturing companies, was forced to seek a site in other boroughs or across the Hudson River in New Jersey. In fact, Mr. Fuchs said, he is not sure that the storage part of the moving and storage business is sustainable in this part of Manhattan. 
"It's going to be hard, because property is becoming so valuable and we can't raise our prices as quickly as the parking lots," he said, noting the motorists seem to be willing to pay extraordinary prices for parking. He said some companies may be willing to pay a premium to have their corporate records on the same island as their headquarters, but in less attractive locations than Chelsea. Otherwise, he said, the alternative was New Jersey for companies on the west side.
The change in the neighborhood is turning Mr. Fuchs and his brother Aaron from the moving business to real estate development and transforming a business that began when their grandmother accepted a truck in lieu of rent at the boarding house she was operating in the 1920's. Mr. Fuchs began his career at the family company dispatching moving crews from the spaces where galleries now display art work.
The building at 511 West 25th Street is almost completely converted, with only the first floor still equipped with garage doors and loading docks. Mr. Fuchs said he wanted the upper floors filled with tenants before beginning the expensive business of building a new lobby and a metal and glass facade on the street level. 
The mix of tenants in the 95,000-square-foot building is about 50 percent galleries, 30 percent artists and photographers and about 20 percent offices for companies related to the arts, like an accounting company that monitors budgets of film companies.
Some industrial holdouts remain in the neighborhood, including a few package-delivery companies and some auto repair and body shops, but the trend is clearly toward the arts, said David Mandl, the chief executive of Meltzer/Mandl Architects. Mr. Mandl's firm designed the renovations at 511 and is preparing plans for other buildings owned by Mr. Fuchs on the street. "The concept is migrating to the west," he said.
Another indication of the changing nature of the neighborhood is the signs attached to the trestles of the High Line bearing messages such as "No angst for art" and "To feel or not to feel, this is the answer.' "
Mr. Mandl said galleries and artists were attracted by the 13-foot-high ceilings and 8-foot-tall operating windows that admit natural light.
But that natural light can be a mixed blessing, said Deborah Bell, who operates a photographic gallery on the seventh floor. "Natural light is important to me and my peace of mind, but you do not want too much of it on the photographs," she said. Her answer was to divide her space, with her office next to the outer wall and windows, with doors equipped with translucent glass separating the office from the gallery.
"I wanted separate spaces for working and looking," she added.
Most of the interior spaces are simple, with walls of Sheetrock painted white. The floors have been cleaned up and patched where necessary because of damage from past industrial use. In one penthouse space the wooden floor looks almost new, the product of extensive cleaning and sanding. "This is maple floor that was put down about 70 years ago," Mr. Fuchs said.
Looming outside are two very industrial-looking water tanks supported by steel towers. "It would be very expensive to take them down and, to our surprise, the tenants said to leave them up," he said.
Mr. Mandl noted that Space, a gym, spa and cafe on the 10th floor of the building at 508 West 26th Street, uses the tanks, which are clearly visible from its windows as a symbol of its location.
Dealing with the artistic community is different from dealing with those whose primary business is real estate, Mr. Fuchs said. Unfamiliar with the sometimes arcane negotiating rituals in the industry, many do not know how to press for changes to their spaces to tailor them to their individual businesses.
"We have to let them know that we are more flexible than we might appear," he said. For example, he said, one photographer in the building who specializes in food needed a gas line run to the space. Another who photographs jewelry needed a safe installed.
BUT the adjustment process went both ways, with people now occupying a building that formerly held inanimate objects. "We were in the business of storing corporate records and the boxes don't complain," Mr. Fuchs said. "Now we have live tenants with needs." 
Dominic J. Taglialatella, who operates DJT Fine Art on the second floor, said he had found Mr. Fuchs to be accommodating. When he was scheduled to move, the space he had leased was not yet finished. So, he said, Mr. Fuchs found him space on a higher floor so he would be able to open at the right address when mailings and advertising telling of his shift from the Upper East Side of Manhattan were distributed.
Now in his own space, he said that traffic in Chelsea is greater than it was in his old locations. "We will get 150 people on a Saturday here compared to 30 or 40 on the east side," he said. The ratio of lookers to buyers is higher in the current space, but he said lookers tend to become buyers as their economic fortunes improve.
Joe Neal, a photographer who specializes in still lives and body parts, like hands, said the tall ceilings are particularly useful for the elaborate lighting needed for photography for cosmetics companies.
In anticipation of expanding the gallery and studio project, Mr. Fuchs has breached an interior wall connecting 511 and 531 West 25th Street, also a Whitehall warehouse. If 511 is after, 531 is before, with long corridors lined with metal cages filled with records. "This is still a warehouse, but it will be Phase 2," said Mr. Fuchs, adding that the conversion's timing has not been decided. 
There are interesting possibilities further in the future, Mr. Mandl said. Mr. Fuchs owns a two-story building and a surface parking lot to the west of 531. He said the building might be torn down and the land combined with the parking lot and some unused air rights for a new development in an area that has not seen much new construction in a long time.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Left, Deborah Bell in her photographic gallery at 511 West 25th Street, the building at center in right photo. The adjoining four-story warehouse at 531 West 25th Street is also to be converted for artists' use. (Photographs by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE; 
Garage's New Waiting Line Is Full of Would-Be Buyers

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
Customers discuss the Monterey Garage in tones usually reserved for Zabar's and other pillars of the Upper West Side. "The Monterey represents what the Upper West Side has always been for West Siders," said Doren L. Slade, who parks her car at the garage, at West 89th Street near Columbus Avenue. "A solid community and a wonderful place." 
 But now its future is on the table. The city took control of the garage under the 1962 Upper West Side Urban Renewal Plan, but the property was never developed and the plan expired last month. That expiration has led to talk in this congested community over possible uses of the garage, and one much-discussed idea is for the city to sell it to local nonprofit groups, including a popular synagogue. That possibility has divided those seeking to save a friendly mom-and-pop, and those who want to help worthy nonprofits grow. 
 Kenny Mance, whose family has run the garage both before and after the city seized it, contends that he deserves first crack at buying the property. "It's ridiculous to give it to somebody else," said Mr. Mance, whose family began their tenure there in the 1950's. "My father had a 99-year lease when the city bought it and never used it." 
Supporters of Mr. Mance turned out for a meeting of Community Board 7 last month and spoke of his kindness. If you were going through hard times, they said, Mr. Mance would forgive a late payment. If you had car troubles, he would fix the problem free. If you had a bad leg, he would drive you home.
"It's just common courtesy," Mr. Mance explained.
But such stories have little impact on Deborah Pinsky, the executive director of the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, one of the groups interested in the site. "We're not out to do anything bad to this guy," Ms. Pinsky said. "But we can't expand because space is so limited."
Joel Flax, executive director of the DOME Project, a nonprofit group that helps disadvantaged youths, agreed. "We have to turn away hundreds of kids each year," he said. "We've been looking for space for at least five years."
The five-story Beaux-Arts garage was built in 1906, two years before the Model T hit the road. "It's one of the earliest commercial auto garages built," said Andrew S. Dolkart, an architectural historian at Columbia University, who was hired by Mr. Mance to research the building.
Despite all the local discussion, Carol Abrams, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said that her agency had no immediate plans for the site.
Mr. Mance said that the waiting list for his 100-car garage was still growing. "If you're here first," he said, "you get first dibs." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
With the Arena Plan Down, Is Codey the One Who's Out?

BYLINE:  By Ronald Smothers; Ronald Smothers reports from Newark for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Without a doubt the political fight over the state budget that pitted Mayor Sharpe James of Newark against Governor McGreevey -- and briefly had the proposal for a Newark arena and the $23.4 billion budget hanging in the same balance -- was the seismic event last week that garnered the heavyweight attention.
 But there was a little-noticed undercard, even more brutal in the clenches, that was likely to reverberate in Essex County and state politics alike. It was the battle between Richard J. Codey, the leader of the Democrats in the evenly split Senate, and his caucus opponents who are aligned with three powerful Democratic leaders who would like to unseat him. 
 Mayor James, who is also a state senator, may be angry with Governor McGreevey, but Mr. Codey may well be the one who suffers for it if the mayor can be convinced to side with opponents of the Senate leader. Indeed, in his anger late Sunday over the arena, Mayor James cited the "lack of leadership among Democrats in the Senate" as the cause of the bill's plight. 
The mayor cannily avoided publicly blaming the powerful Democratic governor as most other lawmakers did privately, leaving room for further talks with Mr. McGreevey. But Mr. Codey was not spared.
It all played into Essex County political battles in which Mr. James is alternately courted by and aligned with Mr. Codey on the one hand and on the other by Stephen N. Adubato, a powerful political leader with roots in Newark's North Ward, and his close associate, Joseph DiVincenzo, the chairman of the Essex County Freeholder Board. In last month's primary, Mr. Codey lost badly when Mr. DiVincenzo defeated a Codey associate, Tom Giblin, for the county executive nomination while Mr. Adubato's candidates for party posts swamped Mr. Codey's and took over the county committee. 
Through it all, Mr. James supported Mr. DiVincenzo but never completely cut his ties to Mr. Codey. But last week, Mr. Codey was suddenly looking much more vulnerable. According to several Democrats, Mr. Adubato was talking furiously with two longtime Codey enemies, George Norcross III, the Camden County Democratic leader, and John Lynch, the powerful Middlesex County Democrat. They were devising strategies to somehow unseat him before his term as leader of the Senate Democratic caucus expires in 18 months.
Mr. Lynch and Mr. Norcross were both very visible during the Sunday session of the Legislature, as were Mr. DiVincenzo and with Representative Donald Payne, who is the new Essex County Democratic chairman.
A day later, Mr. Norcross, Mr. Lynch and Mr. Adubato were reportedly talking tactics.
"Suddenly he is weakened and you have leaders from the north, central and southern part of the state ready to move," said one Democrat familiar with the maneuvers. Possible approaches have included talk of even lending Democratic support that each of them controls to elect Senator John Bennett, Mr. Codey's Republican counterpart in the evenly split Senate, as the sole and undisputed leader, a move that would turn a fractious Senate chamber into a Republican fortress.
But other top Democrats said that such a maneuver would alienate others from the three leaders. The more likely approach, they said, was to set Mr. Codey up for a challenge a year and a half from now, after the next legislative elections.
For his part Mr. Codey dismisses talk of an open challenge and especially its chances of success. Pointedly, he first cites his long support of Mr. McGreevey when he was a little-known state senator looking for access to party leaders.
McGreevey administration officials echo this and then go on to privately praise Mr. Codey for "a negotiating and consensus-building style" that which has served the young administration well in an evenly split Senate and tough economic times. It is a style, said one senior administration figure, that doesn't mix well with the take-no-prisoners approach of the three party leaders arrayed against Mr. Codey.
Mr. Codey also noted that it was his work in the trenches of redistricting that helped create the legislative map that allowed Democrats to wrest control of the Assembly from Republicans and fight them to a tie in the Senate. And many of his fans among the Senate Democratic Caucus -- like Senators Barbara Buono, Raymond Lesniak, Bernard Kinney and Joseph Vitale -- enthusiastically second that view.
"Caucus politics are the roughest politics in the game but in the end, Codey did an outstanding job." said Senator Kenny.
Just how rough caucus politics can get became evident in the last week when supporters of Mr. Codey said that his opponents had sunk to suggesting that personal concerns, including the fact that his wife recently learned she had breast cancer, were distracting the West Orange Democrat from his duties. 
"They have used his wife's illness to suggest that he doesn't have time to devote to leadership duties," said Senator Buono describing what she said Mr. Codey's opponents had been whispering. "I know politics is not for the fainthearted, but this is barbaric and reprehensible."
Mayor James is keeping his own counsel. An agreement to hold public hearings on the arena measure starting this week seemed to have eased his frustration for now. Mr. Codey, along with the governor and other Democrats, helped forge that agreement, and if Mr. Codey can make it fly in the Senate when lawmakers return in the early fall, he may return to fight another day.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
ToGrowl and Bear It: They Did

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
MANY mutual funds recorded double-digit losses in the second quarter, with diversified domestic equity funds losing 11.3 percent of their value, on average, according to Morningstar Inc.
 So it is not surprising that the top of the winners' list was crowded with so-called bear-market funds that are intended to thrive during stock market declines by using strategies like shorting stocks. 
 Some of these strategies, however, can create high volatility in share prices, warned Russel Kinnel, director of fund analysis at Morningstar. He recommends looking at the funds' overall track record over time, year by year, or even quarter by quarter, to gauge their riskiness. 
Managers of some of the top performers among diversified actively managed funds -- bear-market funds or otherwise -- talked about the quarter and what they saw ahead for the stock market. Each fund is open to new investors.

A Hybrid of Sorts
The $90 million Comstock Capital Value Class A fund took second place among actively managed diversified domestic equity funds open to new investors, and seventh place over all. The fund rose 22.6 percent in the quarter.
Charles L. Minter, 60, and Martin Weiner, 68, the co-managers, are confirmed bears. "We strongly believe that the stock market will continue down at least another 30 or 35 percent from here," Mr. Weiner said from their offices in Yardley, Pa., outside Philadelphia.
Mr. Minter added: "We're coming off one of the biggest bubbles in U.S. financial history, from the late 1990's to the early 2000's. Everything that's happening now is the result of that inflating bubble."
The fund is classified by Morningstar as a domestic hybrid, which typically owns a mix of stocks and bonds, but Comstock Capital Value has owned no stocks for two years. Instead, it owns United States Treasury bills and bonds and uses a variety of strategies to bet on stock market declines. These include selling stocks short and buying Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures.
Among its most profitable shorts this quarter was the Manugistics Group, a Rockville, Md., company that makes business management software. The managers sold shares short in early April for about $18, closing the position at the end of June when shares traded at $6.11 and earning a return of 67 percent.
So far, they have made about 92 percent on paper in Broadcom, the semiconductor manufacturer in Irvine, Calif. The managers started selling Broadcom shares short about two years ago when the stock was at $229; it closed the quarter at $17.54.

Small Banks Are the Ticket
The $160 million Eclipse Small Cap Value fund was one of a handful of funds that made money in the quarter by buying stocks. It rose 5.9 percent, placing fourth among diversified funds and 11th over all.
Kathy O'Connor, 42, and Wesley G. McCain, 59, the co-managers, review the smallest 2,000 or so United States companies every week, looking for those that they think are undervalued relative to their history, their industry and other small stocks.
Cheap companies are not enough, Ms. O'Connor said from her Manhattan office; they also want to see improving profits. The fund, which is highly diversified, owns 300 stocks.
Its second-quarter performance was driven in part by its stake in small banks -- 17 percent, compared with 14 percent for the Russell Small Cap Value index. Another factor was a relatively small position in technology and communications stocks -- less than 2 percent versus 6 percent for the index, Ms. O'Connor said.
Small banks were profitable, she said, because the economics of the business are particularly strong right now; banks are paying interest rates of about 2 percent to depositors and collecting 6 percent interest on their mortgage loans. "A lot of our portfolio companies benefited from consumers' investments in real estate," she said, adding that their best performers were financial services companies, mortgage lenders and home builders.
One winner was Flagstar Bancorp, the holding company for Flagstar Bank, based in Troy, Mich. Flagstar stock, which rose about 49 percent in the quarter, benefited from the strong real estate market in its area, Ms. O'Connor said. 
For the same reasons, the fund made money in Brookline Bancorp, in Brookline, Mass., the holding company for Brookline Savings Bank, which operates in Brookline and eastern Massachusetts. It rose 48 percent in the quarter. 
Another winner was Novastar Financial, a national mortgage lender based in Westwood, Kan., up 90 percent in the quarter.
Ms. O'Connor says she is not bullish on the market for the short term. "Despite the declines," she said, "market valuations are still historically high because corporate profitability hasn't been catching up."

Counting on Indexes to Fall
The $175 million Hussman Strategic Growth fund rose 3 percent in the second quarter, taking sixth place among diversified domestic equity funds and 16th place over all.
The fund is always fully invested in individual stocks, said John P. Hussman, 39, the manager. But he can hedge away the market risk of the stock portfolio by selling market indexes short related to the stocks. He shorts the Russell 2000 index to offset losses in his smaller stocks and the S.& P. 100 index to offset losses in the bigger stocks.
To decide whether to hedge the fund's stock portfolio, Mr. Hussman uses a computer model to review trends in stock prices and trading volume among individual stocks. He also examines what he calls "uniformity" in the overall market -- whether performance among a variety of groups like large- and small-cap stocks, industry sectors and bonds is moving in tandem.
"Market history indicates that overvalued markets don't always decline," Mr. Hussman said. "What distinguishes them in the short term is uniformity across all the stock sectors, which tells you that investors have a robust preference for taking risk in the overall market."
The hedging, Mr. Hussman explained, is intended to smooth the fund's volatility. By the rules in the prospectus, he may hedge the entire portfolio, which he has largely done since September 2000. But he is not permitted to create a net "short" position, meaning he may not sell more shares than he owns.
The fund's second-quarter results, he said, were driven by the fact that the stocks dropped about 9 percent, on average, while the indexes declined about 12 percent, on average, creating a 3 percent return.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Variable Annuities Offer Safety, at a Price

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
AS if variable annuities, the insurance industry's version of mutual funds, were not bewildering enough, insurers have added a batch of features intended to protect investors from a stock market that lately has not seemed to know which way is up.
 Some companies are offering guarantees that an investor will break even, while others lock in a gain, even when the market is declining. But these protections increase the already considerable expenses of variable annuities -- costs that, in a rising market, usually make them less attractive than comparable mutual funds unless they are held for many years. The money put into most variable annuities must be locked up for 7 to 10 years, with penalities of up to 20 percent for early withdrawals. 
 Even so, the new protections could give nervous investors -- in a market that is falling for the third consecutive year -- the assurance that they can invest in stocks without the fear of losing their capital. 
The insurers are struggling to attract customers. Last year, gross sales fell nearly 18 percent, to $112.8 billion. And the industry has been cannibalizing itself. The Financial Research Corporation of Boston estimates that more than 60 percent of sales last year involved switching policies from one insurer to another, usually in response to an offer of new features and, often, a cash incentive.
Analysts say many investors do not want to commit to an investment for up to 10 years. Some also say the industry is hurting itself with its new gimmicks. "The products are becoming more difficult to understand," said Lisa Plotnick, an analyst at Financial Research. 
The variable annuity, like the 401(k) account, was intended to accumulate money for retirement and usually consists of an assortment of stock and bond funds. But it also includes insurance. If the investor dies, the heirs get at least the amount invested, even if the value has declined. For investors who retire, the insurance guarantees a stream of payments for life, although most cash out at once or over a few years.
Some of the new protections were created when the market was roaring, but they have never been more relevant. These features put a new twist on an old concept. Now, the original investment can be preserved not only for survivors but for investors themselves.
Last June, American Skandia Life Assurance of Shelton, Conn., introduced a feature providing that after seven years, investors will have at least what they started with.
"This is just the thing for older people who don't have enough years left to earn back big losses in the market," said John Meunier, an executive at Cogent Research, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., that helped develop the feature for Skandia, a unit of Skandia Insurance of Stockholm.
"It's also ideal for the investment jock whose wife says, 'I'll kill you if you put money into anything risky these days,' " Mr. Meunier said.
How does Skandia manage this feat? It permits investors to put their money into a range of investments and tracks the money. When the annuity starts heading into the red, a computer shifts money into fixed-income investments with a sufficient yield to meet the break-even target. Other insurers guarantee that investors will not lose their initial stake by requiring them to put two-thirds of their money in fixed-income accounts. The rest goes into stocks.
Another kind of guarantee provides for annual growth of, say, 6 percent for 10 years, which would increase an investment of $100,000 to $179,084.80. In yet another option, the variable annuity's value fluctuates, but, at the end of 10 years, it is credited with the highest value it has reached on any anniversary of the investment during that period.
These last two guarantees come with a significant restriction. Once the 10 years are up, the investor may not take the money in a lump sum or in smaller payments over a short period. The payout must take place over the rest of the investor's life, allowing the insurer to keep earning a profit on the client's money.
One company, G.E. Financial Assurance in Richmond, Va., a unit of General Electric, has taken an approach that seems simple on its face. It asks clients just two questions: How much money do you want to receive in retirement, and when do you want to start receiving it? Then G.E. figures out how much has to be paid in to reach the goal.
In one example, G.E. says that by paying $713.95 a month for 25 years, a couple, each 40 years old, could receive at least $2,000 a month for life, beginning at the age of 65. If the money grew faster than an assumed 5 percent, the monthly payment would increase.
The hard part is that an investor must determine how much money will be needed 25 years in the future and, no matter what happens in his or her life, the goal cannot be changed. As with other variable annuities, there is no provision in the payout for inflation. There is also a stiff penalty for backing out within 10 years and, in a provision not found in other variable annuities, a charge equal to 1 percent of the investment for canceling anytime after that.
While many of the new features may sound inviting, they add to the cost of a variable annuity. And while they reduce the risk of investing in stocks, they also limit gains.
Often, the features do not pay off because investors bail out early. Cynthia Saccocia, a senior analyst at Cerulli Associates in Boston, said that nearly 80 percent of customers switch to another annuity, promising greater rewards, within five years. "If you do this," Ms. Saccocia said, "you've paid five years for a benefit that will never be realized."
Some people simply decide that they need the money for something else. But if they take their money before a specified time -- up to 10 years -- they pay a penalty of as much as 10 percent to the insurer. If they are under 59 1/2, they pay an additional 10 percent to the government.
Variable annuities have consistently been criticized for their cost. According to Morningstar Inc., the average annual fee is 2.21 percent of the value of the investment, compared with 1.39 percent for a mutual fund. While variable annuities have the advantage of being sheltered from taxes as they grow, the added eight-tenths of a percent means they have to be held for a long time -- at least 10 years by some calculations, much longer by others -- to come out ahead of mutual funds.
Insurers, however, say that most people who invest in variable annuities are cautious folk who are not shooting for the moon. Many of these investors would not venture into mutual funds or individual stocks. 
"The alternative for some of these investors would be bank C.D.'s," said Jacob Herschler, American Skandia's marketing director. "But with C.D.'s, they are going to get hammered by inflation. They need to be invested in equities for the long term. They're seeking options and benefits that give them peace of mind."
THE insurers acknowledge that variable annuities are complex. They do not expect most buyers -- usually people in their late 50's or early 60's with annual incomes of $75,000 or less -- to try to figure them out on their own. "Our company's distribution is based on the fact that a qualified financial adviser is going to help you with this," said Michael Wells, the vice chairman of Jackson National Life, a Lansing, Mich., unit of the British insurer Prudential. 
But analysts and consumer advocates question the objectivity of some advice because brokers and financial planners get much more for selling a variable annuity than a mutual fund: 6 percent to 8 percent for an annuity, compared with an average of 4.78 percent for a fund. "An adviser is likely to do better in the long run by making the right decision for a client," said Todd Porter, an analyst at Morningstar. "But certainly some people are tempted to go for the short-term gain."

HEADLINE: Skirmishes Signal Rent Law Countdown 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
LEGISLATION to renew rent regulation a year early never made it onto the table in Albany during the recent legislative season, primarily because tenant advocates and Democrats in the Assembly wanted to force the gristly issue on Senate Republicans, who wouldn't bite.
 But with the rent laws, which affect more than one million households, facing sunset on June 15, 2003, and the gubernatorial election just four months away, the classic debate over how much, and even whether, government should counteract free-market forces to protect certain essentials of a citizen's life is once again stirring. 
 Partisans across the divide concur, grudgingly on one side, that rent stabilization and its withered elder cousin, rent control, will eventually be extended. So, for now, the debate is focusing on the fate of two rent-law provisions that are colloquially called "vacancy decontrol" and "luxury decontrol." 
Those provisions -- more bureaucratically called "high-rent/vacancy decontrol" and "high-rent/high-income decontrol" -- have whittled away the stock of rent-regulated apartments. And a bone of contention in the debate is the sharply conflicting estimates of how many apartments have already been decontrolled under those provisions. 
"We all recognize that regulation will be extended in some fashion for whatever period the elected officials wish to push it out for," said Joseph Strasburg, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, the city's largest landlord group. "We all clearly understand that those tenants who are already in place will be protected."
To which Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, said: "The point here is that the purpose of rent regulation is not merely to protect the tenant in place, it's to keep the apartment affordable for people who are going to live in it in the future. And that's what's lost with these decontrol loopholes."
Under high-rent/vacancy decontrol, which was included in the rent laws when they were last renewed in June 1997, a rent-stabilized apartment is deregulated upon vacancy if the rent can be legally raised to $2,000 or above. In calculating the new rent, a landlord is entitled to an increase of approximately 20 percent when a tenant dies or moves out. Then, if the landlord renovates the apartment, one-fourtieth of the cost of the renovation can be added to the monthly rent, in perpetuity. If those increases bring the rent to $2,000, the apartment can be deregulated, with the landlord allowed to charge whatever the market will bear.
Under high-income decontrol, an occupied apartment for which the rent has climbed to $2,000 or above can be deregulated if the household income exceeds $175,000 for two consecutive years. The $175,000 income threshold was lowered from $250,000 in the 1997 rent-law renewal.
To supporters of rent regulation, these decontrol provisions chip away at both the supply of affordable apartments and the underlying political forces that have sustained the rent regulation system. "There is no question," Mr. McKee said, "that the strategy of the real estate lobby is to allow the various decontrol mechanisms to continue to operate and to whittle away at the rent-regulated universe until such time as there are so few apartments remaining under rent regulation that tenants will lack the political muscle to get the laws renewed for another period of time."
"Just to renew the laws alone is not enough," he said. "We've got to, at a minimum, get this vacancy-decontrol mechanism repealed."
For Mr. Strasburg, in his hopes to see the entire rent-regulation system dismantled, a repeal of vacancy decontrol is unthinkable. "There should be an orderly demise to a system that's been in existence over 50 years," he said.
Topping his wish list for the coming legislative struggle is the elimination of the rent threshold in the high-income decontrol provision. "The issue for us is to examine whether those tenants who are presently earning in excess of $175,000 a year should continue to receive protection just because their rents are below the $2,000 threshold," Mr. Strasburg said. "We're going to see if there is a willingness to look at a means test, rather than looking at incomes plus rent level."
If a household's income exceeds $175,000, "we should not be protecting those individuals," he said. "It should only be those whose incomes are $175,000 or more, and not have the two conditions met."
Whatever the eventual outcome of the cyclical rent-law battle, for now only the Democrats seem anxious to engage -- and so, find themselves dueling with the wind.
Rent regulation is mandated, by statute, in New York City and three suburban counties -- Nassau, Westchester and Rockland -- when vacancy rates drop below 5 percent. According to the 1999 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey, the most recent data available, the city's vacancy rate that year was 3.2 percent, down from 4 percent in 1996.
As far back as April, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan, easily pushed through his house bills that would have extended rent regulation until 2008 (starting this past June 15) while also ending both vacancy decontrol and high-rent decontrol. "Landlords in the city are clearly taking advantage of these provisions," Mr. Silver said, "and they are hiking rental rates to a level that working families cannot afford."
But the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican from upstate Rensselaer County, refused to allow companion legislation to be introduced in his house. Last week, a spokesman for Mr. Bruno, John McArdle, said the majority leader would not discuss the issue. "It doesn't come up for renewal until next June," Mr. McArdle said. "There's nothing to talk about now."
Mr. McKee of the tenants' coalition, not surprisingly, believes the issue should be discussed now, as part of the gubernatorial election. "We will continue to push this issue until Nov. 5," he said. "And as far as we are concerned, the Legislature can do it in September or October, and the governor can even call a special session."
The Democratic candidates for governor, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Andrew M. Cuomo, both support expedited action on the rent laws.
"There's no question that the Republicans are trying to erode and eventually eliminate rent control," Mr. McCall said. "I think it's important to get this done this year, this being an election year."
"And also," Mr. McCall continued, "we should try to avoid what happened five years ago when this issue went down to the wire and caused so much anxiety for tenants in New York. People didn't know if rent regulation would be extended and what their living arrangements would be."
In a written statement, Mr. Cuomo pointed to the Assembly's passage of the bills to renew rent regulation through 2008 and also to "repeal those provisions of law that have allowed landlords to decontrol thousands of city apartments."
"I strongly support those bills," Mr. Cuomo said. "It is time for the Senate to pass them and for Governor Pataki to sign them into law."
Gov. George E. Pataki did not respond to repeated requests for an interview on the subject.
Agreed-upon data on how many regulated apartments have already been decontrolled in recent years does not exist. Estimates vary widely, and by ideology.
No provision was written into either the 1993 or the 1997 rent-law packages requiring owners of stabilized buildings to notify any government agency when an apartment was decontrolled.
There does exist a requirement that every stabilized apartment be registered each year with the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. And on that registration form is a box for the landlord to check if the apartment "became permanently exempt since the prior year." However, filling out the form after an apartment is deregulated is optional.
On June 4, at the request of two members of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board (which has responsibility for deciding each year how much of a rent increase stabilized tenants in the city will receive), the state housing division released numbers on how many landlords had filled out the form and checked the "permanently exempt" box since 1994. The total was 20,161.
According to the Housing and Vacancy Survey, conducted triennially for the city by the Census Bureau, there were 1,020,588 rent-stabilized apartments in the city in 1999 (a new survey is due out early next year). And so, those 20,161 apartments belonging to owners who had checked the "exempt" boxes on the state form represented 2 percent of the city's stabilized housing stock.
Perhaps not surprisingly, of the 20,161 total, 18,618 -- or 92 percent -- were in Manhattan, meaning that at least 5.2 percent of Manhattan's 354,595 stabilized units have been decontrolled since 1994. And those numbers jumped from 544 in 1994 to 1,121 in 1997, when the rent laws were last renewed, to 4,490 in 2001. (Officials at the state housing agency pointed out that 19,461 apartments entered the stabilization rolls between 1999 and 2001, most of them on temporary status under tax-abatement programs that last between 10 and 20 years.) 
Nobody familiar with the issue, however, views the figure of 20,161 deregulated apartments as anything more than a starting point for estimates of apartments that have been removed from rent regulation. 
"That's probably a floor," said Jack Freund, the chief economist for the Rent Stabilization Association, the large landlord group. "My estimation is that, as a cap, there were no more than twice those 20,000 units that were decontrolled, or about 40,000. My guess is that it's somewhere between 30,000 and 40,000."
What adds to the 20,161 checked boxes, Mr. Freund pointed out, is that it is possible to calculate the number of apartments renting for about $1,667 in a given year, so that if the 20 percent rent increase allowed when a vacancy occurs is factored in, the new rent would surpass $2,000. "And each year you make an assumption that the usual turnover rate applies, which is about 10 percent," Mr. Freund said, "so that number of units could possibly go over $2,000 a month and be deregulated."
"There's no way to tell," he said, "but based on the available data it would appear to me and to others, I think, that there are probably no more than 40,000 units that have been deregulated since 1994."
Mr. McKee pointed out, however, that those numbers do not include deregulated apartments where, besides the 20 percent vacancy rent increase, landlords managed to bring the rent to $2,000 or more by performing renovations and adding one-fortieth of the costs. Nor do they include, he said, "the number of units that landlords have simply treated as decontrolled on vacancy without spending the money to get the rent up to $2,000."
Using what amounts to an extrapolation of estimates, based on data from a series of Housing and Vacancy Surveys, the tenants' coalition released a study in February saying that approximately 148,000 apartments had been deregulated since 1991. 
"This is a projection," Mr. McKee said. "We took the trends in the H.V.S. and then projected forward from '99 to 2002." Pointing out that the new survey will be released next year, he added, "We'll see then how close we were, but I think we'll be close."
WHATEVER the statistics and whatever the specifics of an eventual outcome to the current rent-law struggle, the decades-old debate is based on recurring contentions and standard stereotypes invoked by both sides, usually with some degree of validity.
The billboard image projected by the landlords is of the affluent Upper West Sider hogging a $500-a-month, six-room penthouse for decades. For the tenant advocates, while not quite the mustachioed, black-hatted landlord ordering the widow out, there is the headline-name owner of dozens of buildings with thousands of apartments who just can't wait for those vacancies.
"The history of this debate," Mr. Strasburg said, "is that the tenant advocates have protected the rights of tenants whose incomes have exceeded six figures, because they want to protect the unit more than they want to protect the tenant."
Parvati Devi lives on the Upper West Side, but hardly fits the hoggish image.
On the sweltering afternoon of June 26, despite being disabled, Ms. Devi rode the subways downtown to testify at a city Rent Guidelines Board hearing in the Great Hall at Cooper Union. She came to say she could not afford another rent increase on her one-bedroom stabilized apartment in a brownstone on West 90th Street.
The $466 she pays in rent, Ms. Devi said, comes out of her entire income of $637 a month in Social Security disability insurance. "I pay 75 percent of my income on rent," she said. "For shame that so many people with disabilities have to constantly worry about this basic human need."
Mr. McKee insists that "all over the city" landlords are making one-time investments in renovations on vacated apartments and reaping great benefits. "If they spend $10,000, they can raise the rent by $250 per month," he said. "If they spend $40,000, which is not uncommon, they can raise the rent by $1,000 a month."
On the Upper West Side, Mr. McKee continued, "large prewar, six-room apartments are coming back on the market for $8,000 -- $10,000, in some cases." In neighborhoods like Kingsbridge, in the Bronx, he said, "you're seeing one-bedroom apartments renting for $700, $800 under rent stabilization, coming back on the market at $1,100, $1,200."
But Roberta Bernstein, another witness at the rent hearing on June 26, insists that small landlords are squeezed.
Ms. Bernstein is president of the Small Property Owners of New York, an organization of about 1,000 landlords, most of whom own buildings with 10 to 18 apartments. 
Small landlords face obstacles, in part, because they lack the heft of their big-name brethren: few economies of scale allowing them to purchase supplies at a discount; full prices to contractors; the lone tenant whose failure to pay rent seriously crimps the rent roll; no staff lawyer to handle litigious tenants. 
At the rent hearing, Ms. Bernstein called on the board to approve increases for stabilized apartments beyond the 2 percent for a one-year lease and 4 percent for a two-year lease that it had previously proposed.
Insurance costs have jumped, Ms. Bernstein said. "Fuel costs are rising and tax and water increases show no signs of abating," she continued. "If tenants can't or won't pay rent, owners can't pay bills and a snowball starts, often culminating in the loss of buildings. No one benefits."
"Small owners need 4 percent and 6 percent increases this year," Ms. Bernstein insisted. The next day, the guidelines board formally approved the 2 and 4 percent increases.
Andrew Scherer and Peter Salins hold deeply considered, though opposing, views of the rent-regulation issue.
"The theory underlying rent regulation since its inception has been that it would affect the market in ways that would keep rents affordable," said Mr. Scherer, the author of "Residential Landlord-Tenant Law in New York" (West Group, 1999). "It is supposed to do that by placing limitations on the amount of profit that can be taken out of buildings and, while guaranteeing a reasonable return to landlords, limiting the amount that landlords could increase rents."
Particularly in recent years, however, Mr. Scherer said, "Rent regulation is having diminishing value."
For Dr. Salins, the author of "Scarcity by Design: The Legacy of New York City's Housing Policies" (Harvard University Press, 1992), "The most serious impact of continued rent regulation is the misallocation of the housing stock."
"One of the most perverse impacts," Dr. Salins said, "is that increasingly under regulation the rents being paid bear little or no relationship to the quality of the apartment. So you have very low rents on large apartments, high rents on small apartments; low rents on apartments that are ideally located or possess many amenities, higher rents on apartments with inferior locations and fewer amenities."
Mr. Scherer, who is also executive director of Legal Services, a nonprofit corporation that represents poor people in civil cases, said that even with the limits on rent increases allowed under regulation, "the rents have risen to a level that has become unaffordable to low-income people and many lower middle-class people."
Glynis Daniels, associate director of the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law, was asked to examine that assertion, using vacancy survey data. "I looked at the median household income for people living in stabilized units, and in 1999 that was $27,000," Ms. Daniels said. "So, according to the federal government's definition of a very low-income household, which for a family of four would have been no more than $26,700 in 1999, 53 percent of them were spending more than half their incomes for rent in the five boroughs."
An eventual dissipation of rent regulation would ameliorate the inequities, said Dr. Salins, who is also provost of the State University of New York. "What a market does is match the quality and the nature of the consumer goods to not only the financial means of the consumer, but to the expressed needs of the consumer," he said. "The regulated system creates both windfall beneficiaries -- small households occupying large apartments -- and a huge number of nonbeneficiaries who experience a corresponding degree of harm." The nonbeneficiaries are, he said, "a growing number of new households with large families entering the market for the first time, having to pay, as unprotected tenants, higher rents than the protected small households."
"My own assumption is that within 5 to 10 years, the impact of deregulation would be positive, with everybody entering the market on equal terms," Dr. Salins said.
To which Mr. Scherer said: "He's probably right that over time you would have a better fit between housing size and household size. But supply in New York City has never responded adequately to demand. Without regulation, housing prices would escalate throughout the city and low-income people would be priced out of the housing market entirely."
Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, a Brooklyn Democrat, is chairman of the Assembly's Housing Committee. While he is a committed supporter of rent regulation -- indeed, he sponsored the recent legislation to renew the laws early and eliminate the decontrol provisions -- Mr. Lopez is realistic. 
A special session called by the governor "is highly unlikely," he said, "and, therefore, the issue will have to be addressed in next year's session."
"Even talking about next year," Mr. Lopez said, "it's going to be a dogfight."

The Two Faces Of Rent Regulation
 Rent control applies to apartments in buildings constructed before Feb. 1, 1947, in which the tenant or an authorized successor has been in continuous occupancy since before June 30, 1971 -- the date when vacancy decontrol for rent-controlled apartments first took effect.
Rent-controlled tenants are subject to 7.5 percent rent increases in most years as well as fuel and labor cost pass-alongs that can result in actual annual rent increases of a maximum of 15 percent. 
The number of rent-controlled apartments has dropped significantly in recent years, according to the city's Housing and Vacancy Surveys, from 101,798 in 1993 to 52,562 in 1999.
Rent stabilization, which went into effect in 1969, covers buildings constructed between 1947 and 1974, as well as formerly rent-controlled apartments in pre-1947 buildings that are added to the rent-stabilized category when the units become vacant. Some post-1973 buildings have also opted to become stabilized in return for tax abatements. 
Stabilized apartments are subject to rent increases set annually by the city's Rent Guidelines Board, which is appointed by the mayor. 
The latest increases of 2 percent for a one-year lease and 4 percent for a two-year lease will go into effect on Oct. 1.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Accelerate To 65 M.P.H. Now Empty Your Pockets.

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
PUTTING a cash value on life may seem unseemly, but, just in time for the summer driving season, a couple of economists have done so in a way that may prove useful.
 To get right to the point, your life as you travel along the New York State Thruway or similar highways in other states, where the speed limit has been raised to 65 miles an hour from 55, is worth $1.54 million. No one had done that calculation before, and now we know, thanks to new research by Orley Ashenfelter of Princeton University and Michael Greenstone of the University of Chicago. 
 Your life is worth much more, of course. For your family and friends, no amount of money would be enough compensation for your loss. But in deciding in 1987 and 1988 to raise the speed limit by 10 m.p.h., the legislatures in 41 states struck a Faustian bargain. 
Don't misunderstand. You cannot run a country, a state, a city or even a village without Faustian bargains. Weighing cost against benefit -- life against the cost of preserving it or keeping people healthy -- is everyday practice in public policy. 
Even so small a matter as upgrading a water purification system to reduce the bacteria count slightly must be weighed by a town council against the cost of medical treatment for those few who would suffer upset stomachs without the upgrade. If the cost of an improved system is greater than the cost of the medical treatment, can the council members justify the outlay of tax dollars for the upgrade? On philosophical grounds, perhaps they can. A sense of well-being has a value not measurable in money. But the same money spent on school textbooks might bring even more well-being. 
Cost-benefit analysis -- unfortunately missing from most debates over water purification or military spending, for that matter -- figures prominently in determining compensation for the families of those killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. It is central in workers' compensation cases and liability suits. Juries value a life at $3.5 million, on average, one study found. Costs and benefits also play a big role in the wide-ranging struggle over how much of the environment should be sacrificed to logging, home construction, highways and the like.
But when it comes to raising speed limits, the cost in fatalities and the benefit in time saved can be known only well after the fact. Now, in the research of Mr. Ashenfelter and Mr. Greenstone, we have a first cut at the facts 15 years after the 41 legislatures raised the speed limit on Interstate highways running through rural stretches of their states. Finally, the debate can begin -- as we hurry in our cars to summer homes and resorts -- over whether to roll back the speed limit to 55 m.p.h., and spend more vacation time in our cars.
Not that the debate will begin. So many other factors take precedence. That was the case when Congress, during the oil crisis in 1974, imposed a maximum national speed limit of 55 m.p.h., concerned only with the need to conserve fuel. The happy byproduct was a sharp decline in auto fatalities. Lower speeds saved lives. But with oil plentiful again in the late 1980's, most states went back to the 65-m.p.h. limit. Truckers lobbied for the change, and so did many motorists.
Without knowing the stakes, "the legislators and the people they represented voted to lift the speed limit and save the time," Mr. Ashenfelter said.
DRAWING on data from 21 states, the Ashenfelter-Greenstone study counted the number of additional deaths at the higher speed limit from 1986 to 1993. The two economists added to their equations the speeds actually driven, getting that data from electronic highway monitors. Assuming that the hours saved could be spent at work, they valued them at an average wage of roughly $20 an hour. They multiplied the hours saved by the wage and divided the total by the additional deaths.
The results: each person killed in a crash in effect contributed through the loss of his or her life $1.54 million, adjusted for inflation, to the value of the time that was saved by the faster driving of everyone during those seven years.
Some economists say such narrow calculations should be only part of the debate over human preferences, not the driving force in making a decision. Still, $1.54 million in saved time seems grossly inadequate for the loss of a life, particularly in the summer. Millions of drivers earned their vacation pay before they set out and have nothing to gain by getting to their destinations faster.
Let's try a compromise. From the Fourth of July through Labor Day, which happens to be the busiest travel time, why not lower the speed limit back to 55?

LENGTH: 1249 words

HEADLINE: High School on Wheels Is Losing Appeal for Teenagers 

BYLINE:  By DEBORAH NETBURN 

 BODY:
LAST summer was without a doubt one of the best of Steven Alcheh's life, thanks to his 40-day $7,899 (airfare not included) teenage tour of the West Coast and Canada.
 "It was awesome," said Mr. Alcheh, 16, who is from New City, N.Y. "We got tons of freedom, we got to do whatever we wanted, and there was no camping, which was awesome because I hate camping." 
 His enjoyment was heightened by frequent stops at resort hotels with Olympic-size swimming pools. He liked the sightseeing. "We saw the important places, like the monuments and all that kind of stuff," he said. And even better, he liked shopping on Rodeo Drive and skiing at Whistler-Blackcomb, the resort in British Columbia. 
Weissman Teen Tours, the luxury tour operator Mr. Alcheh used, also runs a trip to Europe that promises to be at least as much fun -- shopping in Italy, skiing in the Alps, an English Channel cruise. But Mr. Alcheh will not be going on it this year.
"I would love to go on one of those things again, but I can't," he said. "It's too much money, and also 9/11."
Operators of teenage tours, a summer staple of well-to-do youngsters too old for sleep-away camp and too privileged to work, said that the economy and post-Sept. 11 fears have indeed taken a bite out of their business. For the moment, parents are reluctant to part with their children or their cash in uncertain times.
But teenage tours are also suffering from a bit of tiredness. Indulgence is out and impressive college resumes are in, especially for the teenagers from affluent New York suburbs and parts of Florida who have been the mainstay of such tours almost since they began in the 1960's.
"Bluntly speaking, I don't think a teen tour is a constructive use of time," said Adam Metsch, director of College Advisor of New England, a company that helps students navigate the college admissions process. "It is a vacation basically, and we don't recommend them."
In the 80's, a teenager's summer options were simple: get a job, work as a counselor in training or waiter at a sleep-away camp or see the world with 40 other fun-loving kids from the comfort of an air-conditioned bus. Last year, it is estimated that 6,000 to 7,000 teenagers, 14 to 17, took off on one of those trips. Most roughed it in dorm rooms, campsites and youth hostels, focusing on the sights -- the Grand Canyon, Yosemite -- rather than the accommodations.
But others were treated to the ultimate, top-dollar tours, hopscotching from five-star hotel to five-star hotel, stopping at the world's most desirable spots and wandering, parent-approved credit cards in hand, through stores from Milan to Beverly Hills. Prices range from about $4,000 for three weeks of hotels, dorms and camping to more than $9,000 for Weissman's European tour.
But summer activity advisers say that teenage tours are down about 25 percent this year. Weissman canceled one of the two buses it usually sends to Europe. Other companies have reported similar losses. And it's not only because of Sept. 11. 
Instead of heading for the Colosseum or the Prada store in Rome, many teenagers are on their way to tutor children in the Dominican Republic, take art history at Harvard or intern at Bear Stearns. Nowadays, teenagers have to be immersed, involved, tallying resume points and college essay themes. A teenage tour can seem a self-indulgent holdover from earlier times.
"Teen tours in general are not the way things are going," said Carey Rivers, director of Tips on Trips and Camps, a company that matches youngsters with summer programs. "It is kind of a rite of passage for certain parents and certain groups of people, but there has been such a growth in college programs and community service, and there has been a real change in what parents are looking for in terms of their money."
Not every teenager is happy about that. 
Jen Kreiger, 16, of Hollywood, Fla., went on a trip to the West Coast last summer sponsored by Musiker Tours, which has been running high-end teenage tours since 1966. Her mother, Karen, wholeheartedly supported the idea. "This is what the kids in this community know," Mrs. Kreiger said. "They go to sleep-away camp and then to fabulous programs. My main thing is I want my kids to have as much exposure to the world as they can. I can't take seven weeks off and take them to every national park there is, but it is something that I want for them so that they can feel their adolescent years are everything they want."
Teenage tours can also be high school on wheels, unhappily for those who don't fit in.
Dr. Roni Cohen-Sandler, a psychologist who specializes in teenage girls and parenthood said that she sent her daughter on two teenage tours -- the first across the United States, the second to Europe -- and regrets it. "A lot of what they do is hang out, and a lot of them just want to shop," Dr. Cohen-Sandler said. "They don't want to see the sights or learn the history." 
Two weeks into her daughter's trip to Europe, she called to come home. "They were in Italy, and they were rude, and all they wanted to do was go to Prada and buy 10 pocketbooks at a time," Dr. Cohen-Sandler said. "These girls really ruined it for my daughter. And, by the way, my daughter loves Prada, and it isn't that she doesn't like clothes. It was just too much for her, though."
Nowadays there are more things than ever for teenagers to do in the summer -- and that, experts say, they need to do. 
"I hate teen tours, and I am extremely adamant with my students that they are not going to help you in the college admissions process," said Katherine Cohen, who helps wealthy Manhattan teenagers package themselves for colleges. "Colleges are looking at the level of commitment and involvement of your summer activity."
Lee Stetson, dean of admissions at the University of Pennsylvania, agreed. "I think the preferential summer experience is something that stretches you a bit, including something in depth, like a short study program or an archaeological dig, that is a little more substantive than a tour," he said. "Travel is valuable, but in and of itself is not helpful in giving students exposure to the world."
Ms. Cohen recommends programs like Where There Be Dragons, which takes small student groups to Thailand, Laos, Tibet, Mongolia and other places, combining home stays, community service and rugged experiences. They don't come cheap: 46 days in northern India, with a home stay and service work in Dharmasala and a Himalyan trek, costs $6,550 -- but think of the essay possibilities.
Other college advisers like programs where high school students spend time on a college campus. Jeffrey Shumlin, a director of Putney Student Travel, which runs community service, college and language-immersion programs, said that about a quarter of the 1,200 students his company enrolls each year are choosing community service programs, while more than half take precollege programs. The college programs are still high: seven weeks at Williams College through Putney costs $7,495. The students take two seminar classes a day, for example, criminal law and preliminary College Board preparation.
But, Sept. 11 aside, as long as there is teenage restlessness, the need for summer supervision and parents with money, say tour operators, there will always be Paris. 
"I think that teen tours will always have a place," said Howard Fox, the director of West Coast Connections, one of the tour companies. "How lucky the kids are to do these things, if your parents can afford to do it for you."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 14, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about diminishing interest in summer travel tours for teenagers misstated the name of a tour company that provides such trips. It is Westcoast Connection Travel, not West Coast Connections. The article also misidentified the company's director. He is Mark Segal; Howard Fox is the director of American Trails West, another agency in that business.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Growth-Fund Giant Tries to Cope

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
THE bear market in stocks has been particularly dispiriting for managers of growth funds, and few more so than the British manager Amvescap P.L.C. Its United States funds, sold under the AIM Funds and Invesco brands, have had a long stretch of feeble performance. 
 Both groups have more funds with returns that rank among the worst for their objectives than among the best, and the weakness has become more acute in the last year. 
 "AIM is an aggressively growth-oriented group and Invesco is also growth oriented, and growth hasn't been working," said Phil Edwards, managing director for global fund research at Standard & Poor's.
AIM and Invesco representatives accept that their funds' performance has been poor, but they say they have taken steps to improve it. Invesco has hewn closer to benchmark stock indexes to reduce risk, while AIM has diversified into value stocks. 
"We have tried to diversify our range considerably by bringing out value products," said Ed Larson, AIM's chief investment officer. "We will continue to do that as long as we can attract good talent in that field." 
Invesco has been walloped. Just 5 of the 34 funds it offers have performed in the top 25 percent in their categories -- domestic equity, international equity, bond or money market -- during the 12 months through June 30, S.& P.'s figures show. 
Sixteen of Invesco's funds were in the bottom quarter over the period. AIM has fared better, if not well. Ten of its 56 funds had returns in the top quarter over the period, while 19 were in the bottom quarter.
Amvescap manages $400 billion worldwide -- $182 billion in AIM retail funds, $30 billion in Invesco's United States funds and the rest in foreign funds or portfolios for institutions and wealthy people.
The weakness in growth stocks has caused Amvescap's asset base to shrink, and Invesco announced last month that it was eliminating 111 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force.
Amvescap was created in 1997, when Invesco MIM, the London management company, bought AIM, which is based in Denver. Invesco's United States operations are based in Atlanta. The two divisions are run independently, but they made similar decisions about managing their portfolios as the stock market bubble inflated.
"In the late 1990's Invesco invested very aggressively in technology and other high-growth stocks, some of them pretty speculative," said Peter di Teresa, a senior analyst covering the company for Morningstar Inc. "Since the market dropped early in 2000, it clearly has been a disaster." 
One fund, Invesco Growth, maintained more than 60 percent of its assets in technology stocks through 2000 and 2001, Mr. Di Teresa noted. With the sector losing nearly three-fourths of its value from the peak in early 2000, the fund's managers must have committed more money to keep such high exposure.
"The result was a 24 percent loss in 2000 and a 49 percent loss in 2001," Mr. Di Teresa said. "As of early this year, that manager is no longer on the fund."
MANAGERS at AIM showed the same reluctance to cut their losses after the bubble popped.
AIM, whose mercurial managers specialized in trading in and out of technology stocks, had trouble maneuvering in the market even when it was rising, exacerbating the difficulties that followed. 
"Where AIM had been most successful in its brand of high-turnover growth investing was with small funds buying smaller stocks," said Bridget Hughes, a colleague of Mr. Di Teresa at Morningstar. "Ballooning assets forced the portfolios to buy larger stocks and/or own a huge list of companies."
The fund manager was also undone by waiting for clear signs of flagging earnings growth before selling positions, Ms. Hughes said.
"When tech stocks came tumbling down in early 2000, the managers still believed these companies would grow," she said. "Market sentiment was ahead of the game; AIM was not."
Mr. Edwards praised AIM's initial diversification efforts and said it had introduced some good value funds. "You might argue that AIM already has a pretty good offering," he said. 
Ms. Hughes said that by attending more to value and less to growth prospects, "the funds' performance might be more muted in a sharp market rally." 
Invesco is less inclined to diversify its product range. "We won't stray from our style," said Molly Cisneros, an Invesco spokeswoman.
Invesco managers, however, have become warier of the risks they take. "I'll admit that the risk of our funds got a little out of whack relative to the market and to our peer group," Ms. Cisneros said.
She added that Invesco had given "no thought to merging operations" with AIM, a move that some outsiders have suggested as a way to cut costs.
One important historical difference between the two fund groups no longer applies. Invesco, which previously sold its funds directly to investors, in March adopted AIM's approach of selling funds with loads, or sales charges, through brokers and advisers. 
Amvescap, of course, could acquire value funds in one big bite by buying a fund manager that specializes in that style. Mr. Edwards pointed to Alliance Capital Management's acquisition of the value house Sanford C. Bernstein as a model for such a combination. "They combined their efforts and provided a broader line of funds," he said.
An Amvescap spokesman, Douglas Kidd, declined to comment on the likelihood of such an acquisition, except to say that the company does not speculate on such matters. He noted, though, that Amvescap has acquired other fund managers.
Buying a value manager may be a good idea, but some Amvescap officials do not think the timing is right. A decline in Amvescap's own stock price means that any deal involving payment in its shares would be impractical. Amvescap's stock closed the second quarter at $:5.35, well off its peak of $:17.34 in the fourth quarter of 2000.
"You can hear all this noise about wanting to make deals, but do you want to do that when your stock is selling at its cheapest price in the last few years?" asked one Amvescap official, speaking on condition of anonymity. "The market is in a frenzy for value-style investing, and that means I ain't buying. It's a hard time for people to pony up and buy value."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Ina Battered Market, Optimism on Energy

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
DESPITE the collapse of Enron, energy stocks over all have moved modestly ahead this year, and many Wall Street analysts and fund managers are optimistic about the long-term outlook for the sector.
 The energy component of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 3.0 percent in the six months through June 30, even as the overall index fell 13.8 percent. 
 Among mutual funds, the disparity in performance is even greater. The average domestic stock fund lost 11.6 percent through June, but the average natural-resources fund -- the category that includes energy -- rose 8.9 percent, with the leaders up more than 15 percent, according to Morningstar Inc. 
One of the top performers in the sector is Ivy Global Natural Resources, which has beaten the S.& P. 500 in both good times and bad. In the 1999 bull market, the fund rose 41 percent, or 19.9 percentage points above the index, according to Morningstar. Despite the bear market last year, the fund returned 15.4 percent, and Lipper Analytical Services named it best in its category. 
Through June, the fund rose 17.3 percent, putting it in fifth place in the category, after U.S. Global Investors Global Resources, Prudential Natural Resources, RS Global Natural Resources and Van Eck Global Hard Assets. The category includes several funds that invest only in energy but they tend to be more volatile than the broader natural resources funds. Through June, Fidelity Select Energy Service was up 5.6 percent, AIM Global Energy was up 10.1 percent, and Invesco Energy was up 3.8 percent.
No one is suggesting that investors replace a core holding like an index fund with a sector fund -- an investment that tends to be far more volatile. But investors may want to consider adding a natural-resources fund with an energy focus.
Fred Sturm, who manages the Ivy fund from its home base in Toronto, said late last month that "the energy sector is vastly under-owned in the United States."
"The upside is still very attractive long term," he added.
Mr. Sturm outlined three "return seeking" strategies that he uses to keep his fund ahead of the market. The first, he said, is "core and explore -- anchor the portfolio with world-leading companies as measured by profit margins, rather than size or familiarity." One such holding is Canadian Natural Resources, an oil and gas producer. Others include Brazilian pulp and paper producers.
He also tries to "augment portfolios with companies growing through the drill bit" -- that is, well-managed, well-financed companies growing independently of the market. One holding is Hurricane Hydrocarbons, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, and has production in Kazakhstan.
The third approach, he said, is to "make significant portfolio adjustments by subsectors based on prospects for commodity prices." In late 2000, when a barrel of oil was trading in the mid-$30's, Mr. Sturm said, he began reducing the fund's exposure to energy. By September 2001, when oil prices had fallen to the $20's, he began increasing it again, and energy now accounts for 55 percent of the portfolio. As of June 30, a barrel of oil traded at $26.81.
Mr. Sturm is also adding electricity producers, including Mirant in the United States. 
He also tries to diversify his holdings within natural resources. "We are very conscious of portfolio construction and diversify by commodity, capitalization, country and individual companies," he said. 
Broader diversification can be an important reason for adding energy to a portfolio. Henry D. Cavanna, managing director and senior equity portfolio manager for J. P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management, said that because "energy behaves somewhat differently from other sectors of the market," it was valuable "as part of a diversified approach to investing." 
"North American natural gas is most attractive," he said. "They're not finding more of it, and it is the cleanest, most efficient fuel in the world, so the price should go up." Among the gas producers, Mr. Cavanna likes Devon Energy and Anadarko Petroleum. He also favors the El Paso Corporation, which has natural gas pipelines, and Exxon Mobil and ChevronTexaco among the big integrated oil companies.
Tina J. Vital, an oil and gas equity analyst at Standard & Poor's, is particularly optimistic about the big integrated oil and gas companies and drilling companies, which gained 4.6 percent through June. But, she warned, "Enronitis has thrown a taint over the whole energy sector," even though Enron was classified as a "merchant trader," not an energy company. World tensions have also dampened investor enthusiasm for energy stocks, she said.
But energy is a long-term play, she added. "The fundamentals are there," she said. "Demand should rise."
AMONG her top picks are TotalFinaElf of France; Exxon Mobil; GlobalSantaFe, an offshore drilling company; and Weatherford International, an oil-field services company.
Investors of modest means might consider diversified funds that include sizable energy holdings in their portfolios.
Daniel J. Manion, co-manager of the Sentinel Common Stock fund in Montpelier, Vt., said that a little less than 12 percent of the fund's holdings were energy-related, compared with just over 7 percent for the S.& P. 500. Although the fund slipped 7.8 percent in the first six months of the year, that is almost six percentage points ahead of the overall market. The energy holdings are one reason for the outperformance.
Mr. Manion, who is responsible for the energy portion of the portfolio, shares Ms. Vital's enthusiasm for Exxon Mobil, Weatherford and GlobalSantaFe. He said his fund has not been hurt much by problems associated with companies like Enron and Dynegy because "we have very little exposure to that end -- trading, marketing," preferring to concentrate on "assets in the ground."
Similarly, William A. Featherston, executive director and an oil and gas exploration analyst at UBS Warburg, said he was "pretty optimistic on the outlook medium term for natural gas." He predicted robust drilling activity but a drop in production capacity next year. 
Mr. Featherston has a strong-buy rating on two gas producers, Devon and Apache, and a buy on Kerr-McGee. A lot of investor money that has come out of the energy merchants has gone into the exploration and production stocks, he said, because they are asset plays for which "the accounting is pretty simple."
All the analysts caution that energy stocks are especially vulnerable to world political tensions, particularly in the Middle East, and that an overall economic recovery is needed to lift energy demand. But in the long run, they noted, energy remains fundamental to industrialized society.
