HEADLINE: Once Hot, Now Not, Cool Hunters Are in a Deep Freeze 

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA 

 BODY:
ONLY a year ago Lauren Holden, the former director of design inspiration at Nike, speculated that mainstream American teenagers would soon be wearing organic love beads, flaunting these secular rosaries as an insignia of hip. Around the same time, a number of other trend watchers for top corporations suggested that tight, calf-clutching trousers would supplant their slouchy wide-legged counterparts in the wardrobes of urban youth.
 Despite such predictions, these professed totems of vanguard chic have yet to register on the nation's fashion radar. Like capri pants for men, ballroom dancing, pipe smoking, skiboarding and wearing aprons on the street -- all once anointed by "cool hunters" as the next hot thing -- the predictions have been consigned to the scrap heap of fads, casualties of America's overheated pursuit of cool. 
 In line just behind them may be the cool hunters themselves, those anthropologists of the collective vibe who, digital cameras and notebooks in hand, scour the malls, the bodegas and skate parks from Antwerp to Los Angeles identifying youth trends for companies eager to market them. 
A street-savvy subset of the trend-forecasting industry, whose more mainstream practitioners include Faith Popcorn and Yankelovich Partners, cool hunters proliferated in the late 1990's faster than cross-stitched peasant shirts. 
Firms with names like Agent X, Lambesis, Youth Intelligence and Sputnik fed data from their scouts to clients like Coca-Cola and Sony; based on such street intelligence, Sony designed a Walkman using heavy-duty clips, like the chains young athletes wore, to hold it on. Converse created the One Star, a sneaker sandal inspired by the cholo look of Mexican girl gangs.
But now, although some cool hunters continue to prowl, the consensus is that their trade has become uncool, because it resulted in no more than a handful of successful products. 
"Cool hunting is totally over," said Irma Zandl, a marketing consultant who advises companies like Coca-Cola and Ford on trends among 18- to 24-year-olds. Her firm, the Zandl Group, has incorporated on-the-street interviews and photography for the past 15 years -- but only as one facet of a research system that also includes focus groups, demographic surveys and what it calls "crib chats," visits to the homes of young consumers. 
Corporations that relied exclusively on cool hunting to develop products have soured on it, she said, and she predicted that "in the next wave of budget cuts, cool hunters will be among the first to go." 
Ms. Zandl bemoaned the circumstances conspiring to give cool a bad name: a climate of anxiety after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, which made the restless pursuit of the new and the "in" irrelevant, and a lingering recession that has made cool too rich for most people's pocketbooks. 
Jane Rinzler Buckingham, who heads Youth Intelligence, a research firm that four years ago employed 10 part-time cool hunters, ages 14 to 30, still uses such trend scouts, but the number of clients willing to pay for their insights has dwindled in the last two years, she said. 
"With the difficulties in the economy, people don't have money to spend on lots of trends," said Ms. Buckingham, whose clients include Target and Cosmopolitan magazine. "People do want to know what's happening, what's next, but in terms of obsession with the hottest and the greatest, people are a little over it."
DeeDee Gordon, the former publisher of the L-Report, a quarterly tip sheet once deemed essential reading for students of hip, appears to regard even trend-spotting as a dirty word. 
Now a partner in Look-Look.com, an online youth culture consulting company, Ms. Gordon would not comment for this article. But several months ago she told Sportswear International, a trade monthly: "We don't consider ourselves a trend-forecasting agency. We consider ourselves an information and research company, a Bloomberg or Reuters." 
Ms. Gordon, who still collects much of her data through on-the-street interviews, added, "People need to check in and get information from kids the way they would check stocks." 
Some of the companies that used to count heavily on such independent-style sleuths would beg to differ. "Going out on the street and interviewing people -- we don't rely on that as much," said Michele Clark, manager of product trends for Lee Jeans. Ms. Clark recalled that last year Lee's in-house cool hunter raised eyebrows when she urged the company to produce clam diggers for men. "Our guy wasn't ready for that look," Ms. Clark said.
The biggest challenge that cool chasers face is the elusive nature of cool itself. "The true cool kid is a hard breed to put your finger on," Ms. Clark said. "You can't follow him around; he's going to change all the time. Copy him, and he'll move on to the next thing."
Which may be one reason that companies like Lee now factor in cool hunting as "only one piece in the research puzzle," Ms. Clark said. 
Similarly, Toyota continues to draw on cool hunting as only one small piece of its market research. The Scion bbX, the company's new concept car, with a boxy, Jeep-like design, was conceived in part with the input of an independent cool hunter, David Wales, who identifies youth lifestyle trends -- for instance, the ways in which teenagers use technology. 
"It takes somebody with a fresh perspective to go out and take notes," said Kevin Hunter, the vice president for design at Calty Research, Toyota's design studio in Newport Beach, Calif. He conceded, however, that none of Mr. Wales's specific insights have yet resulted in a tangible product. 
"Using one person can be too narrow," Mr. Hunter said. "I can see maybe using other people, architects or artists, specialists in a variety of fields." 
Increasingly pressed to prove themselves to corporate sponsors, many cool consultants have re-directed their focus from fads to macro trends: slow, sometimes meandering shifts in consumer attitudes and buying patterns, which may be more reliable than fads in helping large businesses plan their strategies. 
Ms. Zandl recalled tight pants for men as a fad that never took off. "We didn't see them happening, because people were overweight," she said. "The trend has been that people are getting fatter." 
Youth market researchers are also taking many of their style cues from mainstream kids, whose tastes proved more influential in the long term than those of their early-adaptor peers. 
In its quarterly Cassandra Report, Youth Intelligence differentiates between the brand preferences of "trendsetters" and "mainstream" kids. The latter, for instance, tend to favor Tommy Hilfiger or Polo Jeans over brands like Seven or Earl, just as, at the movies, they gravitate to crowd-pleasing performers like Adam Sandler or Tom Cruise over more adventurous actors like Russell Crowe. 
Lambesis, the Southern California ad agency that once employed Ms. Gordon, has gone back to basics in its forecasting -- combining man-in-the-street interviews with focus groups, quantitative surveys and the testing of ads for effectiveness. 
"The old trend forecasting methods relied too heavily on the interpretations of a single person: the cool guru," said Claire Brooks, the agency's director of research and planning. 
But at least one company, JNCO, a denim label in Los Angeles, is so committed to cool that it is bypassing the cool hunters and going directly to their sources -- the coolest kids on the block -- and hiring them. The company has been hiring street artists to help create products, rather than merely interpreting their tastes. Between 20 and 50 painters, some of them graffiti artists, are designing tribal logos, tattoo prints and unusual embroideries to be reproduced on T-shirts and jeans. 
"We're known as a street brand," said Michael Wallen, JNCO's president, "and we think hiring street talent is about as grass roots as you can get."

HEADLINE: Detroit's High-Speed Pursuit of the Police Car Market 

BYLINE:  By GEORGE P. BLUMBERG 

 BODY:
BAD boys, bad boys, what you gonna do when a Ford Crown Vic Police Interceptor rolls up behind you? Officers suggest that you pull over, if requested, even if you think your getaway car can outrun the Interceptor, with its 235-horsepower V-8.
 "The Ford is quick enough to reach pursuit speed without sacrificing distance between you and the car you are going after," said Police Officer Greg Reynolds of Chicago. "And it can maintain speed. It can cruise at 120 all day if you have to." 
 The Crown Victoria is the nation's most popular police cruiser, accounting for more than three-quarters of the market. But General Motors has gained a foothold with its Chevrolet Impala, now widely used in New York City, and DaimlerChrysler mounted a challenge this year with a special Dodge Intrepid. Although the Impala and Intrepid are front-drive midsize cars with V-6 engines, in contrast to the larger rear-drive Ford, they have passed muster in exhaustive track testing intended to help police agencies decide which vehicles to buy. 
Although popular, the Crown Victoria has come under a cloud because of fires that killed as many as 11 officers when their cars were struck at the rear, causing the fuel tanks to explode. Ford has created a task force to study new designs and to test safety shields and bladders inside the tanks, which are mounted between the rear bumper and axle. "It is an extremely safe vehicle that we are trying to make even safer," said Sara Tatchio, a Ford spokeswoman.
The cars have become a political issue in Arizona, where a trooper died in a crash last month, and Attorney General Janet Napolitano has urged a wide-ranging recall of the Crown Victoria and the similar Mercury Grand Marquis and Lincoln Town Car. Federal safety investigators have begun an investigation of 1992-2001 Crown Victorias, and lawsuits have been filed in Corpus Christi, Tex., and New Brunswick, N.J. Several police departments say they are reconsidering plans to buy more Crown Victorias.
Today's cop cars are like ordinary street cars, only more so. Special engine-control computer chips (and dual exhausts on Fords) enhance performance. More important, special police packages include heavy-duty brakes and steering, plus tougher suspension and engine parts, along with small features that mean a lot to an on-duty cop. For instance, there are cutouts in Ford's seats for a holster, extra-long safety belts, special wiring for lights and electronic gear and "stab plates" in the seatbacks to protect against assault from the rear.
Utility trumps luxury. "People think that police cars are magic 200 m.p.h. cars," said Dan Bedore, a Ford spokesman. "But they probably wouldn't want one. They are totally functional, with plain bucket seats and heavy rubber floormats. You can hose the whole car out if the prisoner vomits."
Ford has played a role on both sides of the cops-and-robbers horsepower race. Its low-priced V-8 sedan of 1932 gave the average criminal the ability to outrun the average police car. But in 1950, Ford offered the first police package -- a car for law enforcement with a variety of heavy-duty parts.
Officer Edwin Sanow of the Indiana Police Reserves, who is also editor of Law and Order magazine, said Ford won the police car wars from 1932 to 1968, with the Chrysler Corporation making inroads in the 1960's. Plymouth and Dodge led the market from 1969 to 1985, and the Chevy Caprice came to prominence in 1986-96.
G.M. then dropped the Caprice, leaving the Crown Victoria as the only car of the type that cops prefer: a rear-drive, four-door sedan with durable body-on-frame construction and an interior big enough to accommodate husky troopers, a profusion of electronic gear, bulging ticket books and a couple of perps.
Ford's V-8 is another attraction, even if it can't measure up to the 440-cubic-inch monster once offered by Chrysler. "Officers like lots of room to work, and the power a V-8 gives from off the line to top end," said Sgt. Keith Wilson of the Michigan State Police. "Lots of us are car and motorcycle guys, and engines can never be big enough for us. It's like if you're a carpenter, you want the biggest, baddest nail gun on the planet."
Aside from revived competition from the front-drive cars of G.M. and DaimlerChrysler, the S.U.V. craze has not bypassed police departments: Chevy Tahoes, Ford Explorers and Jeep Cherokees are among the utility vehicles being used for police work, particularly when it involves off-road duty or severe weather conditions.
The market is relatively small, with United States police departments buying about 80,000 vehicles a year, including up to 70,000 patrol cars, but highly visible. For manufacturers, these are flashing, wailing testimonials to their toughness.
Front-drive V-6's, like the Impala and Intrepid, are gaining fans among officers. Performance chips add power, and the cars get better fuel economy. With front-wheel drive, they handle better in bad weather, and they are more maneuverable.
Each year, the Michigan State Police and the National Institute of Justice put cars through rigorous tests for handling, acceleration and other factors. These tests don't pick a winner, but certify that the cars tested meet various standards for braking distances, acceleration times, road-course handling and other qualities. Within the parameters of the standards, some makes do better than others.
The most recent test, last fall, included 15 vehicles, including the Intrepid and Impala, the Chevrolet Camaro, the Ford Police Interceptor, the Hummer H1 and several sport utility vehicles from Ford, Chevrolet and Dodge.
Speaking of the Intrepid, Sergeant Wilson, one of the evaluators, said: "I felt the Dodge's handling was pretty neutral, and acceleration and top speed were very good. There's only 2 seconds' maximum difference between front- and rear-wheel drive on our handling course."
Officer Reynolds, from Chicago, agreed. "The Intrepid seemed to handle like a rear-wheel-drive car, and it also feels like a larger car, with very good acceleration." The Dodge was only half a second slower than the Ford on the handling course, has a higher top speed, and is faster to 120 m.p.h. Both beat the Impala.
In his private life, Sgt. Wilson drives a six-cylinder, front-drive Buick Regal, but he prefers the Ford when on patrol.
Captain Al Masek of the Connecticut State Police, which has ordered a few Impalas to supplement its fleet of Ford Interceptors, agreed. "We are staying with a full-frame vehicle, the Crown Vic," he said. "Because it's generally bigger and we think offers more protection and interior office room." He added that a front-drive car was more likely to suffer mechanical damage in a frontal crash, because the engine, transmission and driveline components are packed into a relatively small area.
Sticker prices for the three cars, in the $24,000 range, are largely irrelevant, given that the sales are often determined by sealed bids or negotiations. And the cost of the base car is just a start. "Communications gear, computer, G.P.S., light bars, spotlights and other equipment may add about $16,000," Captain Masek said.
More salvos are coming in the police-car wars. Ford has shown a concept version of its next Interceptor, based on the upgraded 2003 Crown Victoria. DaimlerChrysler and G.M. are developing rear-drive platforms, and it won't be long before those cars are on patrol.

HEADLINE: In Defense Of Our Wicked, Wicked Ways 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA COHEN 

DATELINE: BBURLINGTON, Vt. 

 BODY:
"I CAN stand here and look at this for hours," said James B. Twitchell as he parked himself in front of the bottled water section in City Market, just past the jars of $30-per-pound teas and behind the eight-foot display of imported olive oils. 
 Mr. Twitchell, a professor of English at the University of Florida in Gainesville, specializes in the Romantic poets, but his real obsession is shopping. Given the choice of reading literary theorists like Foucault or gazing at shelves stacked with artfully shaped bottles of water piled up like Jay Gatsby's beautifully tailored shirts, he would quickly choose the latter. "There is more that I can sustain myself with at the water aisle than in all of modern criticism," he said. 
 In a series of books, the latest of which is "Living It Up: Our Love Affair With Luxury" (Columbia University Press), Mr. Twitchell has detailed the consumption habits of Americans with all the scholarly delight of a field anthropologist who has discovered the secret courting rituals of a remote tribe. He is exquisitely attuned to the subtle gradations of status conferred by the labels on what people wear, eat, drink, drive and freeze ice cubes in. 
And he is not alone. Whether prompted by the 90's spendathon or the endless fascination not only with shopping, but with reading about shopping, a new title by an academic or journalist on the subject appears practically every week. Burlington, where Mr. Twitchell grew up and where he now spends summers, was singled out by David Brooks in his wickedly funny "Bobos in Paradise" as a model Latte Town, a city that has perfectly reconciled the mercenary instincts of the bourgeoisie with the artistic spirit of the bohemians to create an upscale consumer culture. 
What distinguishes Mr. Twitchell's study of excessive consumerism, though, is that he applauds it. To him, Evian and Pellegrino, Vermont Pure and Dasani are evidence of what could be called his trickledown theory of luxury: that the defining characteristic of today's society is the average person's embrace of unnecessary consumption, superficial indulgence, wretched excess and endless status-seeking. Oh, earthly paradise!
Once defined by exclusiveness, luxury is now available -- whether in the form of limited-edition coffee at Starbucks or Michael Graves tea kettles at Target -- to all. And that, Mr. Twitchell maintains, is a good thing. Sure, he argues in his book, buying essentially useless luxury items "is one-dimensional, shallow, ahistorical, without memory and expendable. But it is also strangely democratic and unifying. If what you want is peace on earth, a unifying system that transcends religious, cultural and caste differences, well, whoops!, here it is. The Global Village is not the City on the Hill, not quite the Emerald City, and certainly not quite what millennial utopians had in mind, but it is closer to equitable distribution of rank than what other systems have provided."
That is, to say the least, a minority report. For centuries, philosophers, artists and clerics railed against luxury. Ecclesiastical courts forbade most people from eating chocolate, drinking coffee or wearing colors like Prussian blue and royal purple -- "luxuria" that signaled living above one's God-ordered place. 
Thorstein Veblen offered the first modern critique of "conspicuous consumption" in his 1899 treatise "The Theory of the Leisure Class." Post-World War II social critics and economists extended Veblen's critique to the expanding middle class. John Kenneth Galbraith warned in "The Affluent Society" of the binge afflicting the postwar generation. Unwitting consumers, he said, were essentially suckered by admen and salesmen into spending money on things they didn't need. 
In his 1970 study "The Cultural Contradictions of Capitalism" Daniel Bell argued that "the culture was no longer concerned with how to work and achieve, but with how to spend and enjoy." This trend, he warned, could end up undermining the very work ethic that made capitalism function. 
That, obviously, did not happen. If anything people worked more so they could spend more. In "The Overspent American," Juliet B. Schor noted that people no longer compared themselves with others in the same income bracket, but with the richer and more famous they saw on television, propelling them to spend more than they could afford. 
To Mr. Twitchell, the naysayers are scolds and spoilsports. Indoor plumbing, sewing machines, dishwashers, college educations, microwaves, coronary bypasses, birth control and air travel all began as luxury items for the wealthy. 
Nor are buyers mindlessly duped by canny advertisers into buying items they don't really want, he said. Quite the opposite. They enjoy the sensual feel of an Hermes silk tie, the briny delicacy of Petrossian caviar or simply the sensation of indulging themselves. These things may not bring happiness, but neither does their absence from the lives of people too poor to afford them.
It may seem an odd moment to champion luxury. The spectacular boom of the 90's now looks as if it was partly built on spectacular sleight of hand, with Enron, Global Crossing, Adelphia and WorldCom all recently admitting that billions in reported profits were nonexistent. The moment seems ripe for a chastened culture to repent its indulgences. Reassessing the get-and-spend ethic -- not defending consumerism -- might well be the defining current of the next few years. 
The problem with Mr. Twitchell's view, said Robert H. Frank, author of "Luxury Fever," is that our sense of what we need to live comfortably keeps spiraling upward. It is not that luxury spending isn't good for particular individuals, but that it is bad for society overall. "It's like when everybody stands up for a better view, you don't see better than before," Mr. Frank said from his home in Ithaca. There's a lot of waste in luxury spending. Instead of building safer roads or providing better health care, we are spending that money on bigger diamonds and faster cars. 
Mr. Twitchell is unpersuaded, however. Walking down Church Street, Burlington's busy pedestrian mall, he pointed out the transformation that the consumer culture has wrought in his hometown. Lean and tanned, with cropped gray hair and rounded tortoise-shell glasses, Mr. Twitchell looks a bit like Dennis the Menace's father after Dennis has grown up, moved across the country and given his old man a few years to recover. "Church Street once serviced needs, now it services desires," Mr. Twitchell said. The optician's shop is gone, and so is Sears and JCPenney. He pointed out the Ann Taylor store, where the Masonic temple used to be. A chic French children's store sits in the old bank.
"The key to modern luxe is that most of us can have a bit of it on the plate," Mr. Twitchell said. "I can't own a Lexus, but I can rent one. I can't go to Bermuda for a winter, but I can have a time share for a weekend. I don't own a yacht but I'm taking a Princess cruise." 
The process of democratization is mirrored in Mr. Twitchell's family history. His great-grandfather Andrew A. Buell made his fortune building wooden boxes from Adirondack lumber. Driving up Lodge Road to "the hill," where Mr. Buell built a red stone Romanesque mansion with a copper-topped tower, Mr. Twitchell passed the Burlington Country Club, which his grandfather Marshall Coleman Twitchell helped found. The family's sprawling former home is now a women's dormitory, and the surrounding 66-acre estate serves as the University of Vermont's Redstone campus. A couple of blocks from the hilltop, both in location and status, is the relatively modest white wooden house that Mr. Twitchell, the son of Marshall Coleman Twitchell Jr., an ophthalmologist, and his sisters grew up in. 
At that time, said Mr. Twitchell, now 59, one's social place was determined by birth, or "what I call the lucky sperm culture." Today, birth-ordained status has been supplanted by store-bought status. Mr. Twitchell has no regrets about this lost world. "Though I was a beneficiary of it, I'm glad it's over," he said. "There is something refreshing about the material world that downtown Burlington opened up." Compared to the traditional ways of marking status -- race, parentage, accent, private schools -- one's purchases are a preferable way of telling who's up and who's down, he said. 
On that point, Mr. Twitchell is not alone. Gary Cross, a historian at Penn State University, said that consumer culture in one sense is "democracy's highest achievement, giving meaning and dignity to people when workplace participation, ethnic solidarity and even representative democracy have failed."
Still, as Mr. Cross argued in 2000 in "An All-Consuming Century: Why Commercialism Won in Modern America," "most of us, no matter our politics, are repulsed by the absolute identity of society with the market and individual choice with shopping."
True enough, Mr. Twitchell readily conceded. But he maintains the critics are missing the essential characteristic of luxury spending. "Luxury has very little to do with money or things," he said. "Luxury is a story we tell about things," and it's ultimately the story we are after. That is, our purchases are imbued with elaborate narratives about the life we want to live. 
It is advertisers and manufacturers who give objects meaning by constructing the stories about them, Mr. Twitchell said, and that meaning is as much a source of desire as the object itself. Think of the elaborate fantasies spun by marketers like Ralph Lauren and Martha Stewart.
It goes for whatever you're buying, whether it's Jimmy Choo, Birkenstock or Payless shoes. When Mr. Twitchell, a dedicated factory outlet shopper, flashes his member's card at Sam's Club, "the allure is not just that I'm saving money," he said, "but that I'm smarter and savvier, that I'm duping the duper."
Or consider an experiment he performed on his colleagues. He told some English professors that he was going to spend $6,000 to buy an 1850 copy of Wordsworth's "Prelude." Brilliant idea, everyone said. A few days later, Mr. Twitchell told the same colleagues that he had changed his mind and was going to use the $6,000 to buy a used BMW. "I could have said that I was investing in a collection of Beanie Babies comics or a diamond pinkie ring for the shocked response that I got," he wrote.
Critics of consumption will say they are making a moral argument, Mr. Twitchell said, but "often what is condemned as luxury is really just a matter of taste."
To Mr. Twitchell, as long as human beings crave sensation, they will desire material goods and luxurious ones at that, Wall Street scandals notwithstanding. "If this year it's Enron and WorldCom, then another year it was Long-Term Capital Management," he said. 
Recessions may come and go, but consumption is eternal. The ad slogan is right: Diamonds are forever.

HEADLINE: Bringing Discipline (and Scorecards) to Nursing Homes 

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON 

DATELINE: FORT SMITH, Ark. 

 BODY:
SITTING in a conference room at the headquarters here of Beverly Enterprises, the nation's largest nursing home chain, William R. Floyd, its chairman and chief executive, is arguing that providing nursing care to the elderly is not all that different from selling tacos at a fast-food chain.
 "There really are an enormous number of similarities between this and the world I came from," said Mr. Floyd, 57, an intense but self-effacing executive who spent seven years at PepsiCo, most of them at Taco Bell. Recruited to Beverly in April 2000, he was appointed chief executive 10 months later and has spent the last year and a half working to turn around the beleaguered company. 
 Beverly, which had revenue of $2.71 billion last year, operates multiple units, just as a chain of restaurants does, he said. The company also relies heavily on low-wage employees -- nursing assistants -- to provide care. "Taco Bell competes with Beverly for these people," Mr. Floyd said. 
But there are obvious differences. To an industry known for lax, decentralized management of its facilities and little innovation, Mr. Floyd brings a keen emphasis on accountability and is experimenting with more than a dozen new, potentially more profitable health care services.
By setting clear financial goals for his managers and by linking their pay to the quality of care, he has already improved the company's profitability and says it is providing better care.
Before he can declare victory, however, Mr. Floyd faces many challenges, most recently a criminal investigation by the state of California into 46 citations for inadequate patient care at 20 facilities. While the incidents took place from 1998 to 2001, they are a stark reminder of Beverly's frequent run-ins with regulators over how it treats its residents and the prevailing image of a nursing home as a place where no one wants to be.
Last year, for example, a Beverly home in Santa Barbara, Calif., that accounted for 25 of the 46 citations, was fined by the state health department for failing "to properly care for a resident who was fed through a stomach tube, resulting in severe infection and his death." That nursing home, which is also the subject of several private lawsuits, is part of the state's inquiry.
Beverly sold that home last year and is in discussions with regulators about the citations. A settlement could be reached as soon as this month, most likely including a substantial fine. The company also expects to be asked to plead guilty to a criminal charge, but has made no decision on that. In a case brought by California last year against another national chain, the Sun Healthcare Group, a unit of that company pleaded "no contest" to a felony charge and the whole company agreed to improve staffing and oversight.
Beyond the regulatory cases, Beverly and the entire industry, of course, face tremendous uncertainty about federal and state reimbursement policies. When Medicare changed how it paid for care a few years ago, many operators went through bankruptcy reorganizations, including public companies like Kindred Healthcare and Genesis Health Ventures.
Investors remain wary of the industry, and they are unlikely to warm to it. Cuts in state and federal budgets for nursing home care are a distinct possibility as states retrench because of falling tax receipts and as Congress debates funding for Medicare. While praising Beverly's management, Friess Associates, an investment management company that had been a large holder of the stock, recently sold its position over concerns about possible cuts in Medicare reimbursement rates.
Mr. Floyd refuses to adopt what he calls the industry's tendency to view itself as a victim, but he still faces the daunting task of convincing regulators, investors, the public and his own employees that Beverly can escape its past. Over the years, regulators have persistently raised questions about the quality of care that Beverly provides, and the new management team must somehow take what is essentially a low-growth and low-margin business and create something dynamic.
WHEN Mr. Floyd arrived two years ago, Beverly was close to bankruptcy. That February, it had agreed to pay the federal government $175 million to settle the industry's largest allegation of Medicare fraud. The company's stock, which traded as high as $17.50 in late 1997, had plummeted to a low of $2.50.
"He asked a lot of tough questions," said Marilyn R. Seymann, a Beverly director who spent several hours with Mr. Floyd before he began his new job. "I sugar-coated nothing."
In 1998, he left as chief executive of Choice Hotels International, which franchises the Comfort Inn, Econo Lodge and other brands, after finding that he did not have the support of the board or the previous chief executive. He spent the next year and a half, when not climbing mountains, considering his options.
Upon his arrival, Mr. Floyd saw an opportunity to make Beverly a leader in an industry badly in need of one. Despite its leading position, Beverly accounts for just 3 percent of the nation's 1.8 million nursing-home beds, with many of its homes in California, Pennsylvania and Arkansas. Most rivals are for-profit businesses, ranging from large public companies like Manor Care to scattered regional chains to small operators. Many facilities struggled or even failed after the Medicare cuts of the late 1990's and fierce competition from assisted-living centers -- residences that offer some services and appeal to people who shudder at the thought of being in a nursing home.
Because many states limit the number of nursing-home beds, the competition is not as intense as it might be otherwise. "Within a market, they compete with each other over relationships with referral sources," like hospitals, said Jerry L. Doctrow, a senior analyst at Legg Mason Wood Walker.
Many of Beverly's residents arrive directly from hospitals. After receiving some form of rehabilitative therapy, about half leave within six months.
Mr. Floyd said he found a company with no clear direction and with a management team that was badly demoralized. He quickly replaced many of Beverly's senior managers. Blaise J. Mercadante, a marketing colleague from Taco Bell who also spent some time as a senior marketing executive at Universal Studios, now oversees marketing and business innovation. Jeffrey P. Freimark, who had run the Grand Union supermarket chain while it tried to reorganize under bankruptcy laws, was recruited as chief financial officer.
Mr. Floyd also introduced Beverly to the kind of accountability found at companies like PepsiCo, where managers must deliver results, said Kevin Jones, a portfolio manager at ICM Asset Management, which has invested in Beverly stock. Before Mr. Floyd arrived, "there wasn't a whole lot of focus on execution," Mr. Jones said.
The new chief executive has been relentless in demanding performance from individual facilities, one-fifth of which he identified as poor performers in early 2001. Each is judged by a scorecard, on which factors like pretax income, employee turnover, occupancy, bad debt and quality of care are measured. Many have improved, and 14 were closed or sold last year.
Because Florida accounted for most of Beverly's liability costs and just 10 percent of revenue, the company also simply left that market, selling about 50 nursing homes early this year.
Although Beverly remains significantly less profitable than Manor Care, which had operating margins of 13.7 percent last year, compared with Beverly's 9 percent, its financial position has improved. Its margin reached 9.6 percent in the first quarter of 2002. The company reported a loss last year, largely a result of the settlement with the federal government and a $238 million write-off, but cash from operations reached $221 million, compared with $37 million in 2000.
Beverly's stock, which topped $12 a year ago before a fresh wave of concerns over reimbursement levels, is now trading at $7.30.
"It's a turnaround company in an industry that is scarred," said Tom Price, who works for MFP Investors, which has invested in Beverly and hopes for more improvement. "There's another whole round of rationalization the business can do."
Beverly's facilities are now under much tighter corporate control, and Mr. Floyd has replaced one-third of the local managers. "I preach the gospel of the importance of the front lines," he said. Area directors of operations are now responsible for about 10 homes each, about half the number they had been overseeing.
Mr. Floyd spent a week at a California facility when he first joined Beverly. He worked all three shifts at the home, working side by side with a nursing assistant, even helping to change residents' diapers.
At Taco Bell, he had asked potential executives to work with a restaurant crew, and he is now asking every senior executive at Beverly to work for some time at a nursing home. "You gain so much respect," he said. "People will walk over broken glass for you."
To increase occupancy levels and reduce its dependence on government payments, Beverly is emphasizing new services like units specializing in the care of Alzheimer's patients, many of whom pay privately and therefore higher fees than Medicare or Medicaid. Located in separate wings, these new units are intended to provide something of a home-like atmosphere with carpeting, wallpaper and comfortable furniture, in contrast to the linoleum floors and institutional feel of the industry's typical facilities. Patients are given much more individual care and can take part in special programs.
Seventy-six of Beverly's facilities now offer Alzheimer's units, and the company plans to add about 30 more by year-end. In addition to 29 assisted-living centers, Beverly also offers home health care, therapy and hospice care.
Mr. Floyd, however, must still fundamentally rethink how Beverly operates in an industry that is accused of largely warehousing the people it is supposed to care for. Beverly is already trying to innovate, by introducing strength-training programs, for example, that use special exercise equipment that it developed with the Nautilus Group. It is also exploring how to personalize care by assigning a team of employees to a specific small group of residents.
And Mr. Floyd has yet to answer a big question for Beverly: "How do you grow the company?" said Nancy L. Weaver, an analyst who follows the company at Stephens Inc.
He is trying to make the most of Beverly's skills, like providing therapy and nursing care, whether at someone's home or at another facility. Beverly's rehabilitative therapy unit, for example, renamed Aegis Therapies, accounted for more than $180 million in revenue last year.
UNDER the direction of Mr. Mercadante, the former Taco Bell executive, Beverly is also exploring other related businesses. Some are already generating revenue, like ones providing management and procurement services to other nursing homes. It is also working with some drug companies to find whether the data its homes collect about its patients' medication may be useful in expanding the use of some drugs.
Among the other possibilities it is considering are services to older prison inmates. The proportion of prisoners aged 55 and above is expected to double, to about 20 percent, by 2012.
But improving the quality of care remains the main challenge. Some consumer advocates say Beverly still provides poor care at many of its sites. "I haven't seen a difference," said Patricia L. McGinnis, the executive director of the California Advocates for Nursing Home Reform, a nonprofit group.
To focus attention on quality issues, Mr. Floyd has linked compensation directly to quality improvements. Sixty percent of the bonus for a local manager depends on quality factors, like whether regulators find fault with care during their yearly reviews and how many residents are being restrained or heavily medicated. Even 20 percent of the bonus for corporate executives is tied to better quality.
Trying to reduce the number of patients suffering from pressure sores, for example, Beverly bought $2.5 million worth of special bedding. The company set a goal of having no more than an average of 3 percent of its patients suffer from bed sores; it managed to get the average down to a new low of 2.6 percent, according to Patrice K. Acosta, the senior vice president of professional services.
"The real issue is changing the culture," said Mr. Floyd, adding that such changes usually take a couple of years. "I'm seeing a momentum being established."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The Endless City vs. Its Closing Frontier

BYLINE:  By GREGORY RODRIGUEZ; Gregory Rodriguez is a senior fellow at the New America Foundation, a nonpartisan research institute.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
LOS ANGELES is the only big city built on the promise of the suburban dream. Unlike New York, where migrants move to be part of a continuing civic enterprise, the genius and fundamental weakness of Los Angeles is that you rarely feel obliged to be part of anything. Nothing short of cataclysmic events like riots, earthquakes or a Lakers championship can ignite a strong sense of civic unity.
 Southern California's appeal has always been its temperate weather and the allure of the good life. Yet the power of its idyllic image also sowed the seeds of its destruction. Migrants who came to lead a serene suburban existence now find themselves in a sprawling, traffic-jammed metropolis. This tension between the city's contemporary urban reality and its founding suburban myth now threatens to tear Los Angeles apart. 
 This November, city voters will decide whether the San Fernando Valley, home to roughly 40 percent of Los Angeles residents, will secede from the nation's second largest city. Locally, the issue is cast as one of services, governance and revenue flows. Nationally, the issue has been seen as a clash between city and suburb. Yet at the heart of the battle are more basic issues of urban identity. Secessionists are tapping into the Valley's longtime sense of suburban cultural grievance. However, they are doing so at a time when America's quintessential suburb is as urban as the rest of Los Angeles.
If suburbia is a collective effort to lead a private life, then Los Angeles has been the most private of cities. It was a suburban city decades before America became the first suburban nation. In the 1920's, as Midwesterners flocked to the region, developers built close to 3,200 subdivisions and 250,000 detached homes. By 1930, a stunning 94 percent of dwellings in Los Angeles were single-family homes. 
But the city fathers envisioned a major metropolis. Men like William Mulholland, who built the California Aqueduct, and Harry Chandler, who ran The Los Angeles Times, willed a new kind of low-density, multipolar big city into existence. What they did not do was warn the suburbanites that greatness would come at a price.
"There is a constant friction in L.A. between the fundamentally suburban vision of the life we want to lead and our aspirations to be a great city," said Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University.
Even as Los Angeles evolved into an expansive and decentralized Western city, its cultural elite still took its cues from more traditional Eastern cities. They mimicked the New York intelligentsia's contempt for suburbia, and the San Fernando Valley became the most convenient target for their disdain. Just as sophisticated Manhattanites often deride the "bridge and tunnel crowd," residents of tony West Los Angeles weren't above feeling superior to Valley residents. 
Yet, unlike most American suburbs, which developed beyond city limits, the Valley could never find solace in sovereignty. Annexed by Los Angeles in 1915, the San Fernando Valley became a bedroom community where professional and middle-class families could carve out quiet lives within the city limits. 
"It's the one suburb that is an appendage to its tormentor," said D. J. Waldie, author of "Holy Land: A Suburban Memoir." "In an era when cultural elites identify themselves by their aesthetic privilege, many feel it necessary to diminish the popular, the ordinary, the everyday, the suburban."
But half-century-old stereotypes do not do justice to America's contemporary suburban reality. Once scorned for being racially homogenous, economically parasitic and culturally vacuous, suburbia is now more likely to be mixed, viable and vital.
"Much of this country's creativity -- like Silicon Valley or the biotech industry -- is being done by people who eat at Fuddruckers, shop at big box malls and live in suburbia," said David Brooks, the author of "Bobos in Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There."
Last year, a Brookings Institution study found that racial and ethnic diversity in the nation's suburbs rose substantially in the 1990's and that nonwhites were responsible for the bulk of suburban population gains.
THE San Fernando Valley, close to 90 percent white and overwhelmingly middle class in 1960, is now one-third foreign born and almost half Latino. Its mixed economy routinely outperforms the rest of the city in job creation. 
With 1.35 million residents, a new Valley city would be the sixth-largest city in the country, as well as one of the most diverse. Like other big cities, it would have sizable pockets of poverty, blight and gang violence. The crime, drugs and dilapidated housing in some Valley neighborhoods rival the worst conditions in the more well-known inner-city areas of Los Angeles.
"Demographic differences are not the cause of the Valley secession movement," said William Frey, a demographer at the Milken Institute in Santa Monica, Calif. "It's about the periphery coming back to bite the core. They are saying they are just as important."
Disgruntled residents would once have just moved to the new subdivision. For at the root of secessionism is the same urge to elude urbanity that created the city's sprawl. But now that the city has reached its geographic limits and environmentalists seek to preserve the remaining open space, there are no new places to go. 
"We can't act out our suburban dream anymore," says William Fulton, an urban planner and author of "The Reluctant Metropolis." "So what do we do?"
One option has been to turn inward. In the last decade, Los Angeles has become a city of neighborhoods. The 1992 riots were a powerful catalyst for this movement. Many neighborhoods resurrected names that had long been forgotten. Others invented new ones. "Los Angeles traditionally looked outward," says Gregory J. Fischer, a local historian. "Well, there's no 'out' to look at anymore. We've gone as far as we can go. The logical next step is to look back at what you've created."
Yet rather than come to terms with the city they helped build, advocates for secessionism are harking back to the sales pitch at the heart of the history of Los Angeles. "Secessionism tells us that L.A. is still vulnerable to the seductive siren call of suburban narcissism," said Kevin Starr, the state librarian and author of a multivolume history of California. But this seduction is only possible because Los Angeles has never bothered to recalibrate its self-image and draft a new post-suburban narrative. Los Angeles still considers itself the quintessentially anti-urban city.
The problems of the early 1990's made it fashionable for the city that had long fancied itself a paradise to be characterized as a new circle of hell. Utopia became dystopia. But caricatures aside, Angelenos had not seriously grappled with their city's identity until secessionism gained momentum over the last few years.
It was the threat of secession that led to the inclusion of neighborhood councils in the new city charter. More recently, secessionism has prompted talk of splitting the city into boroughs. There is debate about the value of bigness and the beauty of smallness. Complicating matters, Hollywood secession is also on the November ballot.
"Los Angeles was built on the idea that one could create a more perfect place, a New Jerusalem, one's own private Idaho," said Mr. Waldie. The question now is whether voters will be able to reimagine their city as something other than heaven or hell. If Los Angeles is to remain whole, Angelenos will first have to embrace the imperfections of their urban reality and come to terms with the closing of their suburban frontier.

HEADLINE: Capitalism Depends on Character 

BYLINE:  By Jean Strouse; Jean Strouse is the author of "Morgan: American Financier."

 BODY:
When the late 19th-century counterparts of Enron, WorldCom and Global Crossing got into trouble, the investment banker J. Pierpont Morgan took over, allegedly growling at rogue managers, "Your company belongs to my clients." 
 The companies in question were railroads, which brought about productivity changes as revolutionary (and as lucrative) as those derived from information and communications technology 100 years later. In the booming 1880's, 75,000 miles of new track were laid, more than in any previous decade anywhere in the world, and the capital invested in American railroads rose from $2.5 billion in 1870 to $10 billion by 1890. The size of private fortunes soared: railroad barons worth more than $100 million in 1889 included Jay Gould, Leland Stanford and the heirs of Cornelius Vanderbilt. 
 The prospect of immense wealth led, as it does in all speculative bubbles, to overbuilding, fierce competition, widespread corruption and economic collapse. Wildcat promoters sold worthless securities to eager investors with dollar signs in their eyes, or built shoddy roads parallel to existing tracks, hoping to force the older lines to buy them out. Buccaneer managers manipulated the securities of their own roads, plundered capital reserves, bribed politicians and formed bogus construction companies to charge exorbitant fees that they willingly paid -- to themselves.
Often it was hard to tell good guys from bad guys: "Commodore" Vanderbilt and Jay Gould ran successful railroads using outlaw tactics. Government had neither the power nor the mandate to impose order on this chaotically growing industry. J. P. Morgan did -- since he controlled its access to capital. 
His firm raised funds for America's railroads by selling bonds and preferred stock abroad. The emerging United States economy did not have the resources to build enormously expensive roads, but foreign investors who had been rooked by profiteering pirates were not about to send more money 3,000 miles across the Atlantic without some guarantee that it would be safe. Morgan essentially provided that guarantee, choosing solid properties and taking what he called "moral responsibility" for companies whose securities he underwrote. When a road he had backed went bankrupt, he and his partners stepped in, saying in effect "we control the company, or no bailout." The pattern of what came to be called "Morganization" involved scrutinizing every aspect of a railroad's operations, restructuring its finances, raising capital, settling lawsuits, firing managers, hiring new ones, appointing directors, and keeping vigilant watch over the company's finances, sometimes for decades, until solvency was restored.
Morgan had plenty of critics -- he was a domineering plutocrat more concerned with building giant trusts and maintaining the international value of the dollar than with the struggles of American farmers and workers or the social costs of industrialization. Nonetheless, in a time of cowboy capitalism he was an honest broker representing thousands of widely dispersed stock- and bondholders who owned "new economy" railroads but had no effective control over the managers who ran them. In the course of his career he helped make American markets credible to foreign investors, kept the flow of capital moving east to west and transformed railroad securities from high-risk speculations into stable, long-term investments.
What the new new economy needs in the wake of recent scandals is a force comparable to Morgan's. Someone has to stand behind the fundamental accuracy of a company's financial statements in a legally responsible way, but derelict auditors, executives and boards of directors have defaulted, either by design or inexcusable ignorance. A second tier of guardians -- Wall Street analysts, rating agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission -- failed to issue warnings of corporate deceit. As a result, foreign investors are no less spooked than they were in the 1890's, and American shareholders have flipped from euphoria to gloom. Excessive fear is choking off the market's access to capital, hurting sound companies as well as crooks -- even though the economy appears to be recovering and there are few attractive alternatives to American stocks. The evil-doers at WorldCom, Enron and company have done more than Al Qaeda to undermine confidence in American capitalism. Not since the 1930's has there been such a shudder of revulsion against big business. 
To some extent we're in the mop-up that inevitably follows market manias. (Referring to the boom-and-bust cycles of 19th-century America, John Kenneth Galbraith said that the intervals between panics corresponded roughly with the time it took people to forget the last disaster.) Potential chief executives are now doing rigorous due diligence before taking big jobs. Arthur Andersen is out of business, Enron is in court, WorldCom is toast. Punishing losses have made it clear that investing entails real risk. But the deposed miscreants made off with millions while company employees and ordinary investors were wiped out.
Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill said recently that corporate executives who falsely certify company finances should go to jail -- which sounds like a good idea, although white collar criminals can usually afford terrific defense lawyers. Capital markets do not work effectively unless people believe in their essential integrity. Investors will only take necessary risks if the game isn't rigged. 
In today's vast, complex markets, no one can play J. P. Morgan, but a remark he made near the end of his life is worth recalling. Asked by the lawyer for a congressional investigating committee in 1912 whether bankers issued commercial credit only to people who already had money or property, Morgan said, "No sir; the first thing is character." The skeptical lawyer repeated his question and Morgan, in Victorian terminology, elaborated on his answer -- "because a man I do not trust could not get money from me on all the bonds in Christendom."

HEADLINE: Intrigue at the Palazzo Agnelli 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL with DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: ROME 

 BODY:
AS Gianni Agnelli, the patriarch of Italian industry and dynastic head of the Fiat auto and industrial empire, lay in a New York hospital bed in May and early June, even some of his best friends had sadly given up hope that he would survive prostate cancer.
 But when a rumor of the death of the 81-year-old Mr. Agnelli swept Italian markets, Fiat's ailing stock leapt by 6 percent. Some investors hoped that the departure of a man whom Italians call "l'Avvocato" -- the lawyer -- would hasten the sale of the chronically money-losing auto division that has powered the intertwined destinies of Fiat and the Agnelli family since the company was founded in 1899. 
 To investors, it was Mr. Agnelli's stubborn commitment to his family's roots in the car business that was preventing the company -- whose fortunes he once said were synonymous with Italy's -- from entering a new, post-automotive era. 
Mr. Agnelli, of course, survived and is undergoing chemotherapy at his home near Turin. But the incident provided a foretaste of what may well be in store for him, his dynasty and his business. 
Now the honorary chairman of Fiat, he has reigned for an often triumphant, often turbulent 36 years during which myth and man have fused in an artfully tended image of raffish wisdom, international celebrity and Machiavellian manipulation. 
To many Italians, he is an institution whose influence once seemed boundless. Besides the flagship Fiat, his family holding companies control a newspaper and a star-studded soccer team. His pivotal influence on public life here was rewarded with life membership in the Italian senate. In his prime, paparazzi trailed him from Alpine ski resorts to the yacht basins of the Riviera. Along the way, he became the personification of the nation's ability to strut on a global stage long before globalization became a concept, an enduring symbol of Italian manhood blending playboy looks and entrepreneurial grit.
Yet, as the exaggerated rumors of his death spread, it appeared as if the empire had entered its darkest hour, deeply in hock to the banks and unloved by investors, its top management in turmoil and its auto plants producing far more cars than anyone seemed to want to buy. Since its peak in 1998, Fiat's stock has dropped to about 12.9 euros, from nearly 45 euros. 
"This is a very bad moment for Fiat; we are not going to hide that," Susanna Agnelli, Mr. Agnelli's 80-year-old sister, said in an interview in her elegant dove-gray sixth-floor apartment, filled with books and fine paintings, overlooking the Quirinale Palace in central Rome.
After a recent spate of loans, asset disposals and other maneuvers, Fiat's chairman, Paolo Fresco, contends that the company has some breathing room. But its travails could scarcely have come at a worse time for the family that has long regarded it as both fief and cash cow. 
THE Agnelli dynasty, created in the late 19th century by Gianni Agnelli's grandfather, Giovanni, embraces about 150 descendants -- cousins, nephews, nieces, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Of them, some work, some do not, and 80 have shares in the family-owned Giovanni Agnelli & Company, which controls the empire. This year, Forbes magazine estimated the family's worth at $2.3 billion, down from $5 billion in 2000, and shares of two publicly traded holding companies controlled by the Agnellis have lost about two-thirds of their market value in the last few years, largely because of their exposure to Fiat.
In other words, the number of family members clamoring for a slice of the pie is growing just as the pie is shrinking, and just as the family's control over the business faces an unparalleled challenge from bankers demanding reductions in Fiat's debt. That, said Antonio Tonioli, an analyst at ING Barings in Milan, means that the family's fortunes depend directly on Fiat's ability to make the car business profitable or to sell it.
With Mr. Agnelli hobbled by illness, those who follow the family's fortunes much as Kremlin watchers once studied the Soviet empire perceive two important shifts in power. In one, Mr. Agnelli's often-eclipsed younger brother Umberto, 68, who had been shoved aside in a palace conspiracy worthy of the Medicis, has gained a measure of influence. In the other, John Philip Elkann, 26, a grandson of Gianni Agnelli, seems to have been designated heir apparent, a move that may ruffle investors' feathers at a time when corporate governance is a prime concern.
These chapters have unfolded after a long and painful story, one that recalls a Kennedyesque blend of glamour, power and loss. In it, untimely death has stalked the Agnelli family, offering uncanny parallels between the early demise of the parents of Gianni and Umberto Agnelli and that of both of their sons.
The newest uncertainties became apparent in 2000 when Fiat, worried about the future of Fiat Auto as an independent company, sold 20 percent of it to General Motors in a $2.4 billion stock swap. G.M. saw the deal as strengthening its position in Europe, where it owns the Opel and Saab brands, and in South America, where Fiat has interests in auto- and truck-making, in components and in other industrial plants, mainly in Brazil and Argentina. 
But the deal also required G.M. to acquire the remainder of Fiat Auto from 2004 to 2009 under a put option to be exercised by Fiat. In light of the company's slide, some analysts have begun to question the wisdom of that agreement. "At the time, it must have seemed like a good idea; I guess you had to be there," said Ron Tadross, an analyst at Bank of America. "Right now, I can't see a good reason why you would do this transaction."
Last year, Fiat Auto and General Motors Europe had combined losses of $1.3 billion. "Given that the financial situation of both companies has deteriorated, there's concern from investors," said Stephen Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. Far from strengthening G.M. in Europe, the Fiat deal may well weaken it.
Much more upheaval is likely. Fiat Auto has long relied on a protected Italian market, but the gradual removal of barriers has exposed it to European and Japanese rivals. Though it is still heavily dependent on Italian sales, its share of the home market has dropped to about 31 percent from almost two-thirds in the early 1990's. Fiat's share of the Western European car market is down to 8.8 percent from 10.4 percent only a year ago. Its range of cars and dealership facilities is limited. Although it owns the once-exclusive Lancia and Alfa Romeo marques, its high-end cars are not serious challengers to BMW or Mercedes, while its midrange and small cars lag behind those of rivals like Volkswagen.
This year alone, Fiat Auto, which has not reported a profit since 1997, expects to lose at least a further $540 million, the same as last year.
According to former Fiat managers who spoke on condition of anonymity, Fiat Auto's difficulties stem in part from its failure to break away from its small-car roots in the 1990's, when it became apparent that the cost of technology that buyers expect in features like antilock brakes and electric windows would cut the profit margin on small cars to zero.
"At a certain moment, they should have concentrated on building cars that people wanted to buy," said Ms. Agnelli, the only senior member of the dynasty who agreed to be interviewed. "They should have concentrated on making better cars."
In May, Fiat had to negotiate a rescue package of 3 billion euros (nearly $3 billion) with Italian banks in return for a pledge to cut its net debt of 6.5 billion euros by half by year-end. 
To do that, the company has begun selling assets, including 14 percent of Italenergia, its energy division, and a one-third stake in Ferrari, the maker of luxury sports cars that is one of its crown jewels. In June, it sold $200 million worth of new shares in its American agricultural tractor unit, Case New Holland. But the pressure to cut debt further is building fast.
Teksid, Fiat's foundry business, is being sold to Questor, a private American finance company, and more disposals of Fiat subsidiaries are in the works, including its Magnetti Mirelli auto components business and its Comau tooling unit. Mr. Fresco has also hinted that Fiat might reduce its stake in its truck and aerospace units.
But the core of the rescue lies with the loan extended by Italian banks. Ominously, that package stipulates that if Fiat does not meet its debt-reduction target, the loan can be converted into additional shares, diluting the Agnelli family's 30 percent stake in Fiat unless family members put up around a billion euros to soak up the new shares. "The family's influence on the company could be under threat unless the company meets these debt targets," said John Lawson, an analyst at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney in London.
Significantly, the family has been systematically reducing its exposure to Fiat. A decade ago, Fiat represented 80 percent of the Agnellis' portfolio; now it is less than half.
As it diversified, the family took stakes in dozens of businesses, including tourism, paper and the Rinascente retail chain. It has long owned the Juventus soccer team in Turin and now has a controlling stake in Club Mediterranee, the vacation company. Through Fiat, the Agnellis branched out into insurance and energy, and Fiat owns La Stampa, the Turin newspaper. 
The family exerts control through what Italians call a cascade of companies, starting with the 100 percent-owned limited partnership, Giovanni Agnelli & Company, in which Gianni Agnelli has a 30 percent stake. Other shareholders are spread among the descendants of the two branches of the founding family, the Agnellis and the Nasis. That company, in turn, holds 100 percent of the family holding company IFI, which in turn has a 54 percent stake in another holding company, IFIL. The partnership owns 60 percent of the Exor Group, another link in the chain.
Between them, those holding companies, which are run by Umberto, hold 30 percent of Fiat.
But already, Fiat's woes are eating into the family's prime interests: in June, shares in IFI and IFIL fell as dividends were cut, reducing family members' income. 
For all that, said Stephen Reitmann, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in London, "the family is still enormously influential." 
That was clear in recent weeks, as Fiat juggled its top managers, trying to satisfy the family and outside investors. In June, Paolo Cantarella, the chief executive, was ousted as part of a realignment of Fiat management and was replaced by Gabriele Galateri, who had been chief executive of the family holding companies run by Umberto. In an unusual move, Mr. Galateri was named co-chief executive, along with Mr. Fresco, who remains chairman.
THE maneuver, though, was seen as furthering the influence of a younger brother who had long been sidelined in Fiat's affairs.
"Now, for obvious reasons of health, it's Umberto that has the ball," one friend of the family said. "In biographical terms, this is his trial, his opportunity. Even if it comes late in life, is he going to be just the liquidator of the family fortune or is there going to be something more than that?"
In May, Umberto told shareholders in the IFI holding company that Fiat's car business should be given every chance to revive its fortunes as part of the Fiat empire, but hinted that this was not the only option. "But if it is not possible, " he said, "we must give these people the possibility of working in the best and most calm way possible."
That was the broadest public hint that the younger Mr. Agnelli is less attached than Gianni to Fiat Auto, which accounts for less than one-fourth of the family's investments. 
But Umberto's ascent has occurred after many painful years. As the two men grew up, it was Gianni, with his hallmark fashion statements (watch worn over the cuff of his shirt, button-down collars never buttoned), his amours (Pamela Harriman among them), and his contacts (the Shah of Iran, the Kennedys, Mikhail Gorbachev) who stole the limelight. Still, about a dozen years ago, Gianni began speaking of Umberto as his likely successor.
That plan fell afoul of Cesare Romiti, called Il Duro -- the tough guy. He was Fiat's chief executive from 1976 to 1996 and later the chairman who, until he left the company in 1998, was seen by Agnelli watchers as a close ally of Mediobanca, the secretive Milan investment bank that masterminded much of Italy's idiosyncratic post-war capitalism.
So strong was his influence, according to Giancarlo Galli, author of "The Agnellis," published in Rome in 1997, that if Gianni Agnelli was emperor then Mr. Romiti was his Bismarck-like chancellor. Some former managers contend that Fiat's woes derive from the fact that the two men spent more time plotting their continued control of Fiat in the 1990's than on devising a strategic vision for it, particularly the car business.
The reality, Mr. Galli wrote, was that "neither Gianni nor Cesare had any intention of passing the baton, in spite of age, the company's oft-changed statutes or the petty conspiracies of the court," a reference to the family members and managers in Mr. Agnelli's circle.
Mr. Romiti, in this account, ended all talk of Umberto as a successor. But it was the question of succession that nonetheless brought terrible pain to the family. Early on, Umberto's only son, Giovanni Alberto Agnelli, had been anointed, only to die of a rare brain tumor at the age of 33 in 1997. Three years later, in 2000, Gianni's troubled only son, Edoardo, committed suicide after a life near an empire that would never admit him to its inner conclaves. 
At 46, Edoardo had apparently come to realize that his track record of dabbling in drugs, mysticism and oriental religions, of long journeys to India and Africa and of theories about the democratization of the workplace would preclude him from the succession. On Nov. 15, 2000, his Fiat Croma car was found on a 240-foot-high road bridge and his body was found beside a stream below. 
For Gianni, "it was a terrible, terrible blow, more than he ever said or expressed," said Ms. Agnelli, his sister. "He considered it was a failure on his part." For many Italians, she said, the death of Giovanni Alberto -- a golden boy blessed with looks, wealth and glamour -- "seemed an unwanted punishment for something, for having had too much."
By the time of Edoardo's death, though, it had become evident that Mr. Agnelli the patriarch was looking elsewhere for a successor. "He wanted someone from the family who was his direct descendant," said Ms. Agnelli, a former Italian foreign minister and leading political player. He chose his oldest grandson, John Philip Elkann, the son of Mr. Agnelli's daughter Margherita and her first husband, Alain Elkann.
Unlike his grandfather and mentor, John Elkann has not attracted gossip columnists. He grew up in Britain, Brazil and France, his father said, but attended state schools and "lived as a normal student" when he studied engineering in Turin.
Of course, his family connections carried him a long way. Mr. Fresco, the Fiat chairman, who had worked almost four decades at General Electric, secured him a temporary position with the G.E. corporate strategy group in 2000 and the audit staff from 2001 until this May.. He impressed people there as having "a nice level of self-confidence without being cocky," said William Conaty, a senior vice president of human resources for G.E. "He's pretty grounded," Mr. Conaty added.
This, of course, may no longer be an age when heirs can simply be anointed. Fiat's image has been badly dented not only with investors but among Italians themselves.
"We say that when things go well, Fiat and Agnelli make money, but when the economy starts limping, the state has to take care of Fiat and its workers," said Danilo Cruciani, 36, a shopkeeper in Rome. "I wonder if this role has become too much of a heavy burden for the country. And as a family myth, I think it is anyhow fading away."

HEADLINE: In Name Only; 
Call It the (Pick Your Poison) Recovery

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
TRY hapless recovery or nervous recovery or hidden recovery or reversible recovery or frail recovery or moderating recovery or anemic recovery or easily short-circuited recovery. Each of these descriptions of an uncertain economy has its constituents.
 The unhappy adjectives are proliferating as the recovery, which seemed so promising last winter, gives way in the summer to falling stock prices, multiplying corporate scandals and incessant layoffs. Not that recession has returned. But the mayhem is gradually robbing people of the feeling there is a genuine recovery under way, even though the statistics say otherwise. 
 "We are just getting to the beginning of the damage from the bubble," said Dean Baker, an economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington. "Even if we don't get a double dip back into a recession, we are going to get a weaker recovery than we normally see." 
The weird aftermath of the booming 1990's and the recession that brought those wild years to an end is like no other recovery since World War II. For a while last winter, when the output of goods and services rose rapidly, as it often has after previous recessions, the United States economy seemed to be sidestepping much damage from an overvalued stock market and excessive corporate expansion.
Sure enough, with the stock market holding its own in the first quarter, many forecasters declared that fears of a bursting bubble were unfounded. Corporate profits, after all, had shot up in the late 90's. And productivity -- the efficiency of workers -- had begun to rise again after years of stagnation. Perhaps the New Economy had some reality to it, and had lifted the United States to a permanently higher level of prosperity, interrupted occasionally by mild recessions.
Then the Enron accounting scandal spread, followed lately by the WorldCom fiasco and the restating of profits downward by dozens of companies -- all of this sapping public confidence in financial markets. Investors reasoned if the soaring corporate profits were part hoax, then so were the soaring stock prices, based as they were on the promise of rising corporate profitability. 
As a result, stock prices have plunged in recent weeks. While millions of Americans are nervously keeping an eye on their net worth, corporate America is struggling to restore profits -- true profits -- mainly by cutting costs. The telecommunications industry, with its wholesale layoffs and scaled-back operations, is an extreme example of this process. 
Still, despite all the battering, there is enough on the positive side of the economic ledger to keep the economy growing, if much more slowly than in the winter. The recovery lives, sustained mainly by consumer spending, made possible through rising debt as well as rising incomes and falling interest rates. It may even outlast the current setbacks.
Home construction is robust, and rising home prices mean families can cash out gains through new mortgages and use the money for spending or paying down debt. Some experts warn that the rapid increase in home prices may be another bubble about to burst, wreaking more damage on the economy, but so far, at least, housing has helped to prop up the recovery.
In a backhanded way, even the stock market is helping the economy. As investors shift money from stocks to interest-bearing bonds and Treasury securities, the demand for these investments has helped to drive down interest rates, including mortgage rates. Low rates in turn have sustained the home-sale boom, although this dynamic has its limits.
"It would be disastrous," Albert M. Wojnilower, a Wall Street economist, wrote recently, if falling stock prices became the principal source of low interest rates.
Missing in action during the recovery has been capital spending by companies for new machinery, software, computers, office space and all the many tools of production. When chief executives realized they had over-expanded, they cut back sharply on this spending, bringing on a recession that started in March 2001. Business spending has finally stopped falling, but until it revives, most economists say, the recovery is likely to be weak at best, and overly dependent on housing and consumer spending. 
Historians will undoubtedly liken the early years of the 21st century to the aftermath of the booming 1920's, when inflated stock prices, excessive expansion and corporate and financial dishonesty also had to be reversed. Then, bank failures led to a rapid unraveling of the economy. "If there is a financial smash now, all bets are off," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant and forecaster.
Almost no one anticipates an aftermath to the 90's as disastrous as the Great Depression, certainly not Mr. Bernstein. Despite the multiplying troubles, nearly every forecaster is betting on a recovery. "You can call it a tentative recovery, but I would not go any further," said ChrisVarvares, president of Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis. And turning to a metaphor, as forecasters so often do, he declared, "We are experiencing a little turbulence on takeoff, but the flight will be fine."
So how do you define a recovery anyway? The six distinguished economists who serve as the nation's official designators of recoveries and recessions are themselves having trouble labeling this cycle. The popular definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters in which the gross domestic product contracts. A recovery begins once the economy has expanded for at least two quarters.
By these definitions, the single quarter in which the economy contracted -- from July through September last year -- did not even constitute a recession. But the six economists, who serve on the Business Cycle Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research, are guided by different standards. 
THE committee tracks four basic indicators of economic health: employment, industrial production, personal income and wholesale and retail sales. When these rise to a peak and then start down, a recession has begun. When they bottom out and rise again, passing the previous peak, then the committee looks back and in hindsight declares that the recovery began when those key indicators began their ascent.
Three of the four indicators have not only begun rising but have already exceeded their previous peaks. The economy is clearly generating more output than in March of last year, the last peak. That explains why the G.D.P. has continued to rise. What has not recovered at all is employment. The economy lost 1.8 million jobs from March 2001 through April, and only 60,000 have reappeared since then, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported on Friday.
The employment problem has persuaded some economists, including Robert Hall of Stanford University, chairman of the Dating Cycle Committee, that recovery isn't a sure thing. For Professor Hall, employment weighs more heavily than the three other indicators combined. "If employment had grown more rapidly over the last few months and had passed its old peak, then there is no question where we would stand," he said. 
Until that happens, he shies away from recovery or recession as proper labels. He leans toward recovery, of course, but if the other indicators should falter before employment comes back, then Professor Hall would be prepared to declare a double-dip recession or a prolonged recession. "In my years on the committee, which started in 1978," Professor Hall said, "we have stuck to the rule that we would not call it a recovery until we saw employment back to its previous peak."
So add "jobless recovery" to the list of ways to describe this uncertain moment in post-boom America.
